Development Tendencies of Forest Management Research in Taiwan as Exemplified by TFRI's Publications in the Last 50 years

The study aims at analyzing the relationships between the research tendency and human resources in terms of forest management subject of Taiwan Forestry Research Institute (TFRI) from 1947 to 2000 by means of adopting bibliometrics and sociometrics. There were 165 papers regarding forest management completed within the period, equivalently 15% of the amount of TFRI’s total papers published. Quantitatively, these researches were mostly focused on traditional forest management, forest economics and forest planning, but less concentrated on forest policy and forest recreation. Generally speaking, the papers still stressed on the core concepts of traditional forest management such as timber production or plantation management; however, new issues from the viewpoints of ecology and society emerged in the last decade. Since TFRI is suffered from the shortage of manpower, the minority of researchers who have high academic productivity usually dominate its performance in forest management subject. The study also indicates that the faster the turnover of researchers, the more the innovation and diffusion of research concepts.
Cheng Chi-ChaunTFRIHead of Division of Forest Managementcoauther

bibliometricsbibliometrics includes content analysis,citation analysis,creating thesauri; measuring term frequencies; exploring grammatical and syntactical structures of texts.sociometricsSociometrics is described as a science that involves the study and measurement of relationships, social structures, and mental health. It involves the measurement of groups and the behavior and status of individuals within such groups.Sociometrics involves taking a different approach to understanding group alliances. Unlike other sciences, it requires the exploration of social groups and organizations from the core of the structures. Sociometrics deals with revealing and analyzing the hidden beliefs, alliances, and hidden agendas of group structures. It also involves the analysis of group substructure. Sociometrics works under the premise that each of these elements, from alliances to subgroups, combine to give form to groups and organizations.

Phylogenetic systematics of the monotypic genus Hayataella (Rubiaceae) endemic to Taiwan

Hayataella (Rubiaceae) is a monotypic genus endemic to Taiwan that comprises H. michelloides. In recent year, Hayataella was considered to be synonymous with Ophiorrhiza; however, no specific data have been reported, and the systematic treatment of Hayataella has been unclear. To elucidate the systematic treatment of Hayataella, molecular phylogenetic analyses based on ITS of nrDNA, atpB-rbcL, and trnK/matK of cpDNA were conducted with four Ophiorrhiza species.In the Bayesian and the most parsimonious trees, H. michelloides was included in the Ophiorrhiza clade. The monotypic status of Hayataella is, therefore, not cosidered appropriate, and the combination Ophiorriza michelloides (Masam.) H. S. Lo is supported.
Division of Forestry Biology, Taiwan Forestry Research Institute

Cytotoxic Constituents from the Leaves of Cinnamomum subavenium

Two new butanolides, subamolide D (1) and subamolide E (2), and a new secobutanolide, secosubamolide A (3), along with 21 known compounds were isolated from the leaves of Cinnamomum subavenium. The structures of 1—3 were determined by spectroscopic analysis. Propidium iodide staining and cytometry analysis were used to evaluate the cell cycle progression of the treated SW480 cells and it was found that 1 and 2 caused DNA damage in a dose- and time-dependent manner.

ExperimentalMelting points were determined using a Yanagimoto micro-melting point apparatus and are uncorrected. Optical rotations were measured with a JASCO DIP-370 digital polarimeter. UV spectra were obtained in MeCN using a JASCO V-530 spectrophotometer. The IR spectra were measured on a Hitachi 260-30 spectrophotometer. 1H (400 MHz, using CDCl3 as solvent for measurement), 13C (100 MHz), DEPT, HETCOR, COSY, NOESY, and HMBC NMR spectra were obtained on a Unity Plus Varian NMR spectrometer. LR-FAB-MS and LR-EI-MS were obtained with a JEOL JMS-SX/SX 102A mass spectrometer or a Quattro GC-MS spectrometer with a direct inlet system. HR-FAB-MS and HR-EI-MS were measured on a JEOL JMSHX 110 mass spectrometer. Silica gel 60 (Merck, 230—400 mesh) was usedfor column chromatography. Precoated silica gel plates (Merck, Kieselgel 60 F-254, 0.20 mm) were used for analytical TLC, and precoated silica gel plates (Merck, Kieselgel 60 F-254, 0.50 mm) were used for preparative TLC.Spots were detected by spraying with 50% H2SO4 and then heating on a hot plate. Flow cytometry analysis was performed using a Becton-Dickinson FACS-Calibur flow cytometer. The DNA labeling dye, propidium iodide (PI), was used to determine DNA damage and the cell cycle progression.28,29) Data is presented as meansstandard deviation (S.D.) and analyzed using one-way ANOVA with Scheffe’s test. A p value of less than 0.05 was consideredas statistically significant.Plant MaterialThe leaves of C. subavenium were collected from Wulai Hsiang, Taipei County, Taiwan in May, 2005. A voucher specimen (Cinnamo. 5) was characterized by one of the authors (Y.-R.H.) and deposited in the Basic Medical Science Education Center, Fooyin University, Kaohsiung County, Taiwan.Extraction and IsolationThe air-dried leaves of C. subavenium (11.0 kg) were extracted with MeOH (50 l_6) at room temperature and a MeOH extract (326.5 g) was obtained upon concentration under reduced pressure. The MeOH extract, suspended in H2O (1 l), was partitioned with CHCl3 (2 l_5) to give fractions soluble in CHCl3 (198.5 g) and H2O (101.2 g). The CHCl3-soluble fraction (198.5 g) was chromatographed over silica gel (800 g, 70—230 mesh) using n-hexane/EtOAc/MeOH mixtures as eluents to produce five fractions. Part of fraction 1 (9.33 g) was subjected to silica gel chromatography by eluting with n-hexane–EtOAc (20 : 1), enriched with EtOAc to furnish five fractions (1-1—1-5). Fraction 1-1 (7.02 g) was subjected to further silica gel chromatography, eluting with n-hexane–EtOAc (100 : 1) and enriched gradually with EtOAc, to obtain three fractions (1-1-1—1-1-3). Fraction 1-1-1 (2.41 g) was further purified by passage over another silica gel column using n-hexane/EtOAc mixtures to obtain stearic acid (42 mg), palmitic acid (57 mg), squalene (23 mg), aristophyll-C (25 mg), and pheophytin-a (10 mg). Fraction 1-1-2 (1.64 g), eluted with n-hexane–EtOAc (30 : 1), was further separated using silica gel column chromatography and preparative TLC (n-hexane–EtOAc (30 : 1) and gave linderanolide B (32 mg) and isolinderanolide B (45 mg). Fraction 1-1-3 (1.11 g) was subjected to silica gel column chromatography and purified by preparative TLC (thin layer chromatography) to yield p-hydroxybenzoic acid (15 mg), p-hydroxybenzaldehyde (19 mg), syringic acid (4 mg), vanillin (12 mg), and vanillic acid (19 mg). Fraction 1-2 (3.02 g) was subjected to silica gel chromatography, eluted with n-hexane–EtOAc (50 : 1) and enriched gradually with EtOAc, to obtain three fractions (1-2-1—1-2-3). Fraction 1-2-2 (2.26 g), eluted with nhexane–EtOAc (40 : 1), was further separated using silica gel column chromatography and preparative TLC (n-hexane–EtOAc (30 : 1) and gave submolide D (1) (34 mg), submolide E (2) (51 mg) and secosubamolide A (3) (12 mg). Part of fraction 2 (8.11 g) was subjected to silica gel chromatography by eluting with n-hexane–EtOAc (10 : 1), then enriched gradually with EtOAc to furnish five fractions (2-1—2-5). Fraction 2-1 (2.02 g) was subjected to silica gel chromatography, eluting with CHCl3–MeOH (100 : 1), and enriched gradually with MeOH, to obtain five fractions (2-1-1—2-1-5). Fractions 2-1-1 (0.31 g) and 2-1-2 (0.24 g) were subjected to further silica gel column chromatography and purified by preparative TLC (thin layer chromatography) to yield eugenol (24 mg), and a mixture of ficaprenol-10 and ficaprenol-11 (48 mg). Fraction 2-4 (1.21 g) was subjected to silica gel chromatography, eluting with n-hexane–EtOAc (40 : 1), and enriched gradually with EtOAc to obtain five fractions (2-4-1—2-4-5). Fraction 2-4-3 (1.31 g), eluted with n-hexane–EtOAc (10 : 1), was further separated using silica gel column chromatography and preparative TLC (n-hexane–EtOAc (20 : 1) and gave caryophyllene (57 mg). Fraction 2-5 (6.03 g, nhexane–EtOAc (10 : 1) was purified by passage over a silica gel column (400 g, 230—400 mesh), using CHCl3/MeOH, to obtain a mixture of b-sitosterol and stigmasterol (1.34 g). Part of fraction 3 (7.21 g) was subjected to silica gel chromatography by eluting with n-hexane–EtOAc (1 : 1) and enriched gradually with EtOAc, to furnish five fractions (3-1—3-5). Part of fraction 4 (2.42 g) was subjected to silica gel chromatography by eluting with n-hexane–EtOAc (1 : 5), enriched with EtOAc to furnish five further fractions (4-1—4-5). Fraction 4-2 (1.62 g) was purified on a silica gel column (200 g, 230—400 mesh) using CHCl3/MeOH mixtures to obtain (_)-abscisic acid (21 mg). A mixture of b-sitosteryl-D-glucoside and stigmasteryl-D-glucoside (50 mg) was recrystallized (MeOH) from fraction 5. Theknown compounds have been characterized by comparison of their spectroscopicdata with literature values.Cell Culture and Drug TreatmentThe human colon cancer cell line (SW480) was obtained from the American Type Culture Collection (Rockville, MD, U.S.A.). The SW480 cells were cultured in DMEM supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 100 units/ml penicillin G and 100m g/ml streptomycin at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 humidified atmosphere. Stock solutions of 1 and 2 (100mM) were dissolved in DMSO and various concentrations were prepared in DMEM basal medium with a final DMSO concentration of 0.1%.Cell Cycle AnalysisFor determination of cell cycle progression, the cells were analyzed by flow cytometry.28,29) The colon cells were seeded at a density of 5105 per 60-mm tissue-culture dish. Culture medium was replenished when cells were 80% confluent. Monolayers were treated with various concentrations—of 1 and 2 for 24 h. At the end of treatment, adherent and floating cells were collected, washed twice with PBS, then fixed with PBS–methanol (1 : 2, volume/volume) solution, and stored at 4 °C for at least 18 h. After centrifugation, cell pellets were stained with PBS containing 50m g/ml propidium iodide (PI), and 50m g/ml DNase-free RNaseA for 30 min at room temperature in the dark. The samples were analyzed in a Becton-Dickinson system of FACS-Calibur flow cytometer by using CellQuest software. The percentage of cell cycle phases (G0/G1, S, and G2/M) was quantified using a ModFit LT software (BD Biosciences).

森林下層植物在演替過程中的碳收支動態反應 (2/3)

在台灣北部、中部、南部、東部海拔500 m以下之人工林分及相似生育條件之天然林，每地區2-3大樣區(1 ha)。人工林包括近年執行之平地造林地、相思樹林及木麻黃林。利用生物量估算不同森林下層植被每公頃之碳吸存量。瞭解低海拔地區平地造林林分、相思樹林分、木麻黃林分及相似地區之天然林分下層植群之組成。完成低海拔地區各代表林分下層植群之碳吸存量分析。木麻黃（Casuarina equisetifolia）林分之下層植物生物量，以太麻里樣區蓄積最高，平均達3.1 Mg ha-1；四湖樣區最少僅0.95 Mg ha-1；相思樹（Acacia confusa）林分之下層植物生物量，以通宵樣區最高，為5.02 Mg ha-1，此數據亦遠大於木麻黃最高之每公頃生物量平均蓄積。木麻黃調查中，主要下層生物量蓄積物種為馬纓丹（Lantana camara）、巴拉草（Brachiaria mutica）、大花咸豐草（Bidens pilosa）、瓊麻（Agave sisalana）及雙面刺（Zanthoxylum nitidum）等，含碳百分比依序為馬纓丹44.92%、瓊麻40.15%、大花咸豐草40%、瓊麻40.15%、雙面刺43.81%。相思樹林主要下層生物量蓄積物種為大黍、馬纓丹、扛香藤（Mallotus repandus）等，含碳百分比依序為大黍36.14%、馬纓丹45.12%、扛香藤43.43%。從生物多樣性角度中，木麻黃下層植物種類以太麻里樣區的歧異度最高，植物種類達40種。相思樹下層植物物種歧異度最高之樣區為恆春半島樣區，植物種類達36種。

生物量取樣生物量的量取小樣區內之灌木分葉部、枝條、根部，其他各類草本植物則以全株計量，先量測所有植物的鮮重。再分灌木、雙子葉草本、單子葉草本、蕨類植物等，各部位取100g左右之新鮮材料攜回實驗室，以70℃之烘箱烘至絕乾後秤重。碳氮分析碳氮分析將攜回實驗室各樣本烘至絕乾，取其根、莖、葉部磨成細粉(< 0.5 mm)，再以元素分析儀測定其碳及氮濃度。可由此推估出林下植物碳和氮總貯存量。分別在台灣北、中、南區之中、低海拔之天然林，每一樣區內隨機設置4個20×25m樣區，每個樣區依系統取樣法取5個5×5m小樣區，總樣區數為60個。紀錄區內植物種類及覆蓋度，並量測其下層植物生物量。1生物量的量取：小樣區內之灌木分葉部、枝條、根部，其他各類草本植物則以全株計量，先量測所有植物的鮮重。再分灌木、雙子葉草本、單子葉草本、蕨類植物等，各部位取100g左右之新鮮材料攜回實驗室，以70℃之烘箱烘至絕乾後秤重。 2將攜回實驗室各樣本烘至絕乾，取其根、莖、葉部磨成細粉(< 0.5 mm)，再以元素分析儀測定其碳及氮濃度。可由此推估出林下植物碳和氮總貯存量。

森林下層植物在演替過程中的碳收支動態反應 (2/3)
Genetic differentiation of eulophid wasp Quadrastichus erythrinae Kim (Hymenoptera: Eulophidae) from various Erythrina hosts based on mitochondrial and nuclear genes

Many Erythrina trees were found wilting initially and suffering die-back later due to severe infestations by Quadrastichus erythrinae (Hymenoptera: Eulophidae) in Mauritius, Réunion, and Singapore since 2000. It then has widely spread into various countries in tropical and subtropical areas. Various degrees of damage and different symptoms were observed on different host species which raised a question whether the pest belong to same species or not. In order to measure the differentiation of the Erythrina eulophid wasps from different geographic area and host plants, 36 samples from 14 localities of Taiwan and 11 samples from Singapore and Mauritius were collected. Singapore and Mauritius was two of the three countries included in the original description of the new species of Quadrastichus erythrinae Kim. We analyzed mitochondrial genes of 12S ribosomal RNA and cytochrome oxidase I, and nuclear sequence of intergenic spacer 2 to understand their genetic variation and phylogenetic relationship. Sequences of the same region in all the three genes are identical among all the samples. The homogeneity of the genetic composition suggests that there were no cryptic species in the samples. It confirms that all the wasps sampled in this study, despite their different origins in areas and hosts, are belong to the same species. Apparently, all the pests in these countries came from the same monomorphic genotype which quickly and widely spread to other areas.

In order to measure geographic variation and to identify the Erythrina eulophid wasps from different host plants, samples from various areas and hosts were collected. These included 36 samples from 14 localities of Taiwan and 11 samples from Singapore and Mauritius (Table 1). Singapore and Mauritius was two of the three countries included in the original description of the new species of Quadrastichus erythrinae Kim. Samples of Taiwan were collected from six Erythrina taxa, including 19 samples from E. variegata, 10 from E. variegata var. orientalis, 3 from E. corallodendron, 2 from E. crista-galli, 1 from E. abyssinica, and 1 from E. berteroana. Samples outside Taiwan covers 7 from E. fusca in Singapore and 4 from E. variegata in Mauritius.

Bigleaf mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla King) seeds in Taiwan exhibit orthodox storage behaviour

The storage behaviour of Swietenia macrophylla King seeds (Meliaceae) was studied. Seeds that were dried to 3.7% moisture content and stored at 3°C for two years had a 82.7% germination. The two-year stored seeds were then transferred to -196°C and -20°C for continued storage for another one and two years, respectively. Result showed that seeds stored at either -20°C or -196°C retained their original germinability. Thus, seeds of S. macrophylla harvested in Taiwan exhibit orthodox storage behaviour.

Seed harvesting and handling Bigleaf mahogany seeds used in this study were collected from Kaohsiung county, south-western Taiwan in March 2004. Annual rainfall and annual mean temperature in the collection site are about 1,952 mm and 25.3°C, respectively (statistical analysis from 2000 to 2008). The brown fruits were air-dried in the sun for about 4 days until they had opened. Seeds were mechanically and manually extracted. The winged part of the seeds was removed by hand, followed by fanning to separate wings from seeds. De-winged seeds were dried in the sun for another 3 days to reduce the moisture content. Each fruit contained about 60 brown-winged seeds. Drying treatment and storage conditions The dried seeds were drawn from a bulk collection, which were stored at 3°C in the Tree Seed Bank of Dongshih Forest District Office, Taiwan Forest Bureau for 2 years. Moisture contents (fresh weight basis) of the two-year-old seeds were determined by an oven-dry method with four replications each of intact seeds, corky wings and embryos separately at 70°C and 80°C for 24 hours, and at 103°C for 17 hours (ISTA, 1999). Results of the moisture contents analysis are summarized in table 1. The order of seed moisture contents from high to low in the intact seeds, corky wings, and embryos as determined by the three different oven-drying temperatures was 103°C > 80°C > 70°C. Table 1 also shows that corky wings retained a higher moisture content than did embryos. Seeds typically have higher moisture in embryos than in the seed coat or pericarp. Thus, the corky wings possessing extensive air spaces may have caused the higher moisture content. Prior to transferring the two-year-stored seeds from 3°C to -20°C and -196°C (in liquid nitrogen) for continued storage, a germination test was conducted with alternating temperatures of 30/20°C with 12 h of light at the higher temperature for 8 weeks. Following this reassessment of seed quality, the drawn seed samples were wrapped in sealed aluminum foil and stored at -20°C for two years and -196°C for one year. Germination of seeds was based on samples of 75 seeds in three replications of 25 each. Seed treatment methods and statstical analysis The germination test was carried out by mixing seeds with sphagnum medium (cut into small piece) at a 75%~80% moisture content in sealable polyethylene bags (0.04 mm thick) and then incubating them at the alternating temperature of 30/20°C with 12 h of light at the higher temperature for 8 weeks. The progress of germination was monitored weekly, and mean percentages of germination were calculated and compared by analysis of variance (ANOVA) and by the least significant difference (LSD) test at a 5% level of significance. The mean germination time (MGT) in days was calculated as: MGT = (Σniti)/N, where ni is the number of seeds germinated in ti days from the beginning of the test, and N is the total number of germinated seeds at the end of the test. The MGT is a measure of the rate of germination and of the sharpness of the germination peak.

Micropropagation and evaluation of the camptothecin content of Camptotheca acuminata-CPT analysis

Micropropagation and comptothecin content of shoot tips and nodal stem explants of Camptotheca aucminata, a plant known to have anti-cancer properties, derived from in vitro seedlings were investigated. Induction of multiple shoots from shoot tip explants was much greater than that from stem explants. The greatest shoot production induced from shoot tip explants was achieved on woody plant medium(WPM) with 0.01 mg L-1 α-naphthileneacetic acid(NAA) + 0.5 mg L-1 benzyladenine(BA), forming an average of 6.4 buds per explant in 6 wk. Elongation of these multiple shoots was successful at a lower BA level (0.1 mg L-1) on WPM. Individual shoots were rooted on WPM supplemented with indole-3-butyric acid(IBA) or NAA. A concentration of 1 mg L-1 IBA gave the highest percentage of rooting (100%) and root number (5.6 roots/shoot). The camptothecin content in leaves of seedlings and their micropropagated plants raised from the mother plants grown at Taipei Batonical Garden, and Lienhuachin Central, Taiwan were significantly greater than those from Jiangsu Province, China. Comptothecin of seedlings among the 3 provenances significantly differed. Since a highly positive correlation was found between the comptothecin content of seedlings and their micropropagated plants, this suggests that it is feasible to mass propogate C. acuminata plants cultured in vitro in order to obtain desired clones with high camptothecin content.

The tissue (1 g) was freeze dried and ground to a fine powder with a mortar and pestle. The powdered tissue was extracted 2 times with 20 ml of methanol by sonication, each extraction for 30 min. After sonication, the combined methanolic extract was transfer into glass tube (16 mm x 100 mm) and evaporated to dryness at 40℃ in vacuum evaporator [concentration workstation? For analysis, 1 ml methanol was added to the residue and vortexed for 20 seconds, the mixture was filtered through a 0.2 μm filter (Whatman Inc., Fairfield, NJ), The filtrate solution transferred to clean glass vials for analysis.Isocratic analytical HPLC was performed on a Waters system with a 2996 system photodiode-array detector. (Milford. MA, USA) using a Chromolith Performance RP-18u monolithic column {5μm, 150x4.6mm}(Supelco Disscovery, Bellefonte, PA, USA). The mobile phase for alkaloid elution was 0.03M ammoniumacetate:acetonitrile(60:40), at a flow rate of 1 ml/min with a sample size of 10μl and UV detection at 254nm. The results were also confirmed at 365nm. The quantification of peak area was based on the calibration using a external standard of CPT (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA). 蓮華池研究中心藥用植物園氣象資料 (2012/12/21~2014/02/06)

本資料集所描述的是智慧生態計畫－生態及生物多樣性資訊基礎建設與應用計畫透過計畫合作，介接本所科技計畫於蓮華池研究中心藥園所設置之Anodroid行動裝置SensorPod的氣象觀測系統，進行資料的收集與倉儲，而所有的氣象資料，均可於生態感測資料展示平台（http://iesn.tfri.gov.tw）上查閱，並以開放資料形式提供生態感測開放資料平台(http://iesn.tfri.gov.tw/forestDW/OpenData)作為資料來源之一。

Establishment of commercial taxol-production-tech by culturing Taiwan yew cells in bioreactors (2/3) - Transgenic cell culture

The company cooperated with Taiwan Forestry Research Institute has been decide to produce taxol by bioreactors in Taiwan. To establish the scale up system between lab and commercial production of taxol is very important. This project tries to moitor factors that increase culture volume from 5-L to 20-L and 100-L bioreactor. This pilot study will be decrease the risk of commercial scale might met. Cell cultured in a 5-L bioreactor created by cooperated company worked well. The 20-L bioreactor was designed and produced by the company. The another important work in this project is to try the transgenic cells transformed with auxin, TS, and DBAT genes in suspension cultures to evaluate these cell lines with the better performance than normal cell cultures.

台灣森林物種基因條碼及種質基因庫之建立與保存利用（1/4）

生物多樣性是全球的研究議題，除了生態系和物種的研究，分子技術使基因多樣性的研究變得方便又快速。物種保育措施或政策的擬定，須參考基因多型性所的資訊，基因條碼和因資料庫的建立，有助於基因多樣性資料的提供。森林中有包括植物與菌類的各式物種，是生物多樣性保育與利用之焦點。本研究藉由基因條碼和基因資料庫的建立，佐以形態構造之結果，提供本土森林植物在保育與永續利用便捷的辨識方式。就域外保育與永續利用材料之取得，種質保存是一高度利用空間、克服因豐欠年無法獲得材料的有效方法。本計畫亦擬選擇台灣特稀有樹種，每年進行針闊葉樹各2種的種子保存研究；調查具利用價值的腐朽菌，進行培養保存，以達到區外保育與利用目的。

森林野生物基因條碼和基因資料庫的建立森林野生物基因條碼建立：將包括台灣重要森林組成物種和具經濟潛力植物，如蕨類石松科植物、裸子植物、殼斗科、樟科、茶科、杜鵑花科等重要的原生植物，建立DNA序列基因庫。利用核糖體DNA的ITS、葉綠體DNA等序列資料，建立生物基因條碼。本年度擬以蕨類石松科、裸子植物及殼斗科植物對象，利用核糖體DNA的ITS、葉綠體DNA的基因間序列(intergenric spacer)等基因序列，建立生物條碼。條碼資料庫的建立：序列必須登入資料庫內，才能進行比對或提供作為其他研究的資料。現有林試所植物標本館已有植物標本資料庫，條碼資料庫將可連結標本資料庫，每一獲得條碼的樣本都必須有一存證標本藏於標本館內供比對，尚需有分類群描述和登錄。條碼資料庫的建立可配合植物標本館的證據標本和分類描述，連結林業試驗所植物標本館資料庫，建立成完整的資料庫。高海拔樹種種子保存與族群生態環境調查高海拔種子保存：採集高海拔針葉樹冷杉、雲杉毬果和闊葉樹高山櫟、狹葉櫟果實，進行種子的發芽和乾燥儲藏，以瞭解種子的儲藏性質，乾儲型、濕儲型或中間型。試驗方法是將種子控制成至少三種不同的含水率，和新鮮的種子，儲藏在至少三種溫度，如-20℃、4℃和15℃，然後調查種子發芽率，以瞭解種子儲藏後之保持情形。族群生態環境之調查：族群密度、樹種大小結構、生育地環境、微環境氣候、其他植物種類等。具利用價值腐朽菌調查、培養及保存木材腐朽菌的調查：木材腐朽菌是棲息於木本植物木材組織的真菌，其引起木材腐朽造成材積減少及木材品質降低，其可能造成嚴重之經濟損失。但有些木材腐朽菌具有食用及藥用價值，極具經濟價值。另有些木材腐朽菌具有重要生態地位，如推動森林演替，可見木材腐朽菌具有有益及有害雙重地位，本研究調查木材腐朽菌之種類、寄主範圍及重要經濟地位，並建立資料庫，調查方法有文獻回顧及野外調查。木材腐朽菌的培養與保存：將所獲得的木材腐朽菌進行純化培養，並將菌種保存，以供開發利用。
中文學名 依據台灣植物誌及植物簡誌

台灣森林物種基因條碼及種質基因庫之建立與保存利用（1/4）

Species name拉丁學名拉丁學名Chinese name中文學名 依據台灣植物誌及植物簡誌中文文字Sample site採集地中文文字Code採集地英文縮寫英文字母Number採樣樣木編號數字Sequence of atpB-rbcL葉綠體DNA atpB-rbcL 序列文字Sequence of trnL-trnF葉綠體DNA trnL-trnF序列文字Sequence of trnP-petG葉綠體DNA trnP-petG序列文字
台灣二葉松地上部生物量及碳貯存之估算

The study was research on estimation of the aboveground biomass and carbon storage of 34 year old Taiwan red pine ( Pinus taiwanensis ) plantation in Lishan area located in central Taiwan. According to the DBH distribution of stand, allometric equation established by stem analysis data of sample trees, and the value of convert coefficient built by the least squares method. Furthermore, elemental analyzer was used to analyze carbon content of the sample taken from trees harvested. The results show that estimated aboveground biomass were 178.33±22.13tonha-1 by DBH-biomass-volume equations and related convert coefficients, and 81.1% was in stem. Current aboveground biomass production were 1.9±0.3tonha-1yr-1 by volume increment formula. In terms of carbon concentration, there are different among different tissues. The mean values rank as：bark（49.4±1.3﹪）≒live branch（49.0±0.3﹪）≒leaf（48.5±0.5﹪）＞dead branch（47.9±0.7﹪）＞stem（45.9±0.7﹪）,and carbon concentration of living tree is 46.9±0.1％. Meanwhile, carbon storage in aboveground of trees estimated were 81.6±9.9tonha-1 , and current carbon sequestration were 0.9±0.3 tonha-1yr-1, that means 3.3±1.0 co2 tonha-1yr-1 were sequestrated into the aboveground parts of Taiwan red pine plantation .

研究資料為宜蘭大學自然資源學系林世宗教授擁有,如需要使用本報告之任何原始資料,請與林世宗教授聯繫,於獲得同意後方可使用原始資料進行研究或作為其他用途.
研究資料為宜蘭大學自然資源學系林世宗教授擁有,如需要使用本報告之任何原始資料,請與林世宗教授聯繫,於獲得同意後方可使用原始資料進行研究或作為其他用途.

材料與方法試驗地位於大甲溪事業區44、45林班之34年生二葉松造林地，海拔2050m，南向坡，設9個40mx25m生物量調查樣區，調查樹高2公尺以上之林木測量其胸徑。採分層取樣選取二葉松樣木，依調查資料之胸徑級分布，每徑級取5~6株樣木，共分5級，台灣二葉松共取28株，選定之樣木伐倒後測量其樹高與地上部生物調查。(Ⅰ)、生物量調查自樣木上先取所有枯枝秤重後將冠層等分為上、中、下三層，分別秤各層之枝、葉鮮重，樣木樹幹則依樹幹解析方式分段秤鮮重，再自各層分別逢機取枝葉次樣本，樹幹則取至胸高、樹冠基部及樹冠中部之圓盤次樣本分離樹皮及木材，秤鮮重後再以70℃烘至絕乾重，計算各樣木之葉、枝、枯枝、樹皮及木材乾鮮比，復由樣木各部位鮮重轉換為乾重，總加為樣木乾重，即樣木地上部生物量，並進行Duncan’s檢定各部位之碳濃度之差異。(Ⅱ)、台灣二葉松樹幹解析自生物量調查樣木中取20株林木，依樹幹解析方法，於各高度取3-5公分厚之橫斷面圓盤，陰乾後經刨光磨平後經電子掃描建立影像檔，利用德國Ligno vision軟體分析量測各圓盤樹輪寬，以smalian分段求積法計算各樣木材積及其胸徑生長量。(Ⅲ)、樣木各部位物質碳濃度分析與樣木碳含量估算自不同徑級之9株樣木中以各部位次樣本經烘乾(70℃)再以切碎磨粉過篩(≦0.2mm)裝袋密封，以元素分析儀（HERAEUS Vario, EL-Ⅲ, Germany）分析碳濃度，由樣木各部位碳濃度與乾重，總加為樣木碳含量，樣木平均碳濃度則以樣木各部位乾重為加權值乘其碳濃度計算。(Ⅳ)、相關性分析與林分碳存量推估就不同徑級林木之生長參數(DBH、H)、林木生物量、材積等進行相關性分析，以最小平方法(least squares method)估算建立各項參數之轉換係數(convert coefficient)值，包括地上部生物量與樹幹生物量比值，即擴張係數（expansion factor, EFabove）、樹幹生物量與其連皮材積比值，即立木密度（stem density）與立木木材密度（basic density），即木材乾重與去皮材積之比值。並採用相對生長迴歸式與材積轉換係數推估台灣二葉松林木地上部生物量及碳存量。

材料與方法試驗地位於大甲溪事業區44、45林班之34年生二葉松造林地，海拔2050m，南向坡，設9個40mx25m生物量調查樣區，調查樹高2公尺以上之林木測量其胸徑。採分層取樣選取二葉松樣木，依調查資料之胸徑級分布，每徑級取5~6株樣木，共分5級，台灣二葉松共取28株，選定之樣木伐倒後測量其樹高與地上部生物調查。(Ⅰ)、生物量調查自樣木上先取所有枯枝秤重後將冠層等分為上、中、下三層，分別秤各層之枝、葉鮮重，樣木樹幹則依樹幹解析方式分段秤鮮重，再自各層分別逢機取枝葉次樣本，樹幹則取至胸高、樹冠基部及樹冠中部之圓盤次樣本分離樹皮及木材，秤鮮重後再以70℃烘至絕乾重，計算各樣木之葉、枝、枯枝、樹皮及木材乾鮮比，復由樣木各部位鮮重轉換為乾重，總加為樣木乾重，即樣木地上部生物量，並進行Duncan’s檢定各部位之碳濃度之差異。(Ⅱ)、台灣二葉松樹幹解析自生物量調查樣木中取20株林木，依樹幹解析方法，於各高度取3-5公分厚之橫斷面圓盤，陰乾後經刨光磨平後經電子掃描建立影像檔，利用德國Ligno vision軟體分析量測各圓盤樹輪寬，以smalian分段求積法計算各樣木材積及其胸徑生長量。(Ⅲ)、樣木各部位物質碳濃度分析與樣木碳含量估算自不同徑級之9株樣木中以各部位次樣本經烘乾(70℃)再以切碎磨粉過篩(≦0.2mm)裝袋密封，以元素分析儀（HERAEUS Vario, EL-Ⅲ, Germany）分析碳濃度，由樣木各部位碳濃度與乾重，總加為樣木碳含量，樣木平均碳濃度則以樣木各部位乾重為加權值乘其碳濃度計算。(Ⅳ)、相關性分析與林分碳存量推估就不同徑級林木之生長參數(DBH、H)、林木生物量、材積等進行相關性分析，以最小平方法(least squares method)估算建立各項參數之轉換係數(convert coefficient)值，包括地上部生物量與樹幹生物量比值，即擴張係數（expansion factor, EFabove）、樹幹生物量與其連皮材積比值，即立木密度（stem density）與立木木材密度（basic density），即木材乾重與去皮材積之比值。並採用相對生長迴歸式與材積轉換係數推估台灣二葉松林木地上部生物量及碳存量。
台灣二葉松地上部生物量及碳貯存之估算
農業生態系研究與生態資訊系統建構(國際合作)

農業生態系有別於自然生態系，其運作與管理影響生物多樣性之保存與利用及人類社會之永續發展與生存，故行政院國家科學委員會將於2006年開始農業生態系之長期生態研究。美國在其國科會的支持下，已建立26個長期生態研究站，並已有相當豐碩之成果。但其中僅有Kellogg Biological Station (KBS) 屬於溫帶農業生態研究站。雖然台灣所建立的為亞熱帶的農業生態研究站，但為草創期，我國若能與其發展技術合作與互訪，進行交流，KBS數十年在長期農業生態研究上的經驗，應可為我國進行此一方面研究之參考，節省研究初期所需付出之學習時間與經費。同時亦針對其在長期農業生態系研究資料系統之建置與管理進行交流，期能加速台灣在此一領域之科技腳步，進行資料之分享，並提供完整且多元之農業生態系資訊的服務。 台灣長期生態研究已在過去十年累積了大量且龐雜的生態資料，其包含了時間與空間資料，但這些資料均分散在各個生態學家或少數小型資料庫內，在資料整合與分享上十分困難。為提升台灣生態資料價值與國際地位，資訊的整合與分享是絕對必要的。美國長期生態研究網的生態學家、生態資訊管理員與資訊技術學家經過多年的努力，已成功的發展出生態學資訊共通的標準語言EML(Ecological Metadata Language)，可以讓龐雜的生態資訊相互交換分享，延續生態資料的生命與提升其使用價值，藉由分享，擴大研究尺度，對於生態研究有更全面更深入的視野。台灣若要與世界接軌，生態資訊服務系統的建立是最為迫切的事。生態資訊服務系統的建立，可以整合台灣長期生態研究的各種資料，讓資料分享有運作良好的平台，提昇研究效率，不僅服務生態學家，更可以提供生態資訊給教育界及一般民眾有用可靠的生態資訊，擴展生態研究價值的層面。最為重要的是與國際的交流合作與共同研究將更為頻繁，在此同時台灣的經驗亦將領先亞太地區，成為此一新興領域的領導者。
Chau ChinLinTaiwan Forestry Research InstituteAssociate Scientist53 Nan-Hei Rd.Taipei100Taiwan02-23039978-2660chin@tfri.gov.tw

本年度重要工作項目及實施方法八、本年度重要工作項目及實施方法：1. 彙整國內農業長期生態研究資料與資訊，派兩名資訊管理員參訪KBS試驗站，學習其豐富的研究架構、試驗方法、長期農業生態資料庫之建置與分享機制，提升國內農業及生態資訊服務系統之技術與品質。2. 建構更完善的生態資訊服務系統，在此一新興資訊管理領域，持續加強國內生態資訊服務系統建置技術與管理人員之能力，並與世界生態資訊接軌，以提升國內生態研究地位的重要性。國際長期生態研究網與美國長期生態研究網，每年均會舉辦生態資訊管理員會議，除經驗的分享外，對於服務技術與品質的提升亦有相當的討論。因此，本計畫擬派兩名資訊管理員參加會議，與國際學者及其他資訊管理人員共同交流，提升國內生態資訊服務系統之技術與品質。3. 2007年將由韓國主辦第三次亞太地區生態資訊管理系統研習會，對象為亞太地區長期生態資訊網之會員國，台灣在過去兩次會議扮演主導角色，成功地協助培訓亞太各國建置生態資訊系統能力。預計派遣三名資訊管理員參與該會議，以了解亞太各國在此一領域的發展狀況，確保我國在此一領域領先的優勢。

IPCC Climate Change Data: 1961-1990, Temperature Difference

From the IPCC website: The CRU Global Climate Dataset available through the IPCC DDC consists of a multi-variate 0.01º latitude by 0.01º longitude resolution mean monthly climatology for global land areas, excluding Antarctica, strictly constrained to the period 1961-1990. The mean 1961-1990 climatology comprises a suite of eleven surface variables: precipitation (PRE) and wet-day frequency (WET); mean, maximum and minimum temperature (TMP, TMX, TMN); diurnal temperature range (DTR); vapour pressure (VAP;) global radiation (RAD;) cloud cover (CLD); frost frequency (FRS); and wind speed (WND). The mean climate surfaces have been constructed from a new dataset of station 1961-1990 climatological normals, numbering between 19,800 (precipitation) and 3615 (windspeed). The station data were interpolated as a function of latitude, longitude and elevation using thin-plate splines. The accuracy of the interpolations are assessed using cross-validation and by comparison with other climatologies. this data-set has been decsribed in: New,M., Hulme,M. and Jones,P.D. (1999) Representing twentieth century space-time climate variability. Part 1: development of a 1961-90 mean monthly terrestrial climatology J.Climate 12, 829-856.

Format (ASCII) The first and second lines of the file contain information on the grid size, for example: grd_sz xmin ymin xmax ymax n_cols n_rows n_months missing 0.01 120.0309121 21.8442559 122.0609121 25.5542559 371 203 12 -9999 This is followed by 12 monthly grids that are n_cols by n_rows in size. Each record contains n_cols (=371) columns longitude values, format 720i5, starting at xmin (= 120.0309121 deg) and ending at xmax (=122.0609121 deg) The first record starts at January, ymax (=25.5542559 deg) and the last record is the row for December, ymin (=21.8442559 deg). Co-ordinates represent the centre of each grid cell. Missing values (Antarctica, oceans and major inland water bodies) are assigned integer values of -9999. Units: degrees KProblems have come to light through user feedback and routine quality control in the Climatic Research Unit (during work towards the construction of an updated version of the 1961-1990 climatology). These problems range from systematic errors (for example, due to incorrect units being assumed for a whole country) to single-station errors. Errors at single stations have varying importance depending on the density of the surrounding network. Where the network is sparse, the station error will influence a larger area because of its greater spatial influence during the interpolation. Systematic errors arise because of varying reporting methods and units adopted by different national meteorological agencies (and other data contributors). The methods used to standardise data to a common format are discussed by New et al. (1999). Some problems are due to shortcomings in the standardisation methods used. In addition, misunderstandings (or a lack of information) about the units in which data were supplied means that the incorrect (or no) standardisation was used. The majority of problems/errors identified to date are due to confusion of units and shortcomings in the standardisation towards the use of common units. The climate variable with the largest potential for confusion is wind speed. Not only do reporting units vary between metres per second, miles per hour and knots; anemometer heights can vary greatly from the desired 10m (e.g. between 2m and 20m). The following (variable) gridded files are known to have either systematic or significant single station errors which potential users need to be aware of. The errors are present in the mean-monthly 1961-90 terrestrial climatology files and are thus propagated into the gridded 1901-1995 monthly time-series. The affected part of the globe is defined where possible. * Greenland: all variables The interior of Greenland is poorly covered by meteorological observation. This coupled with the presence of the high elevation ice cap makes interpolation of climate normals very difficult due to the potential for unusual lapse rates. It is likely that significant bias may be present with all variables for the interior of the landmass (e.g. diurnal temperature range and precipitation too high).

IPCC Climate Change Data: 1961-1990, Temperature Difference

Problems have come to light through user feedback and routine quality control in the Climatic Research Unit (during work towards the construction of an updated version of the 1961-1990 climatology). These problems range from systematic errors (for example, due to incorrect units being assumed for a whole country) to single-station errors. Errors at single stations have varying importance depending on the density of the surrounding network. Where the network is sparse, the station error will influence a larger area because of its greater spatial influence during the interpolation. Systematic errors arise because of varying reporting methods and units adopted by different national meteorological agencies (and other data contributors). The methods used to standardise data to a common format are discussed by New et al. (1999). Some problems are due to shortcomings in the standardisation methods used. In addition, misunderstandings (or a lack of information) about the units in which data were supplied means that the incorrect (or no) standardisation was used. The majority of problems/errors identified to date are due to confusion of units and shortcomings in the standardisation towards the use of common units. The climate variable with the largest potential for confusion is wind speed. Not only do reporting units vary between metres per second, miles per hour and knots; anemometer heights can vary greatly from the desired 10m (e.g. between 2m and 20m). The following (variable) gridded files are known to have either systematic or significant single station errors which potential users need to be aware of. The errors are present in the mean-monthly 1961-90 terrestrial climatology files and are thus propagated into the gridded 1901-1995 monthly time-series. The affected part of the globe is defined where possible. * Greenland: all variables The interior of Greenland is poorly covered by meteorological observation. This coupled with the presence of the high elevation ice cap makes interpolation of climate normals very difficult due to the potential for unusual lapse rates. It is likely that significant bias may be present with all variables for the interior of the landmass (e.g. diurnal temperature range and precipitation too high).
Fate, Transport, and Retention of Applied 15N Labelled Nitrogen in Forest Soils

Applied 15N labelled ammonium was retained longer in an acid soil with moder humus but was quickly nitrified and leached as nitrate in base rich soils with mull humus type of surface organic layer. Longer retention of applied ammonium in acid soils was associated with low nitrification (heterotrophic type) rate. However,the surface organic layer in moder humus adsorbed only a small amount of the applied ammonium whereas most was adsorbed in the mineral soil layers.Retention of ammonium by adsorption depended on soil temperature which was reduced at higher temperature by increasing nitrification, and was increased with decreasing temperature by lowering nitrification. This mechanism potentially delayed leaching losses of applied ammonium as nitrates in acid soils especially at low temperatures in the nongrowing season and probably increased the uptake of N by microbes and plants. Retention of 15N labelled ammonium in organic compounds (microbial biomass,soil organic matter) was high when microbial biomass was high. The dominant effect of microbial immobilisation, which was independent of soil layers and humus forms, suggested the importance of the fate of microbial detritus for the long-term retention of deposited ammonium in forest soils. Retention of 15N labelled nitrate in organic compounds was very low in the Solling soil in contrast to other studies with different application procedures of labelled nitrate.
Dr.Chiao-PingWangTaiwan Forestry Research InstituteAssociate ResearcherNan-Hai Re. 53TaipeiTaiwan+886-2-23374765cpwang@tfri.gov.tw

lab incubationFrom the Solling site, soil cores of the surface organic layer, 0–10 cm, and 10–20 cm soil depth were collected, and from the Go¨ttinger Wald site mineral soil layers were used (L–10 cm, 10–20 cm, and 20–30 cm soil depth). The L layer was included in the L–10 cm layer at Go¨ttinger Wald. The soil cores were installed in a microcosm system (Hantschel et al. 1994) and automatically irrigated six times per day (Solling: 4 mm per day; Go¨ttinger Wald: 6 mm per day) with an artificially prepared throughfall solution over a 4-month period.15N labelled nitrogen was applied at the rate of 20 kg N ha1 per year either as ammonium or nitrate but in three different steps. During the first 3 weeks, nitrogen was applied as non-labelled NH4NO3 (preliminary period) to achieve a steady state condition in the water flow and in the microbial transformation processes. For the next 60 days, 15N labelled NH4NO3 with either ammonium or nitrate (15Nex 49.4 atom%) were applied in separate experiments together with Cl to study the anion transport processes in the soil layers. In the third period, non-labelled NH4NO3 was applied to study the remobilisation of 15N from the soils over 4 weeks. Soil solutions were sampled from the bottom of the soil cores where a 0.45 mm nylon membrane (Hybond-N, Amersham, England) was placed, and analysed for ammonium and nitrate and the 15N content to calculate the leaching losses of labelled ammonium and nitrate.undisturbed soil cores (15 cm diameter) from different soil layers were used to study the vertical distribution of C- and N-transformations at different temperatures and for different form of N-applied: at 3–4C (Solling: n = 4 and Go¨ttinger Wald: n = 6), at 7–8C (Solling:15NH4 +, n = 8;15NO3, n = 4 and Go¨ttinger Wald: n = 3), and at 16C (Solling: n = 4 Go¨ttinger Wald: n = 9)

Fate, Transport, and Retention of Applied 15N Labelled Nitrogen in Forest Soils
六龜地區台灣杉人工林地位指數模式之建立

立地品等(site quality)之有效數量化是森林經營中至為重要之要務之一。由於林分之優勢樹高生長 是為林齡和地位之函數，因此要計算林分優勢樹高之前必須先對立地之品等進行評量。本研究使用單 形地位指數曲線(anamorphic site index curve)和多形地位指數曲線(polymorphic site index curve)兩種 方式，以樹幹解析資料，使用不同之模式進行六龜地區台灣杉人工林地位指數曲線之建立，並進行配 置模式間推估值正確性和精確性之比較。研究顯示在同時考慮正確性和精確性而言(mean square error, MSE)，所有模式中以Payandeh和Wang發表(1994)並經本研究調整後之模式，就所有觀測到各林齡之 台灣杉人工林言之，其進行地位指數推估之成效最高，驗證資料顯示其相對偏差小於3%。基準年無關 (base-age-invariant)之地位指數模式雖然具有模式配置不受到不同基準年影響之優點，但本研究發現和 基準年相依(base-age-specific)之地位指數模式相比，前者之推估能力較後者為差，尤其是對林齡小於 11年生之林分，其差異現象更為明顯。此外，地位指數之推估正確性會隨著推估地位指數時所有採用 之起初林齡(predictor age)呈現相當大之變化。一般而言，研究結果顯示在推估地位指數時使用之起初 林齡越接近基準年，則其推估會呈現更為精確之趨勢。

對立地之品等進行評量本研究使用單形地位指數曲線(anamorphic site index curve)和多形地位指數曲線(polymorphic site index curve)兩種方式。以樹幹解析資料，使用不同之模式進行六龜地區台灣杉人工林地位指數曲線之建立，並進行配 置模式間推估值正確性和精確性之比較。所有觀測到各林齡之其進行地位指數推估之成效最高，驗證資料顯示其相對偏差小於3%。基準年無關 (base-age-invariant)之地位指數模式雖然具有模式配置不受到不同基準年影響之優點，但本研究發現和 基準年相依(base-age-specific)之地位指數模式相比，前者之推估能力較後者為差，尤其是對林齡小於 11年生之林分，其差異現象更為明顯。

Intermediate Storage Behaviour and the Effect of Prechilling on Germination of Japanese Zelkova (Zelkova serrata) Seeds

The small seeds of Japanese Zelkova, Zelkova serrata, seem to be orthodox seeds, and have been treated as such by foresters. In this study, the responses of the seed viability of mature seeds to combined range of moisture contents (2%~18%, on a fresh-weight basis) and subsequent hermetic storage at -20 to 15 °C for 2 years were investigated. Among the three storage temperatures tested (15, 4, and –20 °C) the seeds remain viable for at least 24 months at 15 °C and a moisture content of between 2.1% and 10.5%. However, at 4 °C seeds only remain viable at a moisture content of between 5.8% and 10%. Seeds stored at –20 °C deteriorated the fastest, and fewer than their viability was just 60% at a moisture content of 10.5%. Japanese Zelkova seeds survived at low moisture content; however, the viability was lost more rapidly than seeds with higher moisture contents. These results confirm that the storage behaviour of Japanese Zelkova seeds is intermediate between typical orthodox and recalcitrant seeds, and is characterized as being tolerant of desiccation but sensitive to low and freezing temperatures.

controll of seed moisture contentTo obtain seeds at 5 MC levels between 2.1%~18.4% of Japanese Zelkova, clean seeds were divided into 5 sub-lots. Seeds of each sub-lot were desiccated at 2%~5% RHs in a hermetically sealed acrylic box containing a molecular sieve at 20 °C. A small fan was installed in the box to circulate the air. Immediately after the relative humidity treatment, each MC group was wrapped in an aluminium foil bag and stored at 5 °C for 3~5 d to allow the moisture to equilibrate within and among the seeds. The obtained MCs were 2.9%, 6.8%, 10.5%, 14.2% and 18.4%; and 2.1%, 5.8%, 9.8%, 13.8% and 17.5% for the 2 seedlots, respectively.storage treatmentThe seed moisture of each MC group was determined, and seed bags were stored at three temperatures (-20, 4, and 15 °C) for up to 24 months. A factorial design was used to study the responses of Japanese Zelkova seed survival to moisture content, temperature, and storage period. Thus, three temperatures (-20, 4, and 15 °C) were combined with 5 MCs (from 2.1% to 18.4%), and with storage periods of 0, 2, 4, 6, 9, 12, 18, and 24; and 0, 1, 3, 6, 9, 12,15, 18, 21, and 24 months for the 2 seedlots, respectively.

扇平園區情人橋舊址蛙類聲景錄音檔

本資料集所描述的是智慧生態計畫－生態及生物多樣性資訊基礎建設與應用計畫於本所六龜研究中心扇平園區的情人橋舊址所設置的固定式錄音設備，目的在於長期監測蛙類聲景變化。本觀測點為全天候24小時待命，每15分鐘錄音2分鐘。所有的錄音資料，均可於生態感測資料展示平台（http://iesn.tfri.gov.tw）上查閱，並以開放資料形式提供生態感測開放資料平台(http://iesn.tfri.gov.tw/forestDW/OpenData)作為資料來源之一。

資料收集方式 將現場聲音資料由外接式麥克風經由前期擴大訊號後，利用電腦內可定時排程錄音之軟體，將聲音檔案記錄於電腦硬碟內；聲音資料為每15分鐘錄製2分鐘，24小時持續錄製，並以16bit 44.1kHz之WAV格式錄製；扇平園區情人橋舊址經架設錄音設備後，定時以無線網路傳輸方式江錄音檔倉儲於六龜研究中心扇平工作站之儲存設備中，並定時以網路傳輸至台北總所生態感測資料倉儲系統內。 錄音觀測系統：Wildlife Acounstic SM2 + GPS模組 錄音麥克風Shure WL 183 艾訊 eBOX 630 戶外工業主機 Rolls MX54S Promix 麥克風混音座 飛瑞500VA(在線式)UPS不斷電裝置 防水機箱(雙層隔版及隔熱板) 光電轉換器

From the IPCC website: The CRU Global Climate Dataset available through the IPCC DDC consists of a multi-variate 0.01º latitude by 0.01º longitude resolution mean monthly climatology for global land areas, excluding Antarctica, strictly constrained to the period 1961-1990. The mean 1961-1990 climatology comprises a suite of eleven surface variables: precipitation (PRE) and wet-day frequency (WET); mean, maximum and minimum temperature (TMP, TMX, TMN); diurnal temperature range (DTR); vapour pressure (VAP;) global radiation (RAD;) cloud cover (CLD); frost frequency (FRS); and wind speed (WND). The mean climate surfaces have been constructed from a new dataset of station 1961-1990 climatological normals, numbering between 19,800 (precipitation) and 3615 (windspeed). The station data were interpolated as a function of latitude, longitude and elevation using thin-plate splines. The accuracy of the interpolations are assessed using cross-validation and by comparison with other climatologies. this data-set has been decsribed in: New,M., Hulme,M. and Jones,P.D. (1999) Representing twentieth century space-time climate variability. Part 1: development of a 1961-90 mean monthly terrestrial climatology J.Climate 12, 829-856.

Format (ASCII) The first and second lines of the file contain information on the grid size, for example: grd_sz xmin ymin xmax ymax n_cols n_rows n_months missing 0.01 120.0309121 21.8442559 122.0609121 25.5542559 371 203 12 -9999 This is followed by 12 monthly grids that are n_cols by n_rows in size. Each record contains n_cols (=371) columns longitude values, format 720i5, starting at xmin (= 120.0309121 deg) and ending at xmax (=122.0609121 deg) The first record starts at January, ymax (=25.5542559 deg) and the last record is the row for December, ymin (=21.8442559 deg). Co-ordinates represent the centre of each grid cell. Missing values (Antarctica, oceans and major inland water bodies) are assigned integer values of -9999. Units: degrees KProblems have come to light through user feedback and routine quality control in the Climatic Research Unit (during work towards the construction of an updated version of the 1961-1990 climatology). These problems range from systematic errors (for example, due to incorrect units being assumed for a whole country) to single-station errors. Errors at single stations have varying importance depending on the density of the surrounding network. Where the network is sparse, the station error will influence a larger area because of its greater spatial influence during the interpolation. Systematic errors arise because of varying reporting methods and units adopted by different national meteorological agencies (and other data contributors). The methods used to standardise data to a common format are discussed by New et al. (1999). Some problems are due to shortcomings in the standardisation methods used. In addition, misunderstandings (or a lack of information) about the units in which data were supplied means that the incorrect (or no) standardisation was used. The majority of problems/errors identified to date are due to confusion of units and shortcomings in the standardisation towards the use of common units. The climate variable with the largest potential for confusion is wind speed. Not only do reporting units vary between metres per second, miles per hour and knots; anemometer heights can vary greatly from the desired 10m (e.g. between 2m and 20m). The following (variable) gridded files are known to have either systematic or significant single station errors which potential users need to be aware of. The errors are present in the mean-monthly 1961-90 terrestrial climatology files and are thus propagated into the gridded 1901-1995 monthly time-series. The affected part of the globe is defined where possible. * Greenland all variables The interior of Greenland is poorly covered by meteorological observation. This coupled with the presence of the high elevation ice cap makes interpolation of climate normals very difficult due to the potential for unusual lapse rates. It is likely that significant bias may be present with all variables for the interior of the landmass (e.g. diurnal temperature range and precipitation too high).

造紙功能性奈米添加劑之開發研究(1/3)

造紙工藝近年有長足進步，新世紀科技發展中奈米材料的應用也受到高度關注，爰此 本計畫擬利用台灣可取得之各種礦質材料，包括皂土、高嶺土、碳酸鈣、蒙脫土、絹 雲母、滑石粉、二氧化鈦、膠態二氧化矽、膠態銀等之商用或自行製備奈米或次微米 材料對紙料或原紙依濕端添加、塗布、噴灑與含浸等方法施用，以期提升改善現有紙 種的性質或開創新機能性紙類。預期採用奈米材料可解決至少下列種項當前紙類常見 問題，例如輕量塗布紙的不透明度不足；回收漿料所抄紙之嵩度不足問題；以及中鹼 性AKD上膠紙箱摩擦力不足易滑動等缺陷並探討微細材料與紙上留存之機制與具光觸 媒與光氧化能力抗菌防霉紙類之開發。預期成果有利國內紙業技術之進步並增加國際 競爭力。

本年度重要工作項目及實施方法：1.各種奈米與次微米級礦質材料之收集或製備，除碳酸鈣、絹雲母、膨皂土、高嶺土等須透過沉澱分離、冷凍乾燥、機械研磨等方法開發試材，其餘多可透過商業管道取得。2.進行以濕端添加為主的試驗，利用微粒子雙留存甚或三留存系統，探討不同電荷性質聚電解質與礦質材料的交互作用，達到微粒子高度留存於紙匹之目標。3.建立最適之材料與添加條件，利用膨皂土、絹雲母、蒙脫土等膨潤性次微米材料與澱粉添加劑為紙之系列，進行回收舊牛皮漿抄紙之嵩度控制試驗，建立不損傷結合強度下裱面紙板厚度增加之目標條件。4.進行預塗布試驗，探討不同顏料製備塗料之特性與覆蓋性質，作為後續奈米材料塗布試驗的基準。

A Five-year Trade Dependence Analysis of Forest Products Between Taiwan and China

In 2003, Mainland China occupied 15.73% of the total importation value of forest products in Taiwan, and became the 3rd largest source of imported forest products (IFP). Since 1990, the growth rates of IFP values from mainland China are increasing, and higher than that from the global market. It indicated the trend dependence is increasing. The growth rate of IFP values from mainland China has increased to 9.56% in 2003. Four major categories, which dominated the 93.19% of the IFP market share from mainland China, are ordered by the market share as following: wooden & rattan furniture (39.53%), veneer & plywood (20.82%), pulp (17.18%), and wooden & rattan products (15.66%). The trend of that market has shifted from raw materials to semi-products or finished products. Although the trend of trade dependence in imported forest products between Taiwan and mainland China is increasing in current few years, the value of trade dependence decreased sharply since 1998. The structural dependence explained the increasing of trade dependence between Taiwan and Mainland China before 1997, and no obvious reason was recognized the trade dependence increasing during 1998-2003. The research indicated the trend of trade dependence between Taiwan and mainland China has shifted from structural dependence to relative interest dependence.

A New Species, Alpinia nantoensis (Zingiberaceae), from Taiwan

A new species of Alpinia, A. nantoensis F. Y. Lu & Y. W. Kuo, from Taiwan is presented in this paper. This species is found in mountainous areas of central Taiwan, at around 900~1500 m in elevation. This new species can be distinguished from A. pricei by the tubular and persistent conformation of the bracteole and the rhombic labellum. But the lack of a bracteole in A. pricei is the greatest difference. It is also similar to A. shimadai var. shimada, but A. nantoensis has a tubular unlobed, bracteole, and A. shimadai var. shimadai has a shelly bracteole, which is lobed on 1 side. Key words: Alpinia nantoensis, Alpinia, Zingiberaceae.

ææèæ¹æ³Alpinia, of the tribe Alpinieae in thefamily Zingiberaceae and containing about230 species around the world, is mainly distributedin Indonesia, Malaysia, and mainlandSouth and East India (Smith 1990). Plantsin this genus can mainly be distinguished bythe characters of the inflorescence, bracts,bracteoles, calyx, and labellum (Hussin et al.2000). The results of DNA sequence-basedmethods (Kress et al. 2005) showed that thegenus Alpinia is a polyphyletic group. It isrepresented by 6 polyphyletic clades containingspecies of Alpinia distributed across thetribe Alpinieae. Unfortunately, those resultsdo not entirely correspond to Smithâs (1990)classification of the genus. In the earliest classificationliterature, A list of plants from Formosawritten by Henry (1896), 5 species ofAlpinia were recorded. Hayata (1915, 1916,1920) recorded 24 species of Alpinia, 19 ofwhich were proposed as new species. Later,some investigations and studies were carriedout on this genus, and a lot of problems stillremain (Masamune 1936, Moo 1973, 1978,Yang 1993, Yang and Wang 1998). A revisionof the taxonomy of Alpinia was carried out inthe past 4 yrs (Kuo 2006), and in this paper,a new species, A. nantoensis, from Taiwan isdescribed.Alpinia nantoensis F. Y. Lu & Y. W. Kuo sp.nov. åæææ¡ Figs. 1, 2Caulis 1~1.5 m altis. Folia oblonga vellanceolata, 25~30 cm longa, 3~6 cm lata, apiceacuminata, basi cuneata, utrinque paginaglabra, margine villosa, subtus praeter costassparse villosas, ligula oblonga, ca 0.3 cm longa,integra vel bilota, extus hirsuta, petioles0.5~1.5 cm longis. Spica recta erecta, rachis5~10 cm longa, bracteae sub rachis ellipticaecaducosae, bracteola subflore cylindrica1.5~2.3 cm longa, extus sparse hirsuta, margineciliata. Calyx rubellus, cylindricus, ca 1.8cm longus, leviter 2-lobatus. Corollae albae,tubus ca 0.6 cm longus, lobis 3, lobo posticoca 2.5 cm longo, 1.2 cm lato, lobis lateralibusangustioribus, apice ciliatibus. Labellumalbum, ellipticum, vel rotundatum, 2.3~2.5cm longum, 2~2.3 cm latum, medio rubrostriatum,apice integrum vel crenulatum. Stamen1, filamento ca 1.8 cm longo, anthera ca1.3 cm longa. Staminoidia obsoleta. Ovariumviridulum, albo-villosum, ca 0.5 cm longum,0.4 cm latum. Stylus filiformis, ca 3.5 cmlongus, apice infundibuliformis, sparse hirsutus,glandulae connatae, globosae. Capsularubra, globosa, 1~1.5 cm longa, 1.2~1.4 cmlata, 15~17 costulata, sparse villosa. Semina20~30, nigro-castanea, polygona, arillis membranaceisalbicantibus.Plant ca 1~1.5 m high. Leaves oblongto lanceolate, blade 25~30 by 3~6 cm, apexacuminate, base cuneate, glabrous on bothsides except for margin and midrib below;ligule oblong, ca 0.3 cm long, entire or bilobed,hairy on outer surface; petiole 0.5~1.5cm long. Inflorescence spicate, erect, rachisvillose, pale white, 5~10 cm long; bract deciduous,oblong; bracteoles tubular, 1.5~2.3cm long, sparsely pubescent, margin ciliate;calyx pale red, tubular, ca 1.8 cm long, short2-lobed; corolla white, tube ca 0.6 cm long,dorsal lobe 2.5Ã1.2 cm, laterals oblong, 2.5Ã1 cm, margin ciliate; labellum white, ovate,2.3~2.5Ã2~2.3 cm, with red stripes and spotsin center, apex emarginate, margin crispate;stamens 1, filament ca 1.8 cm long, anther ca1.3 cm long; staminodes minute; ovary greenish,villose, villi white, 0.5Ã0.4 cm, stylesca 3.5 cm long, apex funnel-shaped, sparselyhairy, epigynous glands united on 1 side, columnar.Fruit capsular, red, globose, 1~1.5Ã1.2~1.4 cm, 15~17 costellate, sparsely hairy;seeds 20~30, blackish-brown, angled; arilwhite, membranous.

Hydrological Characteristics of a Makino Bamboo Woodland

Hydrological characteristics of litterfall, interception, infiltration, evapotranspiration, and subsurface runoff of a makino bamboo (Phyllostachys makinoi Hayata) woodland, a special forest type found mainly on mid-elevation slopelands from the central to the northern part of Taiwan, in the Lienhuachih Research Center of Taiwan Forestry Research Institute were investigated during the period 1999 to 2004 and compared with those of natural hardwood forests and other major vegetation cover types in Taiwan. Results of the investigation indicated that the peak of litterfall for the makino bamboo woodland was from April to May.

MP100ARatnfall collect Instrument by Tipping bucket raingaugeSolar Radiation Pyranometer Type CM3Litterfall measurementTwenty 100 × 100-cm traps distributed randomly in the makino woodland were installed at 1 m above the ground for collecting litterfall. Litter including leaves, twigs and shoot-sheathes was collected monthly, and oven-dried to a constant weight and then weighed, monthly collected.The collection period was from June 1999 to May 2003. In addition, depths of litter were also randomly measured (as for possible as with no compression) each October of the study period.Subsurface flow measurementFour plastic 15 × 250-cm gutters were installed in a soil pit at the depth of 0, 10, 30 and 60 cm in the makino bamboo-covered slopeland (with an average slope of 59%), Other broadleaf trees site are beneath, for collecting subsurface runoff. The gutters were packed with soil and sealed at the front by wooden shuttering to ensure good contact between the gutters and the soil. Water collected in each gutter was routed into a tipping bucket rain gauge and recorded as subsurface flow.tipping bucket rain gauge

Effects of alkyl chain length of gallates on their antifungal property and potency as an environmentally-benign preservative against wood decay fungi

This study investigated effects of alkyl chain length of eight aliphatic gallates from C1 to C18 on their antifungal activity and free radical scavenging activity, which are two important indicators in developing wood preservatives. Results from the agar plate test showed that the antifungal activity against wood rot fungi of gallates was related to alkyl chain length. It increased with increasing alkyl chain length, reaching to a maximum at octyl gallate (C8), and then decreased as chain length increased. Octyl gallate also exhibited potential antifungal activity against soft rot Chaetomium globosum and copper-tolerant fungi Wolfiporia extensa and Poria placenta, which are difficult to combat with current copper-based wood preservatives. Octyl gallate is a potent antifungal agent with excellent antifungal activity over a broad antifungal spectrum. All of the gallates tested, regardless of their alkyl chain length, showed strong scavenging activity on the DPPH radical with EC50 values around 1~5 μg ml-1, indicating that the alkyl chain length was not directly related to this activity. Results from the soil block test showed that excellent antioxidants like propyl gallate (C3) and octyl gallate impart wood with good resistance against wood decay fungi. This suggests that antioxidants have potential as environmentally-benign wood preservatives.

Free radical scavenging activityThe scavenging activity of DPPH free radical was determined using the method reported by Gyamfi et al. (1999) and Chang et al. (2001). Gallates dissolved in ethanol (50 μl) were mixed with 1000 μl of 0.1 mM DPPH-ethanol solution and 450 μl of 50 mM Tris-HCl buffer (pH 7.4). Pure ethanol (50 μl) was used as the control for this experiment. After 30 min of incubation at ambient temperature, the reduction of the DPPH free radical was measured by reading the absorbance at 517 nm. Catechin was used as positive control. The percentage of inhibition was calculated using the following equation:% Inhibition = [(absorbance of control - absorbance of test sample)/absorbance of control] × 100Soil block testTo evaluate the efficiency of gallates against wood decay fungi in the presence of wood, soil block test was carried out in accordance with the ASTM test method D1413-05b (American Society for Testing and Materials, 2006). Sapwood portion of kiln-dried, defect-free Cryptomeria japonica and Liquidambar formosana lumber were cut into 19 × 19 × 19 mm3 blocks. Liquidambar formosana blocks were used in decay testing with the white-rot fungus (T. versicolor) while Cryptomeria japonica blocks were used in decay testing with the brown-rot fungus (G. trabeum). Wood blocks were impregnated with 5% propyl gallate or octyl gallate in desiccators with the vacuum/soak method. The amount of preservative absorbed by the block, the retention, as kilograms per cubic meter (Kg m-3) of wood as follows:Retention (Kg m-3) = (GC/V) × 10

Characteristics of particleboard made from recycled wood-waste chips impregnated with phenol formaldehyde resin

The main purpose of this study was to manufacture water-resistant particleboard for use in kitchens and bathrooms, and as flooringbased material and in outdoor environments. The chips were from recycled wood wastes of different wood species. The chips were divided into coarse chips with dimensions of 5–8 mesh and fine chips of 8–20 mesh, then, these chips were immersed in water-soluble phenol formaldehyde (PF) resin solution at concentrations of 4.5%, 6.5% and 10%. After 5 min, they were removed from the PF solution and dried in an oven until in a half-hardened condition. Three-layer mats with target densities of 0.70 and 0.80 g/cm3 were formed by using fine chips for the face layer (25%) and back layer (25%) and coarse chips for the core layer (50%). A conventional hot press was used for fabrication of the particleboard, and the temperature, pressure and pressing time were 453 K, 2.9 MPa, and 5 min, respectively. The nominal dimensions of particleboard were 50050012mm (thick). Result showed that the PF resin absorption content of chips (RC) increased linearly with an increase in the concentration of PF solution. Their relationship could be represented by the linear regression formula. The bending strength, internal bonding strength, and thickness swelling (%) of the PF-impregnated particleboards exhibited excellent performances compared to those made in the past, and the retention rate (%) of the modulus of rupture (MOR) and modulus of elasticity (MOE) of PF-impregnated particleboard after treatment in hot water (343 K) for 2 h were maintained at 48.7–84.5% and 49.2–82.7%, respectively. Characteristics of the ultrasonic velocity in the mechanical direction were similar to those in the vertical direction. In addition, there were significant relationships between the ultrasonic velocity and the mechanical properties of the particleboard, and this meant that we could evaluate the properties of the particleboard using ultrasonic velocity.

materialChips from mixed hardwood species including oak (Quercus spp.) and lauan (Shorea spp.) were preparedfrom recycled new construction and demolition wastes which were gathered and then classified by Jen-ChunEnterprise in Feng-Yuan, Taiwan. The adhesive used was a water-soluble PF resin (76–78% solid content and pH 8–9 produced by Tai-Lin Resin, Co., Taipei, Taiwan).Production process of chipsChips were divided into four grades using 5, 8, and 20 meshes, and were divided into coarse chips which passedthrough 5 mesh stop on 8 mesh and fine chips with through 8 mesh stop on 20 mesh. The chips were oven-dried to2–4% moisture content (MC), at a temperature of 33872K. Then, they were immersed in a water-solublePF resin.The PF resin absorption content can be expressed as RC ð%Þ ¼ W2 W1W1 100, (1)where RC is the PF absorption content, W1 is the ovendried weight of the chips before impregnation, and W2 isthe oven-dried weight of chips after impregnation.Next, the chips were dried in an oven until in a halfhardened condition, and then were placed into a frame of5050 cm. The particleboard was formed using fine chips for the face layer (25%) and back layer (25%) and coarsechips for the core layer (50%). A conventional hot press was used for fabrication of the particleboard and thetemperature, pressure and pressing time were 453 K, 2.9MPa and 5 min, respectively. The nominal dimensionsof particleboard were 50050012mm (thick), with three layers. The thickness of particleboard was controlled bystop bars. Two kinds of target densities of particleboard (D1 group was 0.8 g/cm3, and D2 group was 0.7 g/cm3)were fabricated in this study.Testing methodThe particleboards produced for this study, were tested under the American Society Testing and Materials(ASTM) method standard D-1037 [9], in conducting various tests.2.3.1. Ultrasonic wave testPrior to testing, PF-impregnated particleboards were conditioned at 293K and 65% relative humidity, and thefull panels of each particleboard were prepared for the ultrasonic wave tests. The test points of two correspondingsides of a particleboard were considered the investigated points and at intervals of 50 mm, an ultrasonic waveinstrument (Pundit, 54 kHz, C.N.S. Electronic Ltd.) which sends an ultrasonic pulse through the specimen was used tomeasure the time required for the transmission of the pulse through the specimen. The ultrasonic velocity was thencalculated from the length of the specimen divided by the propagation time.After the ultrasonic investigation, the full piece of tested particleboard was cut into static bending specimens andinternal bond (IB) strength specimens following ASTM D-1037 [9], and their positions relative to the full piece ofparticleboard were recorded. These static bending specimens were first used to conduct an ultrasonic wave test toobtain the ultrasonic velocity (Vl) through the face direction using a Pundit ultrasonic apparatus at afrequency of 54 kHz. However, transit times of the ultrasonic pulse for IB specimens were measured at afrequency of 500kHz in the thick direction to the surface of each specimen by the Pundit ultrasonic apparatus. Thevelocity was then calculated by dividing the length. The waves traveled by the transit time. The ultrasonic velocityand dynamic modulus of elasticity (DMOE) were calculated by the following formulae:VlðVtÞ ðm=sÞ ¼Lt, (2)DMOE ðMPaÞ ¼ Vl2 r, (3)where Vl is the ultrasonic velocity in the face direction of particleboard, Vt is the ultrasonic velocity in thickdirection of particleboard, L is the length, t is the transit time, DMOE is the dynamic modulus of elasticity, r is thedensity.2.3.2. Density and moisture contentFabricated particleboards, placed under room humidity for 1 week, were tested for their density and MC, whichused the following formulae: Air-dried density ðg=cm3Þ ¼WaVa, (4)Moisture content ð%Þ ¼Wa W0W0 100, (5)whereWa is the air-dried weight, Va is the air-dried volume, and W0 is the oven-dried weight of the particleboard.2.3.3. Static bending testAfter the ultrasonic wave test for obtaining the ultrasonic velocity, the conditioned samples, 7.6220.32 cm(38 in), two from each of two panels, were tested for the modulus of rupture (MOR) and modulus of elasticity(MOE) per ASTM standard D-1037-96 [9]. The MC, nominal thickness, and density were determined for thesespecimens.The MOR and MOE of each specimen are represented by the following formulae:MOR ðMPaÞ ¼3PbL2bh2 , (6)MOE ðMPaÞ ¼PbpL34bh3Yp, (7)where MOR is static bending strength (MPa), MOE is static bending modulus of elasticity (MPa), Pb is maximumload (N), Pbp is the load at the proportional limit (N), Yp is the deflection corresponding to Pbp (mm), b is the width ofthe specimen (mm), h is the thickness of the specimen (mm), and L is the span (mm).2.3.4. Internal bond strengthThe tensile strength perpendicular to the surface was determined using nine square conditioned specimens of5.085.08 cm (22 in) from each panel according to ASTM standard D-1037-96 [9]. The rupture load (Ps) wasdetermined and IB strength was calculated from the following formula:IB ðMPaÞ ¼Psbl, (8)where IB is the internal bond strength, Ps is the rupture load, and l is the length of the specimen. However, theultrasonic velocity of IB specimens was detected as described above before the IB test.2.3.5. Thickness swellingConditioned samples, 15.2415.24 cm (66 in) for the evaluation of TS were prepared according to ASTMstandard D-1037-96 [9]. The thickness at the middle of the test specimen was measured with a micrometer. Then,the test specimens were placed parallel into the water for 30mm and soaked for 2 and 24 h for measurement of thethickness. The TS rate was determined from the following formula:TS2 ð%Þ ¼t2 t0t0 100, (9)TS24 ð%Þ ¼t24 t0t0 100, (10)where TS is the thickness swelling rate, t0 is thickness at the middle of the test specimen before soaking in the water,and t2 and t24 are the thicknesses in the middle of the test specimen after soaking into water for 2 and 24 h,respectively.2.3.6. Accelerated degradation testsSpecimens were soaked in hot water (343 K) for 2 h and then soaked in cold water (at room temperature) for 1 h forcooling. The static bending tests were conducted on specimens while they were in a wet condition. The MORand MOE retention rates were evaluated from the following formula:MOR retention rate ð%Þ ¼MOR2MOR1 100, (11)MOR retention rate ð%Þ ¼MOE2MOE1 100, (12)where MOR1, MOE1, MOR2 and MOE2 represent the MOR and MOE values in an air-dried condition and aftersoaking in hot water (343 K) for 2 h, respectively.

materialChips from mixed hardwood species including oak (Quercus spp.) and lauan (Shorea spp.) were preparedfrom recycled new construction and demolition wastes which were gathered and then classified by Jen-ChunEnterprise in Feng-Yuan, Taiwan. The adhesive used was a water-soluble PF resin (76–78% solid content and pH 8–9 produced by Tai-Lin Resin, Co., Taipei, Taiwan).Production process of chipsChips were divided into four grades using 5, 8, and 20 meshes, and were divided into coarse chips which passedthrough 5 mesh stop on 8 mesh and fine chips with through 8 mesh stop on 20 mesh. The chips were oven-dried to2–4% moisture content (MC), at a temperature of 33872K. Then, they were immersed in a water-solublePF resin.The PF resin absorption content can be expressed as RC ð%Þ ¼ W2 W1W1 100, (1)where RC is the PF absorption content, W1 is the ovendried weight of the chips before impregnation, and W2 isthe oven-dried weight of chips after impregnation.Next, the chips were dried in an oven until in a halfhardened condition, and then were placed into a frame of5050 cm. The particleboard was formed using fine chips for the face layer (25%) and back layer (25%) and coarsechips for the core layer (50%). A conventional hot press was used for fabrication of the particleboard and thetemperature, pressure and pressing time were 453 K, 2.9MPa and 5 min, respectively. The nominal dimensionsof particleboard were 50050012mm (thick), with three layers. The thickness of particleboard was controlled bystop bars. Two kinds of target densities of particleboard (D1 group was 0.8 g/cm3, and D2 group was 0.7 g/cm3)were fabricated in this study.Testing methodThe particleboards produced for this study, were tested under the American Society Testing and Materials(ASTM) method standard D-1037 [9], in conducting various tests.2.3.1. Ultrasonic wave testPrior to testing, PF-impregnated particleboards were conditioned at 293K and 65% relative humidity, and thefull panels of each particleboard were prepared for the ultrasonic wave tests. The test points of two correspondingsides of a particleboard were considered the investigated points and at intervals of 50 mm, an ultrasonic waveinstrument (Pundit, 54 kHz, C.N.S. Electronic Ltd.) which sends an ultrasonic pulse through the specimen was used tomeasure the time required for the transmission of the pulse through the specimen. The ultrasonic velocity was thencalculated from the length of the specimen divided by the propagation time.After the ultrasonic investigation, the full piece of tested particleboard was cut into static bending specimens andinternal bond (IB) strength specimens following ASTM D-1037 [9], and their positions relative to the full piece ofparticleboard were recorded. These static bending specimens were first used to conduct an ultrasonic wave test toobtain the ultrasonic velocity (Vl) through the face direction using a Pundit ultrasonic apparatus at afrequency of 54 kHz. However, transit times of the ultrasonic pulse for IB specimens were measured at afrequency of 500kHz in the thick direction to the surface of each specimen by the Pundit ultrasonic apparatus. Thevelocity was then calculated by dividing the length. The waves traveled by the transit time. The ultrasonic velocityand dynamic modulus of elasticity (DMOE) were calculated by the following formulae:VlðVtÞ ðm=sÞ ¼Lt, (2)DMOE ðMPaÞ ¼ Vl2 r, (3)where Vl is the ultrasonic velocity in the face direction of particleboard, Vt is the ultrasonic velocity in thickdirection of particleboard, L is the length, t is the transit time, DMOE is the dynamic modulus of elasticity, r is thedensity.2.3.2. Density and moisture contentFabricated particleboards, placed under room humidity for 1 week, were tested for their density and MC, whichused the following formulae: Air-dried density ðg=cm3Þ ¼WaVa, (4)Moisture content ð%Þ ¼Wa W0W0 100, (5)whereWa is the air-dried weight, Va is the air-dried volume, and W0 is the oven-dried weight of the particleboard.2.3.3. Internal bond strengthThe tensile strength perpendicular to the surface was determined using nine square conditioned specimens of5.085.08 cm (22 in) from each panel according to ASTM standard D-1037-96 [9]. The rupture load (Ps) wasdetermined and IB strength was calculated from the following formula:IB ðMPaÞ ¼Psbl, (8)where IB is the internal bond strength, Ps is the rupture load, and l is the length of the specimen. However, theultrasonic velocity of IB specimens was detected as described above before the IB test.2.3.5. Thickness swellingConditioned samples, 15.2415.24 cm (66 in) for the evaluation of TS were prepared according to ASTMstandard D-1037-96 [9]. The thickness at the middle of the test specimen was measured with a micrometer. Then,the test specimens were placed parallel into the water for 30mm and soaked for 2 and 24 h for measurement of thethickness. The TS rate was determined from the following formula:TS2 ð%Þ ¼t2 t0t0 100, (9)TS24 ð%Þ ¼t24 t0t0 100, (10)where TS is the thickness swelling rate, t0 is thickness at the middle of the test specimen before soaking in the water,and t2 and t24 are the thicknesses in the middle of the test specimen after soaking into water for 2 and 24 h,respectively.2.3.6. Accelerated degradation testsSpecimens were soaked in hot water (343 K) for 2 h and then soaked in cold water (at room temperature) for 1 h forcooling. The static bending tests were conducted on specimens while they were in a wet condition. The MORand MOE retention rates were evaluated from the following formula:MOR retention rate ð%Þ ¼MOR2MOR1 100, (11)MOR retention rate ð%Þ ¼MOE2MOE1 100, (12)where MOR1, MOE1, MOR2 and MOE2 represent the MOR and MOE values in an air-dried condition and aftersoaking in hot water (343 K) for 2 h, respectively.

Composition and bioactivities of the leaf essential oils of Cinnamomum subavenium Miq. from Taiwan

Leaves of Cinnamomum subavenium Miq. were collected from 2 sites in Taiwan. Leaf essential oils of C. subavenium were isolated using hydrodistillation and headspace-GC methods to determine their composition and yield. Antioxidant and antimicrobial activities of various oils obtained were also evaluated. Forty-four and 88 compounds were identified in the leaf oils obtained. Whereas 26 and 65 compounds were identified by headspace-GC method, respectively. The main headspace components were comparable to those of the oil. The main components of one of the oils were methyl eugenol (75.9%), linalool (7.3%), and eugenol (6.6%); while those from the other oil were p-cymene (21.6%), 1,8-cineole (16.5%), and linalool (11.9%). Both leaf oils had excellent antioxidant and antimicrobial activities.
Division of Wood Cellulose, Taiwan Forestry Research Institute.
Chen-Lung HoDivision of Wood Cellulose, Taiwan Forestry Research Institute.Assistant Researchchenlung@tfri.gov.tw
