Crown Gall Culture and Camptothecin Production in Camptotheca acuminata

Crown gall cultures of of Camptotheca acuminata were established by infected in vitro leaf explants with Agrobacterium tumefaciens strain A 208. The greatest transformation frequency - 55.2% was obtained when explants co-cultured with the medium containing 1 x 108~9 bacterial cells mL-1 and 200 M acetosyringone for 2 days. At least one crown gall was induced from a explant, in some case 15 galls more per explant were occurred. Integration of T-DNA into host genome was proven using southern blotting as probed by nops gene. Transformed galls grew rapidly in hormone free MS medium. Their fresh weight increased up to 4.3~6.4 times on solid medium after 30 day in culture, while up to 7~8 times in liquid medium after 20 days in culture. The contents of camptothecin (CPT) of 10 gall strains were analyzed by HPLC. The greatest CPT % in dry weight of cells was 0.0385%, while the poorest was near 0%, indicating the variation of CPT production in transformed galls was very great, and extensive selection of gall lines is necessary.

一、試驗材料2004年採集生長於台北植物園的喜樹(1949引自中國，樹齡估計約50年以上) 種子，以微體扦插方式繼續培育成苗。取上述培養1年的試管苗之葉片作為試驗材料。二、農桿腫瘤菌的培養將野生型農桿腫瘤菌A208 以YEB培養基(Van Larebeke et al. 1977)，在200 rpm轉速之旋轉式震盪器，於28℃、黑暗中過夜培養(約16小時)。三、接種與殺菌喜樹葉片切成0.5 x 0.5 cm2大小，以不同菌數之菌液浸泡5分鐘後，將葉片與農桿腫瘤菌，共同培養(接種)於添加3 %蔗糖的MS固體培養基1~4天，去除農桿腫瘤菌。接著以0.5 g L-1 timetin殺菌劑浸泡1 hr後，將葉片培養於含有1~400 mgL-1timetin的MS液體培養基，以100rpm轉速之震盪器培養1週後，移入相同培養基組成但添加洋菜粉的MS固體中再培養3週，以殺死農桿腫瘤菌。殺菌的4週中，每週均需更換新鮮配製的培養基。四、腫瘤細胞培養殺菌後，將葉片移入不含殺菌劑與植物賀爾蒙之MS固體培養基中培養，每個月繼代培養一次。在培養1.5個月時，調查與記錄腫瘤的形成率。五、DNA萃取、聚合酶連鎖反應(polymerse china reaction, 簡稱 PCR)與南方墨點分析(southern blot analysis)喜樹葉片與轉殖農桿腫瘤菌基因之腫瘤細胞，以聚合酶連鎖反應(polymerse china reaction, 簡稱 PCR)與南方墨點分析(southern blot analysis)六、喜樹鹼分析以高效能液相層析儀(HPLC, Series 600 controller pump, 717 plus autosampler, Waters, Milford, MA, USA)，經光電二極體偵測器(2996 Photodiode Array Detector, Waters)分析CPT含量。

Natural resource management and traditional ecological knowledge of aborigine Paiwan恆春半島排灣族原住民傳統知識及自然資源使用方式

Aborigine Paiwan of southern Taiwan have been survived long with the natural environment surrounding them, and accumulated a lot of traditional ecological knowledge through natural resource management. However, the valuable knowledge lost soon, and now only be conserved in few old men and women. The purpose of this study are to investigate how aborigine Paiwan managed the natural resource, and discuss if their traditional ecological knowledge could be used well for natural resource management and conservation now. We completed the map of Kuskus traditional area, and 150 traditional site names concerning the agricultural land, hunting area, residential sites, sacred areas, and so on were recorded. Basing on the interviewing and site visiting with the old men of Kuskus, some of the traditional ways of natural resource management were also recorded. The ecological meanings of traditional natural resource management by Kuskus people will be discussed in this research program.

林木純露生物活性與市場接受度分析 (3/3), The bioactivity and market acceptance of aromatic hydrosols from trees(3/3)

本年度針對檜木葉純露進行性質分析，測定各項生物活性，並針對不同環境進行保存性的探討，消除直接塗抹皮膚或飲用純露的疑慮，並分析潛在消費者對純露之顏色、氣味、味道等不同知覺感受，以消費端做為產品開發依據，副產物的開發利用可提高精油工業的產值與市場，提高林農造林的意願。This study is intended as a investigation of the hydrosols of cypress tree(Chamaecyparis obtusa var. formosana, Chamaecyparis formosensis ) in Taiwan. The hydrosols commonly are used to lotion and drink. For avoidance of doubt, we will determine the biological activity and the preservation exploring in different environments. To analysis of market acceptance, potential consumers experience through color, smell, taste by using hydrosols of cypress tree, as the basis for product development. The development and utilization of by-products Increase the added value of essential oil and enhances the motivation of planting.

測定純露pH值、導電度及表面張力 取試樣10 mL在室溫下以酸鹼度計( Oakton pH/Ion 510)測定之，重複三次取平均值。取試樣10 mL在室溫下以導電度測定儀測定之，重複三次取平均值。利用接觸角測定儀，以懸滴法測定液體的表面張力(Interfacial tension, IFT)，選用外徑0.9 mm針頭。 Oakton pH/Ion 510, Aqualytic CD22, Sindatek model 100SB 固態培養測定純露抗真菌活性 棒狀黴菌(Aspergillus clavatus)、黑黴菌(Aspergillus niger)、球毛殼菌(Chaetomium globosum)、芽枝狀枝孢菌(Cladosporium cladosporioides)、孢漆菌(Myrothecium verrucaria)、橘青黴(Penicillum citrinum)、綠色木黴(Trichoderma viride)等7種菌株以固態培養方式進行試驗，以稀釋成一定濃度的純露做為實驗組，對照組則使用水，依據菌株適合的培養基，調製成馬鈴薯葡萄糖瓊脂(Potato dextrose agar, PDA)、麥芽抽出瓊脂(Malt extract agar, MEA)、玉米粉瓊脂(Cornmeal agar, CMA)等不同培養基，接種試菌於適當培養基之培養皿中，置入適合溫度的培養箱，每週記錄菌絲的生長直徑，待對照組的菌絲長滿培養皿後，測量實驗組之菌絲生長直徑並計算抗菌指數(Antifungal index, %)，抗菌指數的公式如下：抗菌指數(%)= (1-實驗組菌絲生長直徑／對照組菌絲生長直徑) ×100 液態培養測定純露抗真菌活性 白色念珠菌(Candida albicans)以液態培養方式進行試驗，以稀釋成一定濃度的純露做為實驗組，對照組則使用水，調製酵母麥芽肉湯(Yeast malt broth, YM broth)，接種試菌後置入25℃的培養箱，培養一星期後，以0.2 µm的濾膜過濾，凍乾後稱重並計算抗菌指數，抗菌指數的公式如下：抗菌指數(%)= (1-實驗組菌絲乾重／對照組菌絲乾重) ×100 Labconco FreeZone Plus freeze dry systems 測定純露抗細菌活性 大腸桿菌(Escherichia coli)、綠膿桿菌(Psedomonas aeruginosa)、金黃色葡萄球菌(Staphylococcus aureus)、變形鏈球菌(Streptococcus mutans)、遠緣鏈球菌(Streptococcus sobrinus)等5種細菌，先將菌液濃度調配稀釋為1×106 CFU/mL，取1 mL稀釋菌液加入1mL含有不同濃度純露的水解酪蛋白腖肉湯(Mueller Hilton broth, MH broth)混合均勻（菌液的最終濃度為5×105 CFU/mL），放入適當溫度生長箱靜置16-18小時，再取培養液稀釋後塗盤計數(planting count)，再根據稀釋的倍數計算菌數。 1.紅檜葉，樹齡:50年，台大實驗林高岳營林區，29林班經79之2號造林地，海拔: 2500 m。 2.台灣扁柏葉，台大實驗林內茅埔營林區，21林班62-1A造林地，海拔: 1908 m。 3.日本扁柏葉，樹齡:30年，台大實驗林高岳營林區，29林班經79之2號造林地，海拔: 2500 m。 ' 取枝葉進行水蒸氣蒸餾後得到純露

Germination, storage behaviour and cryopreservation of seeds of Champereia manillana (Opiliaceae) and Schefflera octophylla (Araliaceae) --Seeds storage behaviour

Germination, storage behaviour and cryoperservation were tested for seeds of Champereia manillana and Schefflera octophylla. Freshly harvested, mature seeds of both species germinated; 90% after 3 weeks incubation at 30/20C. Seeds of C. manillana survived desiccation to 5.6% moisture content (MC) (fresh weight basis) during storage at 4oC for 6 months without loss of viability, which thereafter decreased gradually. However, viability of seeds with a MC â¥ 5.6% decreased more rapidly during storage at 15C than at 4C. Survival of seeds stored at -20C was lower than that of seeds stored either at 4 or 15oC. Nevertheless, maximum viability of Champereia seeds with a MC of 5.6% was maintained in liquid nitrogen (-196C). Thus, C. manillana exhibited intermediate seed storage behaviour. Seeds of S. octophylla survived desiccation to 6~7% and -20C storage for 24 months without loss of viability. Seeds of this species with a MC â¤ 6.2% also survived in liquid nitrogen, whereas viability was reduced to about 50% of that of seeds originally dried and not stored in liquid nitrogen. Thus, seeds of this species exhibit orthodox storage behaviour.

SeedsMature orange-red fruits (drupes) of C. manillana were harvested from two trees growing in Kenting, Pingtung County on the southern tip of Taiwan in 2004. Mature purple-black fruits of S. octophylla were harvested from four or five trees at each of three collection sites in 2003 (see Table 1). Champereia seeds plus endocarps (hereafter seeds) were extracted directly by washing fruits in water and removing the exocarp and mesocarp. The three lots of Schefflera fruits were placed in a greenhouse equipped with automatic mist spray systems for 2~3 days until the fleshly pericarp rotted, and then the seeds were extracted by washing fruits in water. The clean, sunken seeds of both species were allowed to dry 5~6 hours at room temperature, after which they were stored temporarily in sealed containers at 4oC before treatments. Seeds of S. octophylla were separated by 2 mm screen mesh, and seeds that remained on the screen were used for tests. The white-gray seeds of C. manillana have a fully-developed embryo, a thin endocarp and a membranous seed coat; no endosperm is present. The dark gray seeds of S. octophylla consist of the seed coat and a small embryo [embryo length : seed length = 0.251 Â± 0.026 (SE), n = 15] surrounded by a large amount of endosperm.Drying treatments and storageFresh seeds of C. manillana with an original MC of 28.3% were dried in a sealed container (40 x 25 x 25 cm) with silica gel inside. A small fan was placed inside the container for air circulation; temperature outside the container was maintained at 15oC. A standard sample for estimating MC of the seeds was removed from the sealed container at frequent internals, weighed and then returned to the container. The approximate MC of these seeds was determined using a âgenericâ standard curve (decrease in seed weight vs % MC of seeds). When an approximate desired MC of the standard sample was reached, seeds to be used for various storage treatments were removed from the sealed container for testing actual MC and wrapped in laminated aluminium foil. Actual MCs of seeds then were determined with three replications of 15 seeds and calculated on a fwb after oven drying for 17 h at 103oC (ISTA, 1999). Thus, seeds with MCs of 5.6, 11.3 and 16.3% were obtained. They were sealed in laminated aluminium foil and stored at 15, 4 and -20oC. After 0, 1, 6, 12 and 18 months, three replications of 30 seeds for each of these storage temperatures were tested for germination. Thus, the total number of treatments for seeds of C. manillana was 45 (3 MCs x 3 temperatures x 5 storage periods = 45). Fresh seeds of S. octophylla were dried at various relative humidities (RHs) maintained with saturated salt solutions of LiCl (RH 14%), CaBr2 (RH 20%), MgCl2 (RH 33%) and Ca(NO3)2 (RH 56%) in closed containers at 15oC for 14 days, and MC of seeds was allowed to reach equilibrium with the RH of the inside air (Vertucci and Roos, 1993). MC of seeds taken from containers was measured following ISTA (1999) procedures using three replications of 30 seeds for each treatment and site, after which the seeds were quickly sealed in laminated alumininum foil and stored at 15, 4 and -20oC until tested for germination. At intervals of 0, 4, 8, 12 and 24 months, three replications of 50 seeds for each of these storage conditions were tested for germination. Thus, the total number of treatments for each collection site was 60 (4 MCs x 3 temperatures x 5 storage periods = 60).Liquid nitrogen storageUsing the procedures described above, seeds of C. manillana were dried to a MC of 5.6% and those of S. octophylla from Liukuei and Tasueshan to MCs of 4.4, 4.7, 5.1, 5.5, 6.2, 7.6 and 10.4%, and then they were sealed in aluminium foil packets for storage at liquid nitrogen (-196Â°C). Seeds in the aluminium foil packets were immersed directly into liquid nitrogen (hereafter LN) for storage. Each storage treatment consisted of three replications of 30 seeds for C. manillana and of 50 seeds for S. octophylla. After 1, 6 and 12 months for C. manillana and 4, 8, 12, 24 for S. octophylla, seeds were removed from LN, placed at -20Â°C for at least four hours and then at 4Â°C for several hours, after which they were tested for germination at 30/20oC in light.Cold moist storageFresh seeds of S. octophylla from the three collection sites were mixed with moist sphagnum, sealed inside polyethylene bags and stored at 4Â°C in darkness for 0, 2, 4, 8 and 12 months prior to testing them for germination. Each treatment consisted of three replications of 50 seeds. The sphagnum used for treatments was cut into small pieces and then wetted to a MC of about 400% of its dry mass.Statistical analysisGermination percentages (mean and SE) were calculated, and means were compared by analysis of variance (ANOVA) and by least significant difference (LSD) test at the 5% level of significance (SAS, 2004).

Relationships among selected wood properties of 20-year-old Taiwania (Taiwania cryptomerioides) trees

The relationships between bending properties, compressive strength, tracheid length, microfibril angle, and ring characteristics of 20-year-old Taiwania (Taiwania cryptomerioides Hay.) trees were examined. The trees came from different thinning and pruning treatments, but the practices showed no significant effect on the investigated properties. The results showed that based on comparison with the literature, plantation-grown immature Taiwania have noticeably lower average strength properties than mature trees of the same species. Wood density and bending and compressive strengths were not related to either tracheid length or microfibril angle in young Taiwania. There were positive relationships between bending strength and compressive strength. The wood density, ring width, earlywood width, earlywood density, and latewood percentage were the most important predictors of strength by simple linear regressions. The wood density and ring width/ earlywood width may be considered as indicators for assessing the bending strength, while wood density and latewood percentage were the best predictors of compressive strength by multiple linear regressions.

Content: Cheng-JungLinTFRIAssistant ResearcherDivision of Forest Utilization, 53 Nanhei Rd., TaipeiTaipei100Taiwan02-23039978#260402-23035738d88625002@yahoo.com.tw
Chih-MingChiuTaiwan Forestry Research InstituteDivision of Forest Managementcmchiu@tfri.gov.tw

methodsThe study plantation was planted at a rate of 1750 trees/ha(initial spacing) in 1980. Thinning (811–1528 trees/ha) and pruning (3.6–4.5 m) treatments were implemented in 1990.The study site is located in the no. 12 compartment of the Liukuei Experimental Forest of the Taiwan ForestryResearch Institute (TFRI), Kaohsiung Country, southern Taiwan. The diameter and height of each tree on the 27 smallplots were investigated and measured. A mean diameter from the trees was selected from each plot. In total, 27 meandiameter trees from the stands were selected and cut for testing. The average diameter at breast height (DBH) oftest sampled trees ranged from 23.53 to 28.03 cm. The average tree heights varied from 15.2 m to 15.8 m. (Fig. 1) These trees were harvested on February 14 and 15, 2001, and were about 20 years old. One 50-cm-long log was cut from each tree where its DBH was about 80–130cm above the ground. One crosssectional disk (10 cm thick) was cut from each sample log. A diametrical strip (passing through the pith) was sawn from each disk in the same direction. The strip was cut from the disk for drilling resistance, tracheid length, and microfibril angle measurements.In addition, a piece of cant (passing through pith) was sawn from each log (40 cm long) in an east–west direction.Then, they were further band-sawn into specimens by the cant sawing method, as shown in Fig. 2.Only the nine outermost growth rings (about 3 specimens and diametrical strips) near the bark of the trees weretaken and used to assess the selected wood properties. This is because the trees were sampled 9 years after thinning and pruning treatments. The cambium age of the sample specimens was 12–20 years old (from different silvicultural regimes).All small clear specimens [32 (long) × 1.5 (wide) ×1.5 cm (thick) and 3 (long) × 1.5 (wide) × 1.5 cm (thick)] were cut from the 40-cm-long cant for the bending and compressive tests. Thus, more than a total of 324 specimens were measured (27 trees × more than 6 specimens × 2 tests) for two strength tests. All specimens were conditioned in acontrolled environment room at 20°C and 65% relative humidity such that the wood had a moisture content of 12%.methodsA commercially available ultrasonic testing tool was used to evaluate the ultrasonic wave velocity and dynamicmodulus of elasticity. Then, specimens [32 (long) × 1.5 (wide) × 1.5 cm (thick)] were also measured using an ultrasonicwave technique for longitudinal transmission; the ultrasonic wave apparatus (Sylvatest-duo, 22kHz; Swiss Products) included a transmitting transducer and receiving transducer. The ultrasonic wave velocity (V) and the dynamicmodulus of elasticity (DMOE) were calculated in this experiment.All diametric strips of Taiwania were subjected to the drilling resistance test, tracheid length, and microfibril anglemeasurement. These strips were chosen from same product lot and experimental methods were taken from the sametechniques used in previous studies.6,17 Resistograph measurements were made on specimens (strips, at ca. 12% moisture content) in the radial direction.The annual ring contours were marked on a chart for tree ring and control parameters, including the average tree-ringwidth (RW), earlywood width (EW), latewood width (LW), tree-ring density (RD), earlywood density (EWD), latewooddensity (LWD), highest density (HD), lowest density (LD), and latewood percentage (LWP) in a ring.Bending and compressive methods for wood strength determination were in accordance with CNS 45420 and CNS453,21 respectively. Static bending tests were conducted in accordance with the center-loading method for specimensusing a universal test machine (UH-10A; Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan). All specimens were loaded flatwise, and the spanwas 26cm in the bending tests. The proportional limit, ultimate load, and deflection were obtained from the load–deflection curves, and the modulus of elasticity (MOE) and modulus of rupture (MOR) were calculated. Moreover, thecompressive strength in the longitudinal direction to the grain of a test specimen was evaluated.

methodsThe study plantation was planted at a rate of 1750 trees/ha(initial spacing) in 1980. Thinning (811–1528 trees/ha) and pruning (3.6–4.5 m) treatments were implemented in 1990.The study site is located in the no. 12 compartment of the Liukuei Experimental Forest of the Taiwan ForestryResearch Institute (TFRI), Kaohsiung Country, southern Taiwan. The diameter and height of each tree on the 27 smallplots were investigated and measured. A mean diameter from the trees was selected from each plot. In total, 27 meandiameter trees from the stands were selected and cut for testing. The average diameter at breast height (DBH) oftest sampled trees ranged from 23.53 to 28.03 cm. The average tree heights varied from 15.2 m to 15.8 m. (Fig. 1) These trees were harvested on February 14 and 15, 2001, and were about 20 years old. One 50-cm-long log was cut from each tree where its DBH was about 80–130cm above the ground. One crosssectional disk (10 cm thick) was cut from each sample log. A diametrical strip (passing through the pith) was sawn from each disk in the same direction. The strip was cut from the disk for drilling resistance, tracheid length, and microfibril angle measurements.In addition, a piece of cant (passing through pith) was sawn from each log (40 cm long) in an east–west direction.Then, they were further band-sawn into specimens by the cant sawing method, as shown in Fig. 2.Only the nine outermost growth rings (about 3 specimens and diametrical strips) near the bark of the trees weretaken and used to assess the selected wood properties. This is because the trees were sampled 9 years after thinning and pruning treatments. The cambium age of the sample specimens was 12–20 years old (from different silvicultural regimes).All small clear specimens [32 (long) × 1.5 (wide) ×1.5 cm (thick) and 3 (long) × 1.5 (wide) × 1.5 cm (thick)] were cut from the 40-cm-long cant for the bending and compressive tests. Thus, more than a total of 324 specimens were measured (27 trees × more than 6 specimens × 2 tests) for two strength tests. All specimens were conditioned in acontrolled environment room at 20°C and 65% relative humidity such that the wood had a moisture content of 12%.methodsA commercially available ultrasonic testing tool was used to evaluate the ultrasonic wave velocity and dynamicmodulus of elasticity. Then, specimens [32 (long) × 1.5 (wide) × 1.5 cm (thick)] were also measured using an ultrasonicwave technique for longitudinal transmission; the ultrasonic wave apparatus (Sylvatest-duo, 22kHz; Swiss Products) included a transmitting transducer and receiving transducer. The ultrasonic wave velocity (V) and the dynamicmodulus of elasticity (DMOE) were calculated in this experiment.All diametric strips of Taiwania were subjected to the drilling resistance test, tracheid length, and microfibril anglemeasurement. These strips were chosen from same product lot and experimental methods were taken from the sametechniques used in previous studies.6,17 Resistograph measurements were made on specimens (strips, at ca. 12% moisture content) in the radial direction.The annual ring contours were marked on a chart for tree ring and control parameters, including the average tree-ringwidth (RW), earlywood width (EW), latewood width (LW), tree-ring density (RD), earlywood density (EWD), latewooddensity (LWD), highest density (HD), lowest density (LD), and latewood percentage (LWP) in a ring.Bending and compressive methods for wood strength determination were in accordance with CNS 45420 and CNS453,21 respectively. Static bending tests were conducted in accordance with the center-loading method for specimensusing a universal test machine (UH-10A; Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan). All specimens were loaded flatwise, and the spanwas 26cm in the bending tests. The proportional limit, ultimate load, and deflection were obtained from the load–deflection curves, and the modulus of elasticity (MOE) and modulus of rupture (MOR) were calculated. Moreover, thecompressive strength in the longitudinal direction to the grain of a test specimen was evaluated.

Denitrification associated N loss in mangrove soil

The effect of salinity and nitrogen (NO3- and NH4+) on growth, nutrition and nitrogen uptake in Kandelia candel (L) Druce was investigated in phytroton condition. The experimental design was 4 × 2 factorial with four salinities (0, 0.88, 1.75 and 3.30 % NaCl) and two nitrogen sources (NO3- and NH4+). Nitrogen uptake rates were measured using 15N stable isotope technique. Biomass of shoot and root reduced with increasing salinity. Biomass ratio of root/shoot increased from 0.71 to 1.22 with increasing salinity (0 to 3.30 % NaCl salt) indicating reduction in the flux of water and nutrient transport. It was appeared that young seedlings of K. candel were salt tolerant and hypoctoyl acts as a buffer, regulate salt and nutrients. Increase in NaCl concentration from 0 to 3.30 % significantly reduced nitrogen content of leaf and root by 20 % and 57 % respectively. Nitrogen uptake was significantly reduced with increase in salinity. Nitrate and ammonium were utilized in more or less equal proportion at low salinity whereas NH4+ appears to be major source only at high salinity levels. N uptake patterns support the hypothesis that K. candel can utilize NO3- and NH4+ simultaneously as N source but salinity has strong bearing on it.

Denitrification as affected by inhibitor and plantingAnalysis total N, toal organic C, CEC, pH, EC.Denitrification as affected by soil depthSoil samples were taken using PVC tubes (30 cm long and 1.5 cm inner diameter). The PVC tubes were stoppered on both ends and brought back to the laboratory in a cooler. The ration of actual lenght of soil samples in PVC tubes to the total lenght of PVC tubes inserted in the soil was used to determine the rate of compression. Soil samples were but into 3 cm pieces from the surface, taking into consideration the compression rate. As the mean compresson rate was about 0.6, each 3-cm section represented a 5-cm soil depth. Analysis of samples started within a few hours after sampling.

林業科技資訊網際網路系統管理與維護(3/4)

（1）完成資產管理系統服務之維護管理，可利用神網PC資產管理系統服務協助本所網域內電腦機台之軟硬體資產資訊及管理功能。 （2）建置即時網路流量監測及管理軟體，並於本所Firewall與Router端所安裝之安裝網路流量監測系統，透過TCP/UDP的通訊協定，即時分析通過路由器的各項通訊訊息產出報表。 （3）建置軟體派送機制，以有效達到軟體派送、更新及管理，加強資訊安全管理 （4）建置Microsoft System修補程式update機制所需的軟硬體。 （5）建置VPN結合FTP Server，並建置VPN提供本所遠端使用者存取本所FTP。 （6）提供電子郵件保全的軟體或硬體與規劃並建置MAIL Server異地備援機制。 (7) 舉辦相關資訊系統及軟硬體之教育訓練及說明會：建立全所同仁資訊作業能力、提高設備及應用系統之使用率。

Application of borrelidin from Streptomyces candidus on biocontrol of tree seedling damping-off diseases

Streptomyces candidus Y21007-2(Sc), a naturally screened actinomycete, is antagonistic toward several damping-off disease pathogens of tree seedlings. The growth of Phytophthora cinnamomi was retarded in by diluted metabolites from S. candidus, with most retardation by undiluted metabolites. The complex antagonistic metabolites from S. candidus was further fermented and developed into commercial products (borrelidin from S. candidus, BA-Sc), and was applied in the integrated control of the damping-off pathogens such as Phytophthora cinnamomi (Pc) , Sclerotium rolfsii (Sr) and Rhizoctonia solani (Rs). When the seeds of Koelreuteria henryi Dummer and Cinnamomum camphora (L.) Prsil were coated with the produced biocontrol agent (BA-Sc), their germination rate and the sequential growth of seedlings were better than controls, in both the soil containing the damping-off pathogens and in control groups. After 3-month, germination rates of the seeds treated with BA-Sc were elevated 12%, 4% and 12% in the soil with Pc, Sr and Rs, respectively. The average height of the seedlings from BA-Sc-treated seeds also increased 13.8, 10.14 and 6.79 cm in the soil with Pc, Sr and Rs respectively. Interestingly, the BA-Sc treatment was somewhat helpful for the seed germination and seedling growth in the soil without those pathogens. Another experiment demonstrated that the infected seedlings planted in the BA-Sc treated soil were 5.04 cm higher than those in untreated soil after three months. In addition, the average height of uninfected seedlings grown in the BA-Sc treated soil also was 4.14 cm higher than the averages of those grown in untreated soil. Result showed that BA-Sc should be capable for control pathogens of damping-off diseases.

Composition and Antimicrobial Activity of the Leaf Essential Oil of Litsea nakaii from Taiwan

The leaf essential oil of Litsea nakaii was isolated by hydrodistillation and analyzed to determine its composition and yield. Fifty-five compounds were identified, the main components being α-humulene (15.5%), δ-cadinene (9.2%), (E)-β-ocimene (8.1%), and δ-selinene (7.1%). The leaf oil exhibited excellent antimicrobial activities.

Plant materialsThe fresh leaves of L. nakaii were collected in May 2006 from Shangwu (Taitung County, southern Taiwan, elevation 350 m, N 22º 20´ 72˝, E 120º 53´ 01˝). The samples were compared to specimen no. 11705 from herbarium of National Chung-Hsing University (NCHU) and identified by Prof. Yen-Hsueh Tseng of NCHU. The voucher specimen (CLH-001) has been deposited in the Taiwan Forestry Research Institute herbarium. Leaves of the species were collected for subsequent extraction and analysis.voucher specimen (CLH-001)Isolation of the leaf essential oilThe leaves of L. nakaii (1 kg) were hydrodistillated for 8 hrs in a Clevenger-type apparatus. The oil collected was dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate.Essential oil analysisThe method of Su et al. was adopted [13]. A Hewlett-Packard HP 6890 gas chromatograph equipped with a DB-5 fused silica capillary column (30 m x 0.25 mm x 0.25 μm film thickness, J&W Scientific) and a FID detector was used for the quantitative determination of oil components. Oven temperature was programmed as follows: 50oC for 2 min, rising to 250oC at 5oC /min. Injector temperature: 270oC. Carrier gas: He with a flow rate of 1 mL/min. Detector temperature: 250oC, split ratio: 1:10.GC/MSHewlett-Packard HP 6890/HP5973 equipped with a DB-5 fused silica capillary column (30 m x 0.25 mm x 0.25 μm film thickness, J&W Scientific)

The voucher specimen (CLH-001) has been deposited in the Taiwan Forestry Research Institute herbarium. 喜樹繁殖與枝葉採收之研究（2/2）Study on propagation and leafy stem harvest of Camptotheca acuminata.（2/2）

建置於蓮華池不同栽植密度喜樹枝葉生產試區，以單位面積栽植密度最高的9,000株之枝葉生產收穫量最大，栽植後4個月的第一次收穫量約為1.7公噸/公頃，次年4月第二次收穫量約為4.9公噸/公頃，8月第三次收穫量則每公頃估算為2.2公噸。栽植1.5年之枝葉產量估計約為8.8公噸/公頃，就野外試驗顯示栽植區之喜樹生長，施肥及水分灌溉是喜樹充分生長所必須之栽培條件。 另就建置於台南之喜樹栽植試區，於93年7月栽植後，至93年12月調查，以栽植密度22,000株/公頃試區估算收穫量最大，新鮮枝葉產量可達5公噸/公頃，顯示喜樹栽植初期密植可增加單位面積生產量之結果，但對於後續產量，則有待進一步之枝葉量採收資料加以佐證。 The study on leafy production (B & L) of Camptotheca acuminata of three planting densities, 3,000、6,000 and 9,000 trees/ha were established at Lienhuachih experiment site. The 9,000 trees/ha showed the maximum productivity. From the B&L production of the first harvesting, that harvested after 4 months growth was 1.7 ton/ha and the new sprouting were let it passing through the winter season. The second harvest were on Apr. of the next year. And B & L production reached 4.9 ton/ha, while third harvest (Aug.) was 2.2 ton/ha. The total B&L production of 1.5 years C. acuminata plantation was 8.8 ton/ha. The field practice showed that irrigation and sustaining fertilization can elevated the B&L yield of C. acuminata. The other C. acuminata plantation was established at Tainan, 6 months later 22,000 trees/ha showed the highest B&L productivity (5 ton/ha). The results reveal that increasing the planting density could increase the unit productivity. We expect the harvesting data 1.5 years of plantation will match the estimated result in the nearly future.

1.喜樹種子發芽與儲藏技術之開發由國內民間栽植之喜樹林，目前已能生產大量種子，惟目前種子採收後顯示發芽不易，儲藏方法不明。為調控種苗生產期，故擬考慮以低溫濕藏或以調控種子含水率進行乾藏試驗，以期建立種子儲藏技術。2.喜樹扦插繁殖技術之建立選取喜樹幼苗稍木質化之幼嫩枝條，施以不同濃度之發根激素進行扦插繁殖試驗，期建立喜樹扦插無性繁殖體系。3.建立種子苗枝葉生產栽培區選定本所蓮華池研究中心之平坦山坡地進行枝葉生產造林體系之研究，初擬規劃以每公頃3300株、6800株及9000株之栽植試區，並于栽植區苗高達於枝葉生產時，以40公分高度以上為採取目標，採取並秤鮮重，推算喜樹幼嫩枝葉單位面積生產潛力。另就合作廠商所提供台南仁德地區台糖土地，進行枝葉生產區的建立，藉以評估不同地區喜樹的枝葉生產潛力。

Composition and Antimicrobial Activity of the Leaf and Twig Oils of Litsea mushaensis and L. linii from Taiwan

The hydrodistilled essential oils of the leaves and twigs of Litsea mushaensis and L. linii were analyzed. Sixty-nine and ninety compounds were identified in the leaf and twig oils, respectively, of L. mushaensis. The main components of the leaf oil were β-eudesmol (24.2%), -cadinol (10.2%), α-humulene (10.1%), α-pinene (9.7%), and trans-β-ocimene (6.5%), whereas the main components of the twig oil were trans-β-ocimene (19.5%), α-pinene (12.8%) and cis-β-ocimene (7.7%). With L. linii, 72 and 78 compounds were respectively identified in the leaf and twig oils. The main components of the leaf oil were β-selinene (15.7%), α-selinene (15.5%), β-caryophyllene (12.2%), α-humulene (7.2%), and δ-cadinene (5.6%), and of the twig oil trans-β-ocimene (20.8%), β-selinene (11.4%), α-cadinol (6.0%), δ-cadinene (5.8%), -cadinol (5.4%) and β-eudesmol (5.2%). L. mushaensis leaf oil was shown to have excellent antimicrobial and anti-wood-decay fungal activity, superior to the other oils.

Plant materials Fresh leaves and twigs of L. mushaensis and L. linii were respectively collected from Zhudong (Hsinchu County, northern Taiwan, elevation 580 m, N 24º 34´ 16˝, E 121º 23´ 38˝) in July 2009 and Shangwu (Taitung County, eastern Taiwan, elevation 850 m, N 22º 20´ 72˝, E 120º 53´ 01˝) in July 2008. The samples were respectively compared with specimen no. ou5338 and ou5686 from the Herbarium of the National Chung-Hsing University and positively identified by Prof. Yen-Hsueh Tseng of NCHU. The voucher specimens (CLH-009 and CLH-008) were deposited in the NCHU herbarium. Leaves and twigs of the species were collected for subsequent extraction and analysis. Isolation of the leaf and twig essential oils Leaves and twigs of L. mushaensis and L. linii (1 Kg) were placed in a round-bottom flask and hydrodistilled for 8 h with 3 L of distilled water, respectively. The essential oils obtained were dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate. The oil yields and all test data are the average of triplicate analyses. Essential oil analysis A Hewlett-Packard HP 6890 gas chromatograph equipped with a DB-5 fused silica capillary column (30 m x 0.25 mm x 0.25 μm film thickness, J&W Scientific) and a FID detector was used for the quantitative determination of oil components. Oven temperature was programmed as follows: 50ºC for 2 min, rising to 250ºC at 5ºC/min. Injector temperature: 270ºC. Carrier gas: He with a flow rate of 1 mL/min. Detector temperature: 250ºC split ratio: 1:10. One μL sample was injected. Identification of the oil components was based on their retention indices and mass spectra, obtained from GC/MS analysis on a Hewlett-Packard HP 6890/HP5973 equipped with a DB-5 fused silica capillary column (30 m x 0.25 mm x 0.25 μm film thickness, J&W Scientific). The GC analysis parameters listed above and the MS were obtained (full scan mode: scan time: 0.3 s, mass range was m/z 30-500) in the EI mode at 70 eV. All data were the average of triplicate analyses. A Hewlett-Packard HP 6890 gas chromatograph equipped with a DB-5 fused silica capillary column (30 m x 0.25 mm x 0.25 μm film thickness, J&W Scientific) and a FID detector was used for the quantitative determination of oil components. Component identification Identification of the leaf and twig oils constituents was based on comparisons of retention index (RI) [18], retention times (RT), and mass spectra with those obtained from authentic standards and/or the NIST and Wiley libraries spectra, and literature [7,19], respectively. Antimicrobial activity The in vitro antibacterial and antifungal activity of the leaf and twig oils were evaluated by the disc diffusion method using Mueller-Hinton agar for bacteria and Sabouraud dextrose agar for fungi [20]. Discs containing 15 μL and 30 μL of the oil, which was dissolved in dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO), were placed on the inoculated plates with test microorganisms. Growth inhibition zones (including disc diameter of 6 mm) were measured after 24 h and 48 h of incubation at 37°C and 24°C for bacteria and fungi, respectively. Gentamicin and tetracycline for bacteria, and nystatin for fungi were used as positive controls [4,5]. Microbial strains were obtained from the Culture Collection and Research Center of the Food Industry Research and Development Institute, Hsinchu City, Taiwan. The microbial strains included 5 Gram-negative bacteria: Escherichia coli (IFO 3301), Enterobacter aerogenes (ATCC 13048), Klebsiella pneumoniae (ATCC 4352), Pseudomonas aeruginosa (IFO 3080), and Vibrio parahaemolyticus (ATCC 17803); 3 Gram-positive bacteria: B. cereus (ATCC 11778), S. aureus (ATCC 6538P), and S. epidermidis (ATCC 12228); 1 fungus: A. niger (ATCC 16404) and 1 yeast: C. albicans (ATCC 10231). Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) values were measured by the microdilution broth susceptibility assay recommended by NCCLS [21]. Stock solutions of the oil were prepared in DMSO. Dilution series were prepared from 1000 μg/mL to 50 μg/mL in sterile distilled water in micro-test tubes, from where they were transferred to 96-well microtiter plates. Bacteria grown in double-strength Mueller-Hinton broth and fungi grown in double-strength Sabouraud dextrose broth were standardized to 108 CFU/mL. The last row, containing only the serial dilutions of sample without microorganisms, was used as a negative control. Sterile distilled water and medium served as a positive control. After incubation at 37°C for 24 h and 24°C for 48 h, the MIC values were determined. All experiments were performed in triplicate. Anti-wood-decay fungal assays The method of Su et al. [22] was adopted. The fungi used were T. versicolor (BCRC 35253), Phane. chrysosporium (BCRC 36200), Phaeo. schweinitzii (BCRC 35365) and L. sulphureus (BCRC 35305). Microbial strains were obtained from the Culture Collection and Research Center of the Food Industry Research and Development Institute, Hsinchu City, Taiwan. Anti-wood-decay fungal assays were carried out in triplicate and the data were averaged. Different concentrations of the essential oil (12.5~100 μg/mL) were added to sterilized potato dextrose agar (PDA). The test plates were incubated at 27ºC. When the mycelium of fungi reached the edge of the control plate, the anti-wood-decay fungal index was calculated as follows: Anti-wood-decay fungal index (%)= (1–Da/Db) X 100, where Da is the diameter of the growth zone in the experimental dish (cm) and Db is the diameter of the growth zone in the control dish (cm). DDAC (didecyl dimethyl ammonium chloride) for wood decay fungi was used as a positive control.

Monitoring and development of health forest

1. Analysis of the database for forest pests and other abiotic factors occurring in the past was achieved. Several forest areas were chosen to evaluate the impact and establish the database through the analysis of GIS and climate data. They included: pine wilt disease occurring in northern Taiwan, the windbreak forest infected by Phellinus noxius at the coastal area of central Taiwan, tussock moth on Casaurina, fir wilt disease and forest fire at mountain area of central Taiwan. 2. Investigate and montor the pests caused by Phellinus noxius and Quadrastichus erythrinae occurring in Taiwan. 3. To establish the database of pest monitoring system with the GPS. 4. To establish the forest fire database and the forest fire forecast system. 5. To help the Taiwan Forest Bureu to establish the sampling and monitoring sites of Cycad aulacaspis scale occurring at Taitung area.

過去森林為害資料庫之分析選定北部松線蟲萎凋病為害區，中部海岸林褐根病為害區、埔里杉木枯萎及大甲溪二葉松營林火為害區，分析過去10年的衛星影象及氣象資料與受害情形，以建立台灣重要造林地之受害情形，並建立資料庫。目前森林為害之分析選定中部松線蟲萎凋病為害區、中部海岸林褐根病為害區埔里杉木枯萎區及大甲溪二葉松營林火為害區，於計畫執行期間就過去病害資料庫進行樣區分析選定，並建立為害因子之監測內容，以建立為害因子與氣象之關係。地面調查於設置的樣區內，1.定期調查生物性為害因子的出現頻度、數量及為害嚴重度；2.調查相關的生物量作為推估燃料狀態之基本燃料量；3.樣區之衛星影象及氣象資料收集。建立森林健康監測模式運用地理資訊系統將相關為害因子整合，利用數值空間數據建立基本圖層，再將各因子依健康營林目標，建立森林健康監測的模式。測試結果進行有效性分析運用過去10年之資料庫，進行初步之健康森林監測模式測試，並將測試結果進行有效性分析。

Seed dormancy in the early diverging eudicot Trochodendron aralioides (Trochodendraceae)--Germination test

The embryo length/seed length (E/S) ratio of the early diverging eudicot Trochodendron aralioides is 0.34. Embryos in fresh seeds were 0.36 ^ 0.01mm long, and they increased in length by about 250% (in 20 d) before radicle emergence (germination) occurred, demonstrating that the embryo is underdeveloped at seed maturity. Seeds germinated to 95â100% at 20/10, 25/15 and 30/158C in light in #4 weeks, without any pretreatment, but no seeds germinated in darkness. Thus, seeds of T. aralioides have morphological dormancy (MD), which is considered to be the primitive condition in seed plants, and MD probably has existed in the genus Trochodendron since its origin in the early Tertiary.

seedsRipe seeds were collected on 19 November 2004 from plants of T. aralioides growing in Yangmingsham, Taiwan (258100N, 1208310E) at an elevation of 790m in the subtropical evergreen broadleaved forest zone. After drying at room temperature for 1 week, seeds were air-mailed to the University of Kentucky, Lexington, USA, where the study was performed. Seeds were stored dry at room temperature until used in germination or embryo growth studies.germination testTwo germination tests were conducted. In the first one, which began on 22 December 2004, seeds were incubated in light (14 h daily photoperiod of about 40mmolesm22 s21, 400â700 nm, cool white fluorescent light) at a constant temperature of 58C and at 12/12 h daily alternating temperature regimes of 15/6, 20/10 and 25/158C. At the alternatingtemperature regimes, the photoperiod extended from 1 h before to 1 h after the daily high temperature period. Fifty seeds were sown in each of 12 9.5-cm-diameter Petri dishes on sand moistened with distilled water, and three disheswere placed at each temperature regime. Dishes were wrapped with plastic film to reduce the rate of water loss. Seeds were checked after 3, 4, 6, 8, 10 and 12 weeks, at which time germinated seeds were counted and removed from the dishes. The second germination test was initiated on 9 January 2005, at which time seeds were incubatedin light (14 h daily photoperiod) and in continuous darkness at 12/12 h daily alternating temperature regimes of 15/6, 20/10, 25/15 and 30/158C. Fifty seeds were sown in each of 24 9.5-cm-diameter Petri dishes on sand moistened with distilled water. Three dishes each were placed in light and in darkness at each temperature. All dishes were wrapped with plastic film, and those to be incubated in darkness were wrapped additionally with two layers of aluminium foil. Seeds incubated in light were checked for germination after 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 10 and 12 weeks, but those incubated indarkness were checked only after 4 weeks, at which time they were discarded.

Application of the Fractometer for crushing strength: Juvenile-mature wood demarcation in Taiwania (Taiwania cryptomerioids Hay)

The Fractometer is a device that breaks a radial increment core along the fiber for the measurement of crushing strength which is a direct wood quality indicator for structural lumber. In this study, the crushing strength of Taiwania (Taiwania cryptomerioides Hay) trees using the Fractometer was investigated and the data were used to determine the position of demarcation between juvenile and mature wood. Segmented regression and variance component analysis were used to estimate the demarcation position. Upon increasing the distance from the age, the crushing strength of juvenile wood has been improved. Within-tree variations in wood properties are greater than tree-to-tree variations. In this experiment, the position of demarcation between juvenile and mature wood occurred at an approximate distance of 10.8 cm to 13.2 cm from the pith that was about 18-20 yeas of cambium age.

Plantation siteTaiwania was selected to test the validity of the variance component and segmented regression analysis for crushing strength. The experimental plantation was located in compartment No.3, Liukuei Experimental Forest of the Taiwan Forestry Research Institute (TFRI). The mean annual temperature, relative humidity, and precipitation were 18.6 â, 81 %, and 1150 mm, respectively. The weather can be divided into a dry season and a rainy season. No silvicultural treatment is performed in sampling trees of this plot. The test samples were taken as each of the 19 trees in a study plantation established with a 2 m Ã 2 m spacing and 2500 trees/ha in 1972.SamplingWe took different DBH (diameter at breast height) classes in order to understand the effect of different DBH on juvenile-mature wood demarcation (position). But, the data of suppressed trees are not ideal for strength analysis. 5 Therefore, the samples can be only classified into two types on the basis of DBH, namely, mean 33.6 cm (Type A: 8 trees) and 26.4 cm (Type B: 11 trees) (i.e. dominant trees and intermediate trees, respectively). The two DBH classes are suitable to be used as structural lumber.Core specimensAn increment borer was used to cut cores 5 mm in diameter from Taiwania trees. From the eastern aspect of each sample tree, we extracted a pith-to-bark increment core specimen at DBH (same direction) in December 2003, when they were about 32 years old. The increment cores were conditioned in a controlled-environment (20 â and 65% relative humidity). The measurements were done on treated core (12% moisture conditioned for 2 months).Measurements of crushing strengthAssessment of the crushing strength of Taiwania was investigated by using a Fractometer. The Fractometer (Type II, IML, Germany) is a device that breaks a radial increment core for the measurement of fracture strength along the fiber. The commercially available Fractormeter was used to evaluate the crushing strength of increment cores from pith to bark per 12 mm. The cylindrical specimen is inserted into the jaws so that the fibers are parallel to the direction of load.Numbers of measurementA total of 14 samples (distance from pith) from each tree (core of Type A) were studied (numbered 1.2 cm, 2.4 cm, 3.6 cm, and so on , up to 16.8 cm outward from pith to the bark) and a total of 11 samples (distance from pith) from each tree (core of Type B) were studied (numbered 1.2 cm, 2.4 cm, 3.6 cm, and so on, up to 13.2 cm outward from pith to the bark) for crushing strength.
Cores from pith to bark every 1.2cm.

Three Newly Naturalized Asteraceae Plants in Taiwan

Three newly naturalized Asteraceae species are reported in this paper. Cotula australis (Sieber ex Spreng.) Hook. f. and Erigeron bellioides DC. are well established and naturalized in urban areas of northern Taiwan. Ageratina riparia (Regel) R.M. King & H. Rob. is naturalized to northern and central Taiwan. Descriptions and illustrations of these alien Asteraceae plants are provided.

Chromosome Numbers of Five Species of the Marattiaceae in Taiwan

The chromosome numbers of root tips of all 5 species of the Marattiaceae in Taiwan were determined. Results showed that Angiopteris lygodiifolia (2n = 80), Angiopteris palmiformis (2n = 80), and Marattia pellucida (2n = 78) are diploid; Archangiopteris itoi is triploid (2n = 120), and Archangiopteris somai is tetraploid (2n = 160). These chromosome numbers together with previous evidence support the hypothesis that Archangiopteris itoi is a hybrid between Angiopteris lygodiifolia and Archangiopteris somai.

Plant CollectingSixteen plants of 5 species were collected from Taiwan and a nearby island, Lanyu. Those plants were transplanted to the Taipei Botanical Garden.SquashingAfter about 1month of cultivation, the root tips were pretreated for 3~4 h with a mixture of 70 ppm cycloheximide and 250 ppm 8-hydroxyquinoline (1:1) at about 18~20℃. The root tips were fixed for 1~3 h in a mixture of 45%acetic acid and absolute ethanol (1:3) at about 20℃, and then preserved in 70% ethanol at 4℃. Then they were macerated for 1~3 min in 1 N HCl at 60℃, washed for 10 s and digested for 1~2 h in 4% pectinase. Finally, theroot tips were squashed in modified Sharma’s solution (Sharma 1982). The chromosome number of root tip cells was observed with a light microscope (Leitz, Dialux 20) and photographed with a digital camera (Nikon, Coolpix 995).

Plant CollectingSixteen plants of 5 species were collected from Taiwan and a nearby island, Lanyu. Those plants were transplanted to the Taipei Botanical Garden.SquashingAfter about 1month of cultivation, the root tips were pretreated for 3~4 h with a mixture of 70 ppm cycloheximide and 250 ppm 8-hydroxyquinoline (1:1) at about 18~20℃. The root tips were fixed for 1~3 h in a mixture of 45%acetic acid and absolute ethanol (1:3) at about 20℃, and then preserved in 70% ethanol at 4℃. Then they were macerated for 1~3 min in 1 N HCl at 60℃, washed for 10 s and digested for 1~2 h in 4% pectinase. Finally, theroot tips were squashed in modified Sharma’s solution (Sharma 1982). The chromosome number of root tip cells was observed with a light microscope (Leitz, Dialux 20) and photographed with a digital camera (Nikon, Coolpix 995).
Chromosome Numbers of Five Species of the Marattiaceae in Taiwan
櫸木人工林造林木碳貯存量和吸存量之估算

櫸木(Zelkova serrata (Thunb.))為台灣最重要的闊葉樹造林樹種之一。本研究以苗栗約46年生和台東約25年生兩林人工林為對象，估算其造林木之生物量和生長量，建立根莖比和擴展係數等參數和迴歸式，以估算其碳貯存量和吸存量。結果顯示，櫸木根莖比苗栗為0.240，台東為0.250，兩林分相近，且與熱帶闊葉林平均值相似。地上部擴展係數台東為1.528 Mg m-3，只略高於苗栗的1.328 Mg m-3。兩林分地上部生物量連年生長和平均生長皆隨年齡呈上升趨勢，在24年生後上升趨勢才減緩。苗栗林分櫸木生物量為252.3 Mg ha-1，高於亞洲熱帶地區闊葉林的平均值，台東林分為108.4 Mg ha-1，則偏低。櫸木植體的地上部碳平均濃度，苗栗為49.0%，台東為49.6%。以此換算成林分櫸木碳吸存量，苗栗地上部平均量為1.95 Mg ha-1 yr-1，全株平均量為2.40 Mg ha-1 yr-1；台東地上部為1.81 Mg ha-1 yr-1，全株為2.25 Mg ha-1 yr-1。櫸木能長期貯存大量的碳，可減緩溫室效應。 關鍵詞：人工林、碳貯存量、碳吸存量、根莖比、擴展係數

樣區調查於上述兩林分選擇林冠鬱閉，無明顯孔隙區域，各設立3個臨時樣區。每樣區面積為0.09 ha (30×30 m)。以胸高直徑（簡稱胸徑）大於10 cm之林木定義為喬木，胸徑1~10 cm之林木為灌木。經調查兩林分樣區之胸徑、樹高、株數等資料，列如表1。苗栗林分其他喬木以日本楨楠 (Machilus japonica Sieb. et Zucc.)、江某 (Schefflera octophylla (Lour.) Harms)、山漆 (Rhus succedanea L.)等樹種最多；台東林分則以楓香 (Liquidambar formosana Hance)、黑星紫金牛(Ardisia virens Kurz)、桑樹 (Morus alba L.)等樹種最多。於上述兩林分之大樣區內四個角落各設立5×5 m之小樣區1個。調查其內之灌木及地被植物。就樹種而言，灌木部分苗栗林分以日本楨楠、黑星紫金牛、山香圓 (Turpinia formosana Nakai)等樹種為主；台東林分則以厚殼樹 (Ehretia acuminata R.)、桑樹、通脫木 (Tetrapanax papyriferus (Hook.))、九芎 (Lagerstroemia subcostata Koehne)等為主。地被植物苗栗林分以冷清草(Elatostema lineolatum Wight var. majus Wedd.)、玉山紫金牛 (Ardisia chinensis var. morrisonensis (Hayata))、蕨類等為主；台東林分以卷柏 (Selaginella spp.)、蕨類、弓果藤 (Cyrtococcum patens (L.))等為主。造林木選定與生物量之測定以造林木樣區資料分析胸徑之分布，將胸徑依5 cm分為一級，苗栗林分由10 cm起至50 cm以上共分8級。台東林分則由10 cm起至30 cm以上分為5級。兩林分皆依據樣區內各胸徑級株數之比例選取樣木株數，每胸徑級內選取1~11株樣木 (含粗根生物量和樹幹解析之4株樣木)，測定其生物量，各林分喬木伐取樣木之性質和株數如表2。2006年10至12月間於此兩林分樣區內分別進行伐木取樣工作，將選定之樣木伐倒後，測定樹高、樹冠幅、活葉高(樹冠底部第一片活葉出現的高度)，並以活葉出現位置至樹冠頂端定義為樹冠長。伐倒木的植體區分為樹幹、死枝、葉、小枝條(著葉枝)、大枝條(除著葉枝外之枝條)、附生植物等6部分，分別稱其鮮重。樹幹於樹高1.3 m、樹冠底部及樹冠中央部位各取一約5 cm厚圓盤，稱其鮮重，帶回實驗室後測定其烘乾重(65℃)。再將樹冠依其中央部位區分為上、下兩層，分別稱取死枝、葉、小枝條、大枝條的小樣本(約400 g)，於實驗室中測定其烘乾重。各株樣木皆可由攜回實驗室樣本之烘乾重及其鮮重，推算出各樣本之烘乾重與鮮重比，並由烘乾重與鮮重比分別乘以各植體之鮮重，推算各單株林木之地上部生物量。地下部生物量只測定粗根部分(直徑≧5 mm)。於此兩林分造林木樣木中選取最接近平均胸徑之平均木4株，且其基部1 m半徑範圍無其他喬木存在。每株於測定地上部生物量後，在距基部1 m半徑範圍內之粗根全部挖取。取樣時，由外緣向內小心挖掘，收集粗根，並清除附著的土壤，粗根區分為造林樹種、其它樹種兩類，分別稱鮮重。根頭部份取圓盤1個，造林木粗根取小樣本3個，各約400 g，其餘樹種粗根取1個小樣本，攜回實驗室。於室內清洗後測定其烘乾重，以烘乾重和鮮重比推算單株林木粗根生物量，並以地上部生物量和粗根生物量推算根莖比。附生植物則收集苔蘚和膜蕨以外的附生植物，以單株樣木為單位，不分植株，植體只稱總重，再取小樣本攜回實驗室，烘乾稱重。造林木材積及生長量之測定上述4株平均木除測定粗根生物量外，於樹幹0.3 m、1.3 m處，以及1.3 m以上每2 m間隔如3.3 m、5.3 m…等，取一厚約5 cm之圓盤進行樹幹解析，探討胸徑和樹高與樹齡的關係。用Smalian公式以區分求積法計算林木材積，由生物量與材積推估生物量擴展係數，並推估地上部生物量之連年生長(current annual increment of aboveground biomass, CAIAB)和平均生長(mean annual increment of aboveground biomass, MAIAB)，再建立生物量連年生長和平均生長與樹齡的關係。林分生物量之估算兩地區之喬木及灌木分別以單株林木地上部各部位生物量，或總量生物量與胸徑配置迴歸方程式，選擇最常用的自然對數式lnY = a + b ln (dbh)，以估算單株各部位生物量及總生物量，式中Y為地上部各部位或總量之生物量(kg)，dbh為胸徑(cm)，a和b為迴歸係數。同時，以上述迴歸式推算，胸徑與樹高之關係。另外，迴歸式經過自然對數的轉換，常數a必需經校正係數校正 (Baskerville 1972)。單株林木的迴歸式選出後，以各樣區之造林木資料估算出樣區之地上部生物量，再換算成單位面積之地上部各部位生物量。地下部生物量則以各林分造林木平均粗根根莖比為基礎，推估各林分不同組成之地下部生物量及總生物量。SAS software含碳與氮量估算以植體小樣本供碳與氮濃度分析之用，兩林分各取11株樣木(含4株挖根之樣木)，使其涵蓋大部分樣木之樹種及胸徑級，進行含碳與氮量分析。各植體之樣本磨成細粉 (<0.5 mm)，以乾燒法用元素分析儀 （elementor vario EL型）測定其碳與氮濃度 (Sollins et al. 1999)。由迴歸法估算出造林木單位面積各部位之生物量乘以各部位之平均碳與氮濃度，可估算出造林木碳與氮總貯存量。元素分析儀 （elementor vario EL型）
plot numbers, 3 at Miaoli Hsian and 3 at Taidung
classification of trees by planted and dbh 1: planted trees and its dbh>10 cm 2: other trees and its dbh>10 cm 3: bushes and its dbh<10 cm
experimental site 1: Miaoli Hsian 2: Taidung Hsian

櫸木人工林造林木碳貯存量和吸存量之估算

台灣中部選擇位於苗栗縣泰安鄉的林分，屬大湖事業區61林班，造林年度約在1960年。由中央氣象局苗栗氣象站的統計資料顯示苗栗地區年平均溫度為22.1℃，年平均降雨量為1,625 mm，降雨量超過150 mm的月份為5~9月，10~2月為乾季(月平均降雨量低於100 mm)。林分海拔高為820-870 m、坡度20-26∘，土壤為壤土，其中粘粒佔31.4 %、坋粒41.2 %、砂粒27.6 %，pH値4.6 。120.93120.9524.424.38

台灣東南部林分則選擇位於台東縣延平鄉的林分，屬成功事業區7林班，造林年度約為1981年。台東氣象站統計資料則顯示台東地區年平均溫度為24.3℃，年平均降雨量為1,856 mm，5-10月為雨季，其餘月份為乾季。林分海拔高為290~370 m、坡度9-20∘，土壤則經取樣分析後，其質地為坋質黏土，其中粘粒佔45.2 %、坋粒36.7 %、砂粒18.1%，pH値5.4。121.15121.1722.9522.91

台灣、西表島與香港銀葉樹族群遺傳多樣性之研究

銀葉樹是一種能生長在陸地，亦可適生於潮間帶的正紅樹類植物，雖然在亞洲、澳洲及非洲等地均可見，但由於過度伐採與生育地破壞，導致族群數量銳減，正面臨嚴重威脅。本研究以台灣、香港及日本西表島等地區6個族群60個單株應用簡單序列重覆分子指紋技術，來探討台灣與鄰近島嶼銀葉樹族群遺傳結構及各族群間的親緣關係。依POPGENE分析的結果顯示，總基因歧異度(H)為0.2888，族群間遺傳分化係數(Gst)為0.2742，基因流(Nm)為0.6618，顯示族群已具分化結構。族群間基因流傳並不暢通，不同島嶼間已明顯呈現分化現象，推測應受到島嶼區隔及海流方向影響。經由UPGMA歸群分析結果可區分為三群，即台灣、香港及西表島之族群各自成群，島嶼間以台灣與香港的族群較相近，而西表島的族群遺傳距離則較遠。Mantel test結果顯示族群間地理距離與遺傳距離雖呈正相關但不顯著(r=0.47，P=0.13)，其族群呈隨機散佈，因此遺傳漂變在族群分化上扮演重要角色。族群的分子變方分析(AMOVA)顯示，族群間變方成分佔38.17%( p＜0.001)，族群內個體間的變方成分佔61.87% ( p＜0.001)，顯示族群變異主要於族群內個體之間。故就所得之族群遺傳訊息，建議除需採取就地保育之措施來保存所有族群外，並應進行遷地保育措施。

植物材料針對台灣恆春半島 ( 香蕉灣及港仔2個族群 )、東北角 ( 卯澳及福隆2個族群 )、香港（荔枝窩）及日本（西表島）等4個地區，計6個銀葉樹天然族群進行取樣，採集其幼嫩部位葉片，以供相關分析，採集地點、數量與地理位置詳如表1及圖1。於每族群內取樣時，每隔10~20m隨機選取一株，每單株選取無病蟲害之葉子5-10片，以透氣紙袋包裝後，再利用矽膠乾燥劑於室溫下脫水保存。DNA之萃取與ISSR的擴大反應參考Kobayashi 等人 ( 1998 ) 的CTAB萃取法進行萃取，分離出的DNA加入0.1ml的TE Buffer保存。並利用分光光度計進行DNA濃度 ( ng / μl ) 之測量。參考Zietkiewicz等人 ( 1994 ) 的方法，PCR反應溶液總體積為25μl，其內容物濃度為10 mM Tris-HCl ( pH 9.0 )，50 mM KCl，1.5 mM MgCl2，0.1 % Gelatin ( w/v ) ，1 % Triton X-100 ( w/v ) ，20 ng template DNA，200 μM dNTPs，0.2 μM Primer，1 units Taq polymerase ( Protech Technology Enterprise co., Ltd ) ，於溫度循環器thermocycler ( Applied Biosystems Geneamp PCR System 9700, Foster City, USA ) 進行PCR反應設定溫度循環程序，94℃，6分鐘 ( initial denaturing step ) 後，加上35次循環的：94℃， 60 秒 DNA ( denaturing )，50.6℃-60.5℃， 50 秒，黏合溫度 ( annealing ) 依引子不同而定 ( 表2 )，72℃，2 分15秒 ( elongation ) ，72℃，7 分鐘 ( final elongatoin step ) 最後降溫至4℃ ( end ) 。（Ⅲ）電泳、染色與照相配製1.5 % Agarose，將完成擴大反應的DNA樣本添加追蹤染劑 [ tracking dye ( 0.25 % bromophenol blue, 0.25 % xylene cyanol FF, 30 % glycerol in water )] 與100 bp DNA Ladder，然後以電壓150V進行電泳分析，約2-2.5 h。完成電泳的膠片以溴化乙錠 ( ethidium bromide ) 染色並置於UV燈上顯影觀察，且以Vilber Lourmat CN-100拍照作為記錄。族群遺傳參數1. 記錄強度較強且清晰的DNA片段，有條帶出現者記錄為1，無條帶者記錄為0。利用NTSYS-pc ver. 2.0套裝軟體 ( Rohlf, 1993 )，以Dice公式計算兩兩樣本間之相似度（SAB），建立相似度矩陣（Ssm）。 SAB =2 NAB / （2NAB+ NA+ NB）SAB=兩兩樣本間之相似度。NA=僅在樣本A出現的條帶數。NB=僅在樣本B出現的條帶數。NAB =在樣本A與在樣本B皆出現的條帶數。2. 將各族群之條帶記錄以POPGENE ver. 1.31套裝軟體（Yeh et al, 1999）計算族群間的遺傳資料，包含Nei’s基因歧異度 ( H ) ( Nei, 1973 )。Ho = - Σpi ( lnPi ) ；Pi指某個DNA片段出現的頻度 ( frequency ) 。Shannon's多型性訊息指數 ( I )（Shannon and Weaver, 1949）。如假設各族群近親交配指數 ( Fis ) 為0，則可計算族群間遺傳分化係數Gst ( coefficient of gene differentiation ) ，再利用Gst估算基因流傳值Nm ( Nm = 0.25 × ( 1-Gst ) / Gst ) (Slatkin and Barton, 1989)。3. 進行AMOVA ( Analysis of Molecular Variance ) 分析，以Excoffer et al. ( 1992 ) 所發表兩兩族群的距離公式求得距離矩陣D。D=N ( 1-Ssm ) = N ( 1-M/N ) ； M=兩兩樣本相同條帶數；N=多型性條帶總數。將距離矩陣以AMOVA ver. l.55程式進行分析（Excoffer et al., 1992 )，求得地區間、地區內、族群間、族群內個體間之變方成份值及各變方成份所佔總變方成份的百分比，並用9999次之隨機重排列檢定 ( random permutation test ) ，測驗各變方成分之顯著性，並繪製成不同層級之分析歸納表。4. 將AMOVA計算得之族群間遺傳距離 (Φst ) 矩陣，以NTSYS之配對不加權算數平均值 ( UPGMA ) 的方法進行歸群分析 ( Cluster analysis ) 建立樹枝圖（Sokal and Michener, 1958）。同時透過主座標分析 ( Principal coordinates analysis, PCoA ) 來繪製樣本分布圖，以及運用Mantel test ( Mantel, 1967 ) 來檢測遺傳距離矩陣 ( Φst ) 與相對地理矩陣間的相關性 ( r )。此外UPGMA歸群分析與原距離矩陣間的吻合程度以協表相關係數 ( r ) 來估計，且同樣運用Mantel Z 統計進行( Mantel, 1967 )。

台灣、西表島與香港銀葉樹族群遺傳多樣性之研究
Two New Bulbophyllum (Orchidaceae) Species in Taiwan:B. brevipedunculatum and B. ciliisepalum

Bulbophyllum (Orchidaceae) is the largest orchid genus in Taiwan. It is taxonomically problematic due to difficulty of field collection and morphological similarities between some species. In this study, we recognized two new Bulbophyllum species, B. brevipedunculatum and B. ciliisepalum, from eastern and central Taiwan. Descriptions, illustrations, and comparisons among related species were also presented.

Application of the Fractometer for crushing strength: Juvenile-mature wood demarcation in Taiwania (Taiwania cryptomerioids Hay)

The Fractometer is a device that breaks a radial increment core along the fiber for the measurement of crushing strength which is a direct wood quality indicator for structural lumber. In this study, the crushing strength of Taiwania (Taiwania cryptomerioides Hay) trees using the Fractometer was investigated and the data were used to determine the position of demarcation between juvenile and mature wood. Segmented regression and variance component analysis were used to estimate the demarcation position. Upon increasing the distance from the age, the crushing strength of juvenile wood has been improved. Within-tree variations in wood properties are greater than tree-to-tree variations. In this experiment, the position of demarcation between juvenile and mature wood occurred at an approximate distance of 10.8 cm to 13.2 cm from the pith that was about 18-20 yeas of cambium age.

Plantation siteTaiwania was selected to test the validity of the variance component and segmented regression analysis for crushing strength. The experimental plantation was located in compartment No.3, Liukuei Experimental Forest of the Taiwan Forestry Research Institute (TFRI). The mean annual temperature, relative humidity, and precipitation were 18.6 â, 81 %, and 1150 mm, respectively. The weather can be divided into a dry season and a rainy season. No silvicultural treatment is performed in sampling trees of this plot. The test samples were taken as each of the 19 trees in a study plantation established with a 2 m Ã 2 m spacing and 2500 trees/ha in 1972.SamplingWe took different DBH (diameter at breast height) classes in order to understand the effect of different DBH on juvenile-mature wood demarcation (position). But, the data of suppressed trees are not ideal for strength analysis. 5 Therefore, the samples can be only classified into two types on the basis of DBH, namely, mean 33.6 cm (Type A: 8 trees) and 26.4 cm (Type B: 11 trees) (i.e. dominant trees and intermediate trees, respectively). The two DBH classes are suitable to be used as structural lumber.Core specimensAn increment borer was used to cut cores 5 mm in diameter from Taiwania trees. From the eastern aspect of each sample tree, we extracted a pith-to-bark increment core specimen at DBH (same direction) in December 2003, when they were about 32 years old. The increment cores were conditioned in a controlled-environment (20 â and 65% relative humidity). The measurements were done on treated core (12% moisture conditioned for 2 months).Measurements of crushing strengthAssessment of the crushing strength of Taiwania was investigated by using a Fractometer. The Fractometer (Type II, IML, Germany) is a device that breaks a radial increment core for the measurement of fracture strength along the fiber. The commercially available Fractormeter was used to evaluate the crushing strength of increment cores from pith to bark per 12 mm. The cylindrical specimen is inserted into the jaws so that the fibers are parallel to the direction of load.Numbers of measurementA total of 14 samples (distance from pith) from each tree (core of Type A) were studied (numbered 1.2 cm, 2.4 cm, 3.6 cm, and so on , up to 16.8 cm outward from pith to the bark) and a total of 11 samples (distance from pith) from each tree (core of Type B) were studied (numbered 1.2 cm, 2.4 cm, 3.6 cm, and so on, up to 13.2 cm outward from pith to the bark) for crushing strength.
Cores from pith to bark every 1.2cm.

Identification and detection of Bougainvillea spectabilis chlorotic vein-banding virus in different bougainvillea cultivars in Taiwan

A new virus disease of bougainvillea occurred in Taiwan and proved to be caused by a Badnavirus, which is similar to the pathogen tentatively named ‘Bougainvillea spectabilis chlorotic vein-banding virus (BsCVBV)’ in Brazil according to pathological and molecular results. In electron microscopic observations, typical bacilliform virions measuring 130–158×27–42 nm were observed in infected bougainvillea tissues. The transmission tests demonstrated that the virus could be easily transmitted among different bougainvillea cultivars by bud grafting but not by mechanical inoculation. BsCVBV showed different pathogenicity to various bougainvillea cultivars in our inoculation tests. The Taipei-Red and Thimma cultivars showed the apparent foliar symptoms of chlorosis, chlorotic spots, wrinkling and leaf-distortion; the original species of Bougainvillea glabra produced chlorotic spots and vein clearing on leaves without wrinkling or leaf distortion; both ‘Mrs. Eva Mauve Variegata’ and Hati Gadis showed mild mottling and faint spots of leaves; Helen Johnson was tolerant to BsCVBV. Our devised PCR-based assays demonstrated that BsCVBV could replicate and persistently survived in all tested bougainvillea cultivars used in this study although it induced different symptoms in them. The BsCVBV-1 primer pair devised from our cloned BsCVBV-specific DNA fragments proved to be efficient in the PCR assays for the rapid and specific detection of BsCVBV in Taiwan, and this PCR-based method is helpful in the quarantine, inspection and ecological studies for BsCVBV in Taiwan.

Plant and virus sourcesThe diseased bougainvillea plants suspected to be infected by BsCVBV were collected from the Taipei-Red cultivars (Bougainvillea buttiana, a hybrid derived from Bougainvillea Glabra×B. peruviana), which were previously grown on the campus of National Taiwan University in Taipei. These infected bougainvilleas exhibited symptoms such as mottling, chlorosis, vein banding and stunting. They were directly used in the identification of pathogen, and the one showing the most apparent and severe symptoms was further propagated by the cutting method for a donor plant of inocula in the graft-inoculation tests.Five additionally important bougainvillea cultivars in Taiwan such as B. glabra ‘original species’ (ORI), B. glabra ‘Mrs. Eva Mauve Variegata’ (MEMV), B. glabra ‘Hati Gadis’ (HG), B. buttiana ‘Helen Johnson’ (HJ) and Bougainvillea spectoglabra ‘Thimma (TH) (Vicky)’ (a hybrid derived from B. spectabilis×B. glabra) were used in the bioassays with graft inoculation aside from the Taipei- Red cultivar for comparative symptomatology. All these 3 cultivars with different morphological properties in their flowers and leaves (Cullen, 2001; MacCubbin & Tasker, 2002) were originally obtained from the nursery or greenhouse at the Department of Horticulture at National Taiwan University and were tested for BsCVBV infection using the PCR assays described later to confirm that they are free from BsCVBV. To avoid the possibility that the parts of genomic DNA of Badnavirus integrated into the host genome, all vegetative materials such as grafting budwoods and cutting twigs for propagation of healthy bougainvilleas must be BsCVBV free through the confirmation of PCR assays. The BsCVBV-free cultivars were used as mother plants to produce more seedlings for further inoculation tests.Mechanical inoculation and graft inoculation with BsCVBVFor biological identification, the BsCVBV extracts from diseased bougainvillea tissues were used to inoculate several indicator plants such as Chenopodium amaranticolor, Chenopodium quinoa, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana glutinosa, Nicotiana benthamiana and Nicotiana tabacum through mechanical transmission. The inoculated plants were kept in a greenhouse under temperature control at 25℃ for the observation of symptom development.Budwood grafting methods of Su & Chu (1984) and Yoshida (1996) were chosen for the graft inoculation. In total, six bougainvillea cultivars as described abovewere inoculated with the BsCVBV-infected scions of the Taipei-Red cultivar by grafting. Each cultivar had four replicates of seedling (50 cm tall, 1-year old) for the objective results, and each receptor plant was graft inoculated with two diseased scions at the 10- and 40-cm positions from the top of bougainvillea seedling. Grafting was judged successful when the scions survived for more than 3 months after grafting. All the inoculated bougainvillea seedlings were grown in a greenhouse under temperature control at 25℃. Symptom development was observed and recorded periodically, and all tested plants were sampled monthly for total nucleic acid extraction followed by the PCR-based detection of BsCVBV. The healthy bougainvillea seedlings without graft inoculation were also prepared for the negative controls under the same growth conditions.Transmission electron microscopyFor the preparation of virus samples for transmission electron microscopy, virus particles were purified from the diseased bougainvillea tissues according to the methods described by de Silva et al. (2002) and Adomako et al. (1983) with slight modifications. In brief, the diseased leaves were homogenised in the extraction buffer [0.25 M Tris–HCl (pH 7.4) containing 0.5% (w/v) sodium sulphite, 4% (w/v) polyvinyl pyrrolidone 40, 0.5% (v/v) 2-mercaptoethanol and 0.25% diethyldithio-carbamic acid] with a tissue blender. The sap was clarified through muslin filtration and then added slowly with Triton X-100 (final concentration of 2%) under room temperature. The sample was clarified again through centrifugation 4 (12 000 g for 20 min at 10℃). The supernatant was mixed with polyethylene glycol (MW 6000) in the presence of 0.2 M NaCl and kept at 4℃ for 4.5 h. The resulting pellets were resuspended overnight in 60 mL TN buffer [50 mM Tris–HCl (pH 7.4) and 150 mM NaCl] and centrifuged again (12 000 g for 10 min at 4℃). The supernatant was ultracentrifuged (150 000 g for 2 h at 4℃) to precipitate the virus particles. The pellet was resuspended in 600μl Tris–buffer [50 mMTris–HCl (pH 7.0)].To prepare the specimen for transmission electron microscopy, grids (200 meshes) were coated with supporting film (0.5% formvar in chloroform) and then treated with carbon coating and ion sputter. One drop (approximately 20μl) of the virus preparation as mentioned above was placed on the grid, incubated for 1 min and then removed by filter paper slip. Another drop of 1% phosphotungstic acid (PTA) was put on the grid for approximately 5 min for negative staining. The grid was dried in a vacuum desiccator after removing PTA. Finally, the specimen was examined under a transmission electron microscope (JEM 100 CXII; JOEL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan).Nucleic acid preparation for PCR assaysThe nucleic acid extracts for the PCR templates were prepared using the same method as described by Hung et al. (1999). In brief, bougainvillea leaf samples (approximately 500 mg) were homogenised in the nucleic acid extraction buffer [0.1 M Tris–HCl (pH 8.0), 0.05 M ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), 0.5 M NaCl, 1% N-lauroylsarcosine] and incubated at 55℃ for 1 h. After low-speed (4000 g) centrifugation, the supernatant was treated with 1% hexadecyl-trimethyl-ammoniumbromide at 65℃ for 10 min. The nucleic acid was precipitated (12 000 g) with isopropanol after chloroform/ isoamyl alcohol (24:1) and phenol/chloroform/isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) treatments. The nucleic acid pellet was resuspended in 150μl TE buffer (pH 8.0).Primers and polymerase chain reaction conditionsTwo opposing primers, based on the published sequences of the conserved region of replicase in Badnavirus genomes (Bouhida et al., 1993), were selected in the PCR assay to amplify the BsCVBV-specific fragments for cloning and sequencing. The primer pair (named Badnavirus – 0.67 kb), composed of the forward primer 5’-TCA AAGTTT GAT TTG AAG AGC GGG-3’ and the reverse primer 5’-CTT GCA TAC TGC TCC CCA TCC-3’, were designed to amplify a BsCVBV-specific 0.67 kb fragment by PCR.Another primer pair (named BsCVBV-1), derived from the sequences of our cloned BsCVBV-specific DNA fragments as described above, was designed for the BsCVBVspecific PCR amplification. Primer pair BsCVBV-1, composed of the forward primer 5’-ACA GCG ATT TCA TTGCTG TG-3’ and the reverse primer 5’-GAC TAG TTC TCGATC AGA AGG-3’, was designed to amplify a 413-bp fragment for the rapid detection of BsCVBV by PCR.Polymerase chain reaction was performed using 25μl of reaction mixture containing 20 mM Tris–HCl (pH8.4), 50 mM KCl, 4 mM MgCl2, 0.2 mM each dATP, dTTP, dCTP and dGTP, 50 ng of each primer, 0.75 units of Taq DNA polymerase (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA) and 250 ng template DNA. Thermal cycling conditions were as follows: one cycle at 94℃ for 3 min; 30 cycles at 94℃ for 1 min, 60℃ for 1 min and 72℃ for 2 min, followed by a 72℃ extension for 10 min. Reactions were carried out in a DNA thermal cycler (GeneAmp PCR System 2400; Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA, USA).Analysis of PCR products by electrophoresisPolymerase chain reaction products were analysed by gel electrophoresis using 1.4% agarose in TAE buffer (40 mM Tris–acetate, 1 mM EDTA, pH8.0). After electrophoresis (100 V for 30 min), products in the gel were stained with ethidium bromide (0.5μg mL-1 ), visualised and analysed by the AlphaImager 2000 Documentation & Analysis System (Alpha Innotech Co., San Leandro, CA, USA). A 100-bp DNA Ladder set (Promega, Madison, WI, USA) was included to determine fragment size.Nucleotide sequencing and sequence analysisPolymerase chain reaction products were clarified using a High Pure PCR Product Purification kit (Roche Applied Science, Mannheim, Germany) and then cloned by a TOPO TA Cloning kit (Invitrogen) according to the protocols supplied by the manual. The recombinant plasmids with specific DNA fragments were checked and selected by PCR amplification with the degenerate primers as described previously, and they were replicated and purified through minipreparation using a Qiaprep Spin Miniprep kit (QIAGEN, Hilden, Germany). DNA sequencing was conducted using ABI PRISM Dye Terminator Cycle Sequencing Ready Reaction kit (Applied Biosystems) and analysed in an ABI PRISM 310 Genetic Analyzer (Applied Biosystems) as recommended by the manufacturer. Primers used for sequencing were M13- reverse and T7 universal primers. The determined nucleotide sequences were further analysed and aligned by the MegAlign module in DNASTAR Lazergene software (DNASTAR Inc., Madison, WI, USA) as well as the Basic Local Alignment Search Tool provided from the National Center for Biotechnology Information.

Development and application of distributed computing system for big data from long term ecological observation in forestry

An open data archive for monitoring Asian soundscape (http://soundscape.twgrid.org) has been established based on the GRID infrastructure under the collaboration between Taiwan Forestry Research Institute (TFRI) and the Academia Sinica Grid Computing Centre (ASGC). TFRI and ASGC also co-hosted a workshop on joint monitoring of Asian soundscape at the Lienhuachih Research Center of TFRI during 17-20 Nov. 2014. Participants from Malaysia, Philippines, Taiwan, Thailand, and Vietnam, all agreed on the protocol and open data license for collecting, contributing, and sharing soundscape data on this soundscape open archive to promote soundscape conservation and research of soundscape ecology in Asia.

Formating SD memory card Because SM2+ can not read the 128GB SD card in exFAT32 or NTFS format, the new SDXC card must be reformat into FAT32 format by a formating tool, e.g., SmartDisk_FAT32_tool.exe. SanDisk 128GB SDXC Class10 USB3.0 SD card reader SmartDisk FAT32 tool Configuring Wildlife Acoustics Song Meter SM2+ 1. Using Song Meter SM2+ Configuration Utility downloaded from Wildlife Acoustics (http://www.wildlifeacoustics.com/support/download-software) to set up the daily schedule and parameters for autpmatic sound recording. 2. The schedule was set to start recording for 5 minutes every hour and half-hour. 3. The audio quality settings weres configured as: 1) sampling rate 44.1 KHz; 2) stereo channel; 3) WAV file format; 4) zero microphone gain; 5) keep all filters and sensors off. 4. File prefix follows the pattern of Organization-Site code 5. The capacity was set as: 1) only activate 1st SD card slot with 128GB; 2) %compress 100; 3) internal power source with alkaline batteries. 6. Save the setting file on computer disk then copy it a 128GB SD memory card. Wildlife Acoustic Song Meter SM2+ Song Meter SM2+ Configuration Utility Setting up SM2+ 1. Follow the SM2+ user manual to set up SM2+ before going out the field. 2. Keep power switch off and insert the 128GB SD card into slot A. 3. Install four fresh D-size alkaline batteries. If the internal clock is not accurate replace two fresh AA-size alkaline batteries. 4. Set the microphone amplifier configuration swtichs: 1 (On, 2.5V Bias); 2-3-4-5 (On-Off-On-Off, High Pass 3 Hz); 6-7-8-9 (Off-On-Off-Off) 5. Turn on the power switch to check the status and load the setting file from SD card (User Manual Page 28). 6. Check the recording by manual trigger (User Manual Page 46). Wildlife Acoustic Song Meter SM2+ Field deployment 1. Mount the SM2+ on a tree with DBH close to the width of the recorder. 2. Connect the two SMX-II microphones to the reoreder. 2. Open the cover and turn on the switch to check the status. If OK, then press the WAKE/EXIT button to let it sleep. 4. Use the 3M tape (or similar alternatives) to seal the connected part between microphones and recorder as well as the upper part of the recorder cover, preventing rain drops seeping into the recorder. Wildlife Acoustics Song Meter SM2+ Wildlife Acoustics SMX-II microphones Monthly site maintenance and data management 1. Monthly revisit the field site to replace fresh batteries, microphones, and 128GB SDXC memory card. 2. Remove excess water on the microphone windscreen sponges and placing the microphones taken back from the field in a electrical dehumidifying box with RH% setting < 50%. 3. Copy all the soundscape recording files from SD card to hard disk. 4. Follow the file naming pattern CountryCode_OrganizationCode_SiteCode_Date_Time and use the free ware Advanced Renamer to batch rename all files. 4. Duplicate all renamed soundscape recording files to hard disks and upload to the Asian Soundscape Open Archive (http://soundscape.twgrid.org). Advanced Renamer (http://www.advancedrenamer.com/)

Dormancy and germination in seeds of the medicinal Asian tree species Phellodendron amurense var. wilsonii (Rutaceae)--Effect of stratification on germination

The effects of alternating temperatures, cold stratification and gibberellic acid (GA3) on seed germination of Phellodendron amurense var. wilsonii were investigated. Incubation at 35/10°C or stratification at 4°C prior to incubation of freshly harvested seeds significantly increased germination percentages from 5% to 87%. Germination percentage was increased only slightly in intact seeds treated with up to 2000 ppm GA3. However, partial removal of the seed coat by mechanical scarification plus GA3 resulted in a drastic increase in both germination percentage and rate. Storage in liquid nitrogen for Ã¢ÂÂ¥ one month enhanced germination percentage, and the beneficial action was due to cracking of the seed coat. Embryos excised from their enclosing tissues and embryos surrounded by endosperm germinated to a much higher percentage than intact seeds, indicating that the water-permeable seed coat plays a mechanical role in preventing radicle protrusion in nontreated intact seeds. Seeds required three months of cold stratification to break dormancy, and GA3 promoted seed germination. We conclude that seeds of P. amurense var. wilsonii have physiological dormancy.

Content: Shun-YingChenTaiwan Forestry Research InstituteAssisant Researcher53 Nan-hai. Rd., TaipeiTaipeiTaiwansychen@tfri.gov.tw

Seed collection and preparationMature black fruits of P. amurense var. wilsonii were harvested from Taiping Mountain (24Â°30'N, 121Â°29'E), Ilan County, northeastern Taiwan, at an elevation of 1600 m in September 2004. The fruits are very oily and aromatic. Fruits harvested from natural forests or plantations should be rapidly transported to the handling place to avoid decreases in viability of the seedlots due to high temperatures in the transport-containers (Chien personal observation). Each fruit contains 3~6 seeds (average 5), but some of them are empty. Fruits were macerated by hand in water, and the empty seeds were floated off and discarded. The clean sunken seeds were used for subsequent treatments. The black seed (4~6 mm long and 2~3 mm wide) consists of the seed coat and a large dicotyledonous embryo surrounded by a small amount endosperm (figure 1). The spatulate embryo (Martin, 1946) is fully developed with a mean (Â± SE) embryo length : seed length ratio of 0.83 Â± 0.02 (n = 15), and it does not grow within the seed before the radicle emerges. Seed moisture content was determined with three replicates of 20 seeds and calculated on a fresh-weight basis after oven drying for 17 hours at 103Â°C (ISTA, 1999).ImbibitionEach of 20 non-scarified and scarified (cut at the point away from embryonic axis) seeds were weighed individually to the nearest 0.1 mg at time 0 and after incubation at ambient laboratory temperature (~24Â°C) for 24 hours on Whatman no. 1 filter paper in Petri dishes moistened with distilled water. Percentage water uptake was calculated as follows: %Ws = [(Wi -Wd)/Wd] X100, where Ws = increase in seed mass, Wi = seed mass after imbibition and Wd = initial seed mass (Hidayati et al., 2000). Embryos were excised from each of 30 imbibed seeds, and then three replications of 10 embryos were weighed to nearest 0.1 mg before and after drying them in an oven at 50Â°C for 24 hours. Percentage embryo moisture content was calculated from these data as described above for seeds.Effect of stratification on germinationFor warm followed by cold stratification, freshly harvested seeds were placed in polyethylene bags (0.04 mm in thickness) with moist sphagnum and sealed, and then they were warm-stratified for 2, 4, 6 and 8 weeks at an alternating temperature regime of 30/20Â°C with 12 hours of fluorescent light (80~100 Mole m-2 s-1; hereafter light) at the higher temperature. These warm-stratified seeds were then given 4, 8, 12, 16 or 20 weeks of cold moist stratification at 4Â°C. A cold stratification treatment without a warm treatment was also carried out on fresh seeds in moist sphagnum for 4, 8, 12, 16 and 20 weeks prior to the seeds being subjected to germination tests. Each stratification treatment consisted of three replications of 100 seeds each. Moisture content (MC) of the sphagnum in both warm and cold stratification treatments was about 400% of its dry mass. Germination tests using fresh seeds were performed in germination chambers at constant 25Â°C and at 35/10, 30/20 and 25/15Â°C (12/12 hours) in light during the higher temperature. Germination tests of warm- followed by cold-stratified seeds or of cold-stratified seeds only were performed at 30/20Â°C, i.e. same temperature as that for warm stratification. Sphagnum served as the germination medium. Germination, i.e. radicle at least 5 mm long, was recorded weekly. Results were expressed as percentage germination after 12 weeks and as the mean germination time (MGT) in days. MGT is a measure of the rate (speed) of germination and of the sharpness of the germination peak: MGT = (total niti)/Gt, where ni = number of seeds germinated in ti days from the beginning of the test and Gt = total number of germinated seeds at the end of the test (Kotowski, 1962).Statistical analysisRadical protrusion data were transformed to percentages based on number of treated seeds. Germination (mean Â± SE) was calculated, and means were compared by two-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and by least significant difference (LSD) at the 5% level of significance (SAS, 2004).

Effects of Chilling Stratification, Scarification and Excised-embryo Test on Seed Viability of Lithocarpus lepidocarpus (Hayata) Hayata

Lithocarpus lepidocarpa seeds were collected in 30,Nov.2003, and the seed were water selected to remove the hollow seed. After water selected, the seeds were cold stratification under 4â, and showed after 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, and 8 months. Forty seeds were showed as control, 20 seeds were wounded and 30 seeds were de-shelled. Two months cold stratification increase germination vigor and germination rate (85%) than without cold stratification seed as Liu and Kuo (1999) done, and the germination rate of wounded seeds were the same as the seeds only cold stratification, but could germinated faster. More than 4 months cold stratification, the germination rate of not only control but also wounded seed were decrease, while the germination rate of de-shelled seed were no influenced by the duration of cold stratification and maintained the germination rate in 90-100%. The results show that the seed of Lithocarpus lepidocarpus Hayata has dormancy, which could removed after 4â cold stratification for two months, and has serious physical barrier for seed germination. The best germination condition of Lithocarpus lepidocarpa will be cold stratification the water selected seed more than 2 months and de-shelled, which the germination rate will more than 90%.

桂竹林之生長特性與崩塌擴張潛勢之探討

本研究探討桂竹生長特性、根系剖面、根力行為以及桂竹林之崩塌原因。研究顯示桂竹屬地下莖密度高，主要分布於土層 0-30 cm深度處，大多成純林之林相，較一般樹林單調且多樣性低。鬚根集中於土層0-60cm深度處，最深約可達70 cm，具有固結土 壤與防止地表沖蝕之功能。在土壤深度60 cm之範圍，依土壤剖面內之根面積比與單根之抗拉強度，可推算桂竹根系所能提供之土壤剪力強度增量值△Sr。同時，此增量值之大小主要視地下莖之數量而定。另外，依據現地試驗結果及觀察資料，可綜合評估桂 竹林地之崩塌特徵、崩塌地擴張潛勢、以及桂竹根系對坡地崩塌之作用與影響。
