GeneralUV spectra were obtained in CH3CN, IR spectra were measured on a Hitachi 260-30 spectrophotometer. 1H NMR (500 MHz), HETCOR, NOESY and DEPT spectra were obtained on a Varian (Unity Plus) NMR spectrometer. Low-resolution FABMS and lowresolution EIMS spectra were collected on a Jeol JMS-SX/SX 102A mass spectrometer or Quattro GC/MS spectrometer having a direct inlet system. High-resolution EIMS spectra were measured on a Jeol JMS-HX 110 mass spectrometer. Si gel 60 (Merck, 70–230 mesh, 230–400 mesh) was used for column chromatography. Precoated Si gel plates (Merck, Kieselgel 60 F-254), 0.20mm and 0.50 mm, were used for analytical TLC and preparative TLC, respectively, visualised with 50% H2SO4.Plant materialThe leaves of M. zuihoensis Hayata var. mushaensis (Lu) Y.C. Liu were collected from Wulai Hsiang, Taipei County, Taiwan in May 2005. A voucher specimen (Machino 6) was characterised by one of the authors (Y.-R. Hsui) and deposited in the Basic Medical Science Education Center, Fooyin University, Kaohsiung County, Taiwan.Extraction and isolationThe leaves of M. zuihoensis Hayata var. mushaensis (Lu) Y.C. Liu (5 kg) were extracted repeatedly with MeOH (10L5) at room temperature for 24–48 h. The combined MeOH extracts were evaporated and partitioned to yield CHCl3 and aqueous extracts. The CHCl3 layer (89.5 g) was concentrated and chromatographed over a Si gel column (5010 cm) using MeOH/CHCl3 as eluted to produce 13 fractions. Fr. 4 (16.4 g) was eluted with CHCl3 :MeOH (40 : 1) and was then repeatedly subjected to column chromatography (CC) to give machilolin-A (1) (9.1 mg) and -sitosterol (3) (2.0 g), stigmasterol (4) (2.7 g). Vanillin (2) (10.3 mg) was eluted from Fr. 6 (20.1 g) by Si gel column chromatography (CHCl3 :MeOH 20 : 1).

Organic Matter Accumulation in the Forest Floors of Forest Ecosystems in Taiwan-soil analysis

Organic matter accumulation in the forest floors is important for carbon and nutrient storage and cycling in forest ecosystems. In the winter of 2001, forest floors were sampled in 7 major forest types of mountainous areas of Taiwan: Taiwan red pine, Taiwania, China-fir, Crptomeria, Taiwan red cypress, natural broad-leaved and coniferous forests. Results shows that organic matter accumulation of these 7 forest types increased with an increase in elevation, except the O2 layers of Taiwania and O1 layers of natural coniferous forests which showed an opposite trend. Adding stand age to the regression equations increased the predictive capability of the regression equations based on elevation only. The regression equations developed in this study can be used along with the tree aboveground biomass derived from forest timber surveys to estimate the regional forest aboveground biomass and carbon accumulation in Taiwan.

Duplication of the class I cytosolic small heat shock protein gene and potential functional divergence revealed by sequence variations flanking the a-crystallin domain in the genus Rhododendron (Ericaceae)

Background and Aims Positive selection in the a-crystallin domain (ACD) of the chloroplast small heat shock protein (CPsHSP) gene was found in a previous study and was suggested to be related to the ecological adaptation of Rhododendron species in the subgenus Hymenanthes. Consequently, it was of interest to examine whether gene duplication and subsequent divergence have occurred in other sHSP genes, for example class I cytosolic sHSP genes (CT1sHSPs) in Rhododendron in Taiwan, where many endemic species have evolved as a result of habitat differentiation.

The DNA concentration was determined for each sample using the GeneQuant II RNA–DNA Calculator (Amersham Biosciences, Little Chalfont, UK). Silvicutural Growth Performances of Thirteen Endemic Broadleaf Trees of Taiwan

We investigated the growth potential of some endemic broadleaf species in restorative reforestation. In March 1993, mix-plots planting of the test species was carried out in a tract of land situated at 800 m elevation with south-west facing slope at the Tamalee Research Center of the Taiwan Forestry Research Institute, Taitung, Taiwan. Each species was planted with 3~5 plot repetitions, and in each plot 50 trees of the same species was planted with a 2 x 2 m spacing. A total of 13 species were tested. Survey of the sapling growths were carried out yearly from May of 1996 on, and the frequency changed to 2-year since February of 2003. Tree height and diameter at breast height (DBH) growths were compared from year-to-year, and tree forms were also investigated at the later years. The common elaeocarpus (Elaeocarpus sylvistris) and incense machilus (Machilus zuihoensis var, zuihoensis) saplings grown at the experimental plots, showed good growth and survival rates. After out-planting for 108 mos, the average height growths reached 750 and 730 cm, respectively. And their survival rates in the plantation were about 60%. Other indigenous broadleaf trees, with the exception of Pasania kawakamii which had not reached 5 m in average height, all other endemic broadleaf trees native to the mid-elevation forests of Taiwan, including Pasania kawakamii, Schima superba, Schefflera octophylla, Lithocarpus castanopusisifolius, and Cinnamomum micranthum, although not as fast growing as some traditional plantation species such as Fraxinus formosana, reached average height growth > 5 m, and their average DBH growth all reached 7 cm, nevertheless. The net height growth of the various species in the first 3 yrs, with the exception of Zelkova serrata which reached 80 cm yr-1, all other species had rates of 30~50 cm yr-1. In the 3rd to 5th years, however, all species had net height growths over 80 cm yr-1, with E. sylvistris reached 140 cm yr-1. These were the fast-growing period of the saplings and the rates maintained until the 88th month of out-planting. These results suggest that the endemic broadleaf species have tremendous afforestation potential in the mid- and low-elevation plantation forests of Taiwan. When coupled with good tending and management of the forests, even greater potential can be realized. Even in the early-stage of growth, the saplings often had forking tendencies with crown cover of 2 m or more, which may cause problems for subsequent growth performances and the form and quality of the timber utilization. In particular, as the average forking rate reached 40%, we deem that advancing the schedule for pruning and thinning of the small-diameter-log shall be practice to promote healthy growth of the stand. Regression analysis using tree height growth and tree age as variables generated regression equations having R2 of 0.90 or better, indicating that the 2-variable polynomial regression equations can be used to predict the early growth of forest trees. The information may be also useful in estimating the year-to-year carbon dioxide sequestration amounts in man-made broadleaf forests.

Content: Setup of the experimental siteThe experimental site of the mixed hardwood plantation project is located at the experimental forest of the Tamalee Research Center of TFRI in Taitung. The site has an elevation of 900 m above the sea level, and a southwest facing slope. The selected hardwood species and planting numbers per ha are shown in Table 1. The site was prepared in a horizontal striped fashion and the selected tree species were planted in a mixed-block fashion, with each block planted with 50 trees of the same species (5 rows of 10 trees each); and the blocks are randomized with each species comprising 3~5 blocks for a total of 57 blocks. The planting distances between trees were 2*2 m.Climate conditions of the experimental siteUpon establishing the permanent mixed-hardwood experimental site, a nearby weather station, the Maililu station of the Tamalee Research Center provided year-round temperature and rainfall information which are shown in Table 2. The data shows that the plantation site has an annual mean temperature of ca. 20â, with maximum daily temperature of 36â. It has an annual rainfall of 3500 mm, and a maximum monthly rainfall of 1000 mm. Rainy days can be as high as 160 d or more. Although there were records of temperature less than 10â during the period from November to March of next year, even in winter, an average temperature of 15â was attained. Thus, the site has a relative high annual mean temperature, plus rich precipitations that encourage plant growth year round. These factors also suggest that during the early-stage tending operations, weeds are serious threats to the seedlings. Ladrach (1992) noted that weed control was exceedingly important during the early stage of aforestation in the tropics, as effective suppression of weed competition could enhance survival of planted trees to as high as 90% or more. It also pointed out that because of adequate weed control, the gain in faster plantation tree growth can more than offset the costs of such operations (Schuler and Robison 2006).Surveys on plantation treesSince the establishment of the permanent experimental site in March, 1993, the initial survey of the tree growth information was completed in May of the same year. Subsequently, growths of trees were surveyed yearly during the early period. The frequency changed to once every 2 years since 1996 and the survey items included tree growth, diameter at breast-height (DBH) and height of trees in each block. In a later stage, addition items of individual tree growth data on forking height, forking habit and crown width were also included. Forking of plantation trees refer to the tree form as to the presence of bifurcation or multiple axes or branches as large as the principal axis above DBH.Comparative analyses of the growths of plantation treesInterspecies comparison of tree height and DBH were undertaken using a software package of SAS. Based on different time of surveys, the height and DBH of the trees were plotted against tree age in a polynomial regression analysis in order to establish a model for predicting the early growth performance of different species.

Analysis of Carbon Sequestration and Carbon Dioxide Reduction by Post and Beam Wooden Construction Buildings in Taiwan

The objective of this study was to evaluate the CO2 emission and carbon sequestration under the post and beam (PNB) wooden construction buildings in Taiwan. A total of 53 PNB wooden construction buildings were selected for calculating the CO2 emission, which generated from construction materials’ energy consumption. The results indicated that the usage of wood materials in per unit construction area was 0.2090 m3/m2; the CO2 emission in per unit construction area were 47.47 kg/m2. By comparing the wooden construction to reinforced concrete (RC) and steel prefabricated (S) construction, the CO2 emission reduction of the wooden construction can reach 387.71 kg/m2 and 338.55 kg/m2, respectively. The results clearly proved the PNB wooden construction buildings have significances in CO2 reduction and carbon sequestration.

Rhododendron farrerae Tate ex Sweet (Ericaceae), a Reconfirmed Species in Taiwan

Rhododendron farrerae Tate ex Sweet was first recorded in Taiwan by Kawakami in 1910. Since then, this species has been grouped with R. tashiroi Maxim. due to insufficient reports and specimens, and was eliminated from Flora of Taiwan in 1998. By examining all the specimens preserved in Taiwan herbaria and documents, we confirm that the native population of R. farrerae is actually distributed in southern Taiwan, ranging from Peitawushan to Tajen Township, in the southern part of the Central Mountain Range. The diagnostic character distinguishing R. farrerae from R. tashiroi and R. mariesii Hemsl. & E. H. Wils. is that R. tashiroi and R. mariesii bear 2-3 flowers from each bud at anthesis; in contrast, R. farrerae bears only one flower during the flowering period. We provide in this paper a detailed taxonomic treatment, morphological description, distribution map, line drawing, and a comparison table of these three species of Taiwan, together with photographs.

Rhododendron farrerae Evergreen shrubs, 3-5 m tall, many branches, slightly horizontal, 2-4 layers. Young branchlets with shining brown-pilose or strigose hairs, and glabrous with age; winter buds brown-villous. Leaves crowded at ends of branches, opposite or 3 verticillate, coriaceous; blades elliptic-ovate, 2-4.5 cm long, 1-2 cm wide, the apex acute to acuminate and terminating into a gland or an awn, cuneate at the base, the margins entire, young leaf ciliate; mid-vein concave on the surface and promote at the lower surface, upper surface glabrous, lower surface with reticulate nervulets, glabrous except sparsely hirsute on midrib; young leaves clothed with brown pilose or strigose, glaucenscent; petiole 3-5 mm long, pilose, grooved on upper surface. Flower-bud terminal, single, scales orbicular, ovate, ciliate and densely brown pilose on the middle of outside; flower terminal, solitary, bloom and sprout at the same time; pedicels densely brown pilose, 10-12 mm long at fruiting; calyx pilose; corolla pale rose-purple, widely funnel-shaped, 2-2.5 cm long and 3-3.5 cm in diam., corolla lobe oblanceolate to obovate, with a line-like spot at the upper three corolla-lobe; stamens 10, filaments flattened, glabrous, irregular, shorter than corolla; anthers oblong, porus dehiscence, introrse; ovary ovate, densely clothed with pilose; style 2-2.5 cm long, equal or slightly longer than corolla, glabrous; stigma capitates, slightly lobed. Capsules narrowly ovoid, ovate, 8-10 mm long, 5-6 mm wide, clothed with appressed brown hairs. Seed elliptic to spindled, ca. 1.5 mm long, 0.5 mm wide, acute to acuminate on both sides. We gratefully thank Dr. Goro Kokubugata, Curator of theTsukuba Botancial Garden, for providing specimens andphotos of Rhododendron tashiroi and Y. P. Liu for R. mariesii.We also greatly appreciate C. K. Fu for providing the line drawing. 日本學者Kawakamii 早在1910年記錄丁香杜鵑 (Rhododendron farrerae) 分布於臺灣。此段期間，由於缺乏足夠文獻與標本，本植物一直認定為大武杜鵑 (R. tashiroi) 並於1998年從臺灣植物誌刪除。經查閱貯存之標本與資料，可以確認丁香杜鵑確實分布於臺灣南部中央山脈南端，從北大武山至台東縣達仁鄉。本種與大武杜鵑及守城滿山紅最主要的區別在於本種花頂生於枝條且僅1 朵花，大武杜鵑及守城滿山紅則2-3 朵花叢生於枝條。本文提供丁香杜鵑詳細的分類處理、形態描述、分布圖、手繪圖、照片及3 種近似種形態比較表，以供分類參考。

Contrasting phylogeographical patterns of two closely related species, Machilus thunbergii and Machilus kusanoi (Lauraceae), in Taiwan

Aim: The purpose of this paper was to study the patterns of genetic variation, demographic history, haplotype relationships and potential location of diversity centres of two closely related species, Machilus thunbergii and Machilus kusanoi. Location: The phylogeography of M. thunbergii and M. kusanoi was examined by sampling 110 and 106 individuals from 25 and 16 sampling sited, respectively, across their distributional range in Taiwan. Machilus thunbergii is distributed on the Asian mainland, South Korea, southern Japan, the Ryukyus, Taiwan and the Philippines, whereas M. kusanoi is endemic to Taiwan. These two species are closely related, and both are widely distributed in Taiwan but occupy different altitudinal zones and habitates. Results:Extremely low levels of genetic differentiation were found for both species. This result suggested that these two species probably survived in multiple relict refugia with different population sizes throughout the island during low temperature periods of the Pleistocene. In addition, nested clade analysis (NCA) of cpDNA haplotypes indicated that restricted gene flow with isolation-by-distance characterized the recolonization after the Pleistocene by Tashueshan and Shiouhluan populations of M. thunbergii in the north-central area west of the Central Mountain Range (CMR). In contrast, NCA analysis indicated that a major diversity centre on the southern tip of the island (Kending population) and contiguous range expansion characterized the recolonization by M. kusanoi of northern areas along the east side of the CMR. The major diversity centres found for the two species examined were further supported by the results of the mean Fst for individual populations in the comparison with other populations, and of the contribution of the divergence component to the total diversity. Main conclusions: This research supports the multiple relict refugia hypothesis for both species investigated. Populations of M. thunbergii at Shiouhluan and Tashueshan in the north-central area west of the CMR represent a diversity centre currently expanding its size. A diversity centre at the southern-edge population of M. kusanoi, and a contiguous range expansion from Kending, were found. These results indicate that the M. thunbergii populations at Tashueshan and Shiouhluan and the M. kusanoi population at Kending, and even Soukar, are evolutionarily significant units for conservation programmes.

The range-wide variation of M. thunbergii and M. kusanoi in Taiwan was studied using chloroplast DNA(cpDNA) variations. A haplotype network was constructed with the computer program TCS. Nested clade analysis was conducted with the computer program GeoDIs, and various parameters of genetic diversity were calculated and neutrality tested by the computer program DnASP. Population differentiation was estimated using the programs ARLEQUIN and HAPSTEP. The contribution of the populations to gene diversity and to alletic richness was calculated using the software CONTRIB. The level of divergence for each population from the remaining populations was calculated as the mean value of pairwise Fst for each population against the rest of the populations.plant materials and DNA purificationA total of 110 and 106 individuals were randomly sampled from 25 and 16 populations in Taiwan, encompassing the distributional range of M. thunbergii and M. kusanoi, respectively. Four individuals of M. thunbergii from Okinawa (the Ryukyus) were also collected. The population code, sample size, longitude and latitude for each population within Taiwan are shown in Table 1; collection sites are depicted in Fig. 1. Total DNA was extracted from ground leaf powder according to a modified cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) procedure (Doyle & Doyle, 1987), described in detail by Hwang et al. (2001). DNA was precipitated with ethanol, and after washing with 70% ethanol was dissolved in 200ul TE buffer (pH 8.0) and stored at -20℃. The DNA concentration was determined for each sample using GeneQuant II RNA/DNA Calculator (Amershan Biosciences, Taipei, Taiwan)

Leaf Breakdown in a Subtropical Stream Riffle and Its Association with Macroinvertebrates

Leaf breakdown in a subtropical stream riffle and its association with macroinvertebrates. Zoological Studies 46(5): 609-621. The relationships between the quality of leaves of 3 trees (Machilus thunbergii, Schefflera octophylla, and Ficus erecta) and the assemblages of macroinvertebrates were studied at a riffle section of a 3rd-order subtropical forest stream in northern Taiwan. Macroinvertebrate taxon richness and density that colonized bags of leaves of the 3 tree species did not significantly differ. Macroinvertebrate assemblages were dominated by collectors, such as non-Tanypondinae Chironomidae, Prosimulium spp., and Baetis spp., which constituted > 79% of the total fauna. Results of a principal component analysis (PCA) showed that the macroinvertebrate assemblages were associated with the incubation time of the litter bags in the stream and the fine particulate organic matter (FPOM) trapped by the leaf bags, but not with the variables of leaf litter quality. Shredders, predominantly small nemourids, accounted for only 5.7%, 7.1% and 10.8% of the total macroinvertebrate assemblages on M. thunbergii, S. octophylla, and F. erecta, respectively, suggesting that macroinvertebrates played only a minor role in leaf litter breakdown in this subtropical 3rd-order stream. However, the density of shredders on F. erecta, as a function of the weight of the leaf litter remaining, was significantly higher than that of M. thunbergii, possibly because of the preference of shredders for high-quality food resources. In a comparison with the temperate zone systems, the dominant taxa of shredders that colonized the leaf litter were similar, but their relative abundances were much less in this subtropical forest stream riffle.

Anti-inflammatory Activity of Lindera erythrocarpa Fruits

In this study, in vitro and in vivo anti-inflammatory activities of fruits from Lindera erythrocarpa Makino were evaluated. The ethyl acetate soluble fraction derived from the ethanol extract of L. erythrocarpa fruits inhibited significantly nitric oxide (NO) production in lipopolysaccharide (LPS) induced NO in the murine macrophage cell line (RAW264.7) assay, the EC50 being16.35μg/mL. Four compounds, including lucidone (1), cis/trans-methylludicone (2), methyl linderone (3) and linderone (4) were identified from the active fraction based on the bioactivity-guided fractionation procedure. Of these lucidone possessed the strongest NO inhibitory activity with an EC50 value of 4.22μg/mL. Furthermore, results from the protein expression assay demonstrated that lucidone suppressed iNOS and COX-2 protein expression in a dose-dependent manner. Lucidon also provided antiinflammatory activity in the croton oil-induced ear edema assay. When it was applied topically at a dosage of 0.5 and 1 mg per ear, the percent edema reduction on treated mice was 44％ and 25％, respectively. The results obtained in this study indicated that lucidone has a good potential to be developed as an antiinflammation agent.

Characterization of Cucumber mosaic cucumovirus associated with banana mosaic disease by combined approaches

12 Cucumber mosaic virus (CMV) isolates associated with banana mosaic disease (BMD) in Taiwan were collected and characterized. From the symptoms induced on banana by these CMV isolates, three symptom types were grouped. Members within each banana symptom type also induced similar symptoms on N. glutinosa. It suggested that members within each banana symptom type do share similar common biological prosperities in inducing symptoms on banana and N. glutinosa. Double stranded RNA analysis revealed that the differential symptoms between groups are not related to the presence of satellite RNA. On the contrary, although cowpea is good hosts in CMV grouping based on the ability of CMV in cowpea systemic infection, the grouping is irrelevant in banana symptom inducing. Sequence analysis revealed that the systemic infection of CMV in cowpea reflected in their CP sequence. Phylogenetic analysis also revealed that CMV associated with BMD did not cluster together and were randomly assigned into distinctive CMV subgroup. It indicated several distinctive CMV strains all have the ability to infect banana which will complicate the disease managements. Interestingly, phylogenetic analysis using 89 CMV reported around the world reveled that in contrast to the currently known CMV subgroup IA , IB and II, our collected CMV form a new subgroup within subgroup I, and two new distinctive CMV subgroups within subgroup I were also resolved. Our analysis also pointing out that subgroup IB of CMV is actually phylogeneticlly unresolved and grouping of CMV may need to be further improved.

Samples collection and isolation of virusThe diseased banana leaves with differential symptoms were collected from southern Taiwan. These samples were checked by ELISA using antibody against CMV before isolation (35). The CMV were isolated from infected plants by rubbing the sap extracted from the infected plant to Chenopodium amaranticolor, followed by three times of consecutive single local-lesion isolations, and then maintained and propagated in N. glutinosa. The CMV were transmitted from N. glutinosa to healthy banana plantlets (about 15 cm in height) by cotton aphid (Aphis gossypii ). The aphids were pre-starvation for 2 hr in petri dishes, and then fed on CMV infected N. glutinosa leaves. These aphids were allowed acquisition access for 30 sec~1 min, and then were transferred to banana leaves for overnight. The bananas were then sprayed with imidacloprid insectcide.RNA extractionTotal RNA were extracted by Trizol® reagent (Invitrogen, Life technologies, Carlsbad, CA, USA) following the manufacturer’s instructions, and dissolved in 20 μl DEPC treated water after briefly air dry.Amplification of CMV CP gene by RT-PCRThe RT-PCR reaction were essential the same as described (19). Nucleic acids extracted from CMV infected plants were used as template for cDNA synthesis. First strand cDNA synthesis was initiated with primer CP-CMV RE (5’- GCT GGA TGG ACA ACC CGT TC -3’, complementary to nucleotide positions 2011- 2030 of CMV RNA3) by using M-MLV reverse transcriptase (Promega, Madison, WI, USA). Synthesized cDNAs were used as a template DNA, and the primer pair CP-CMV RE and CP-CMV (a degenerated primer corresponding to nucleotide positions 1153-1172; 5’-CTT TYT CAT GGA TGC TTC TC-3’, Y =A or T) with Taq (Promega) polymerase were used in PCR for 35 cycles. Cycling conditions were: one cycle of 95℃ for 5 min; 35 cycles of 94℃ for 1 min, 55℃ for 30 sec, 72℃ for 1 min; one cycle of 72℃ for 10 min.Double stranded (ds) RNA extraction and analysisTotal RNA were extracted from 1g of infected bananas and LiCl were added to final concentration of 2.1 M, and kept at 4oC overnight. The supernatant were collected after centrifuge at 12000 g for 15 minutes. 2.5 Volume of ethanol was added and centrifuge at 12000 g for 15 minutes to precipitate the dsRNA. The pellets were dissolved in 30 μl DEPC water. To avoid single stranded RNA contamination, 2 μl of sodium chloride (5 M) and 0.5 μl RNaseA (20 μg/ml) were added, and incubated at 37oC for 30 min. Then 3.6 μl of SDS (10%) were added and incubated at 37oC for 15 minutes. The solution were extracted once with equal volume of phenol/chloroform/isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1), and transfer the aqueous phase to a clean mircocentrifuge tube. The residual RNA were precipitated by adding 2.5 volume of ethanol and 1/10 volume of sodium acetate (3 M). The pellets were dissolved in 15 μl DEPC water. The dsRNA were separated on 1% TAE agarose gel.Amplification of CARNA 5 by RT-PCRThe primer, CMV-SAT-LRE (5’- GCT GGA TGG ACA ACC CGT TCG GG T CCT G- 3’), was designed with 8 nucleotides complementary sequences to the most 3’ termini of all published CMV satellite RNAs and followed by CP-CMV-RE sequence at its 5’ region. The CMV-SAT-LRE was used for first strand cDNA synthesis. The CMV-SAT-LFR (5’- CTT TTT CAT GGA TGC TTC TCG TTT TGT TTG -3’) was designed with 10 identical sequences to all published 5’ satellite RNAs and followed by CP-CMV sequences at 5’ region. The CMV-SAT-LFR was used for second strand cDNAs synthesis. The extracted dsRNA (from isolate 22 infected N. glutinosa) were used as template to synthesize cDNA. The cDNAs were synthesized as described. Synthesized cDNAs were used as a template DNA, and the primers CP-CMV RE, CP-CMV were used for PCR amplification with Taq (Promega) polymerase. The PCR cycling conditions were: one cycle of 95℃ for 5 min; 35 cycles of 95℃ 30 sec, 50℃ for 30 sec and 72℃ 20 sec; and one cycle of 72℃ for 10min.Cloning and sequencingThe amplified fragments were cloned into pGEM®-T easy (Promega) by incubating with T4 DNA ligase (Promega) overnight at 4℃, then transformed into Escherichia coli (Top 10). Nucleotide sequences of the cloned cDNAs were determined by use of ABI Prism DNA sequencer 310 or 377 (Applied Biosystems, Foster city, CA)Phylogenetic analysisMultiple sequences alignment were performed by CLUSTAL X (1.83) (31). Phylogenetic analyses were inferred by maximum parsimony (MP) and neighbor joining (NJ) methods. MP and NJ was used by PAUP* 4.0b 10 (31). In MP analysis, we conducted heuristic searches with 1000 random addition replicases, and tree bisection-reconnection branch swapping; and each replicate 10 trees were saved. An HKY85 nucleotide substitution model was analyzed in NJ analysis. Both of NJ and MP analysis branch support were estimated with 1000 replicated bootstrap analyses.
Grouping of CMV by symptoms on differential host
Abbreviations of CMV isolates, GenBank accession numbers, host and geographic origin
Grouping of CMV by symptoms on differential host
Abbreviations of CMV isolates, GenBank accession numbers, host and geographic origin

Symptoms induced by CMV strains on bananas can be grouped into three major types. Type I induced severe green mosaic with deformed leaves (I-d) or slender leaves (I-s), type II induced yellow mosaic with necrosis (II), and type III induced severe green mosaic without deformed leaves (III).

Symptoms induced by CMV strains on N. glutinosa can be grouped into three major types: Isolates within group A induced severe green mosaic with parkling and leaf distortion (A) or fern leaf (A-f), group B induced severe green mosaic with leaf necrosis (B), and group C induced mild mottling without leaf distortion (C).

Symptoms induced by CMV strains on cowpea can be grouped into 2 major groups. Group L (L) induced local lesion on inoculated leaves and will not systematically infect cowpea, and group S (S) can systematically infect cowpea.

Samples collection and isolation of virusThe diseased banana leaves with differential symptoms were collected from southern Taiwan. These samples were checked by ELISA using antibody against CMV before isolation (35). The CMV were isolated from infected plants by rubbing the sap extracted from the infected plant to Chenopodium amaranticolor, followed by three times of consecutive single local-lesion isolations, and then maintained and propagated in N. glutinosa. The CMV were transmitted from N. glutinosa to healthy banana plantlets (about 15 cm in height) by cotton aphid (Aphis gossypii ). The aphids were pre-starvation for 2 hr in petri dishes, and then fed on CMV infected N. glutinosa leaves. These aphids were allowed acquisition access for 30 sec~1 min, and then were transferred to banana leaves for overnight. The pellets were dissolved in 30 μl DEPC water. To avoid single stranded RNA contamination, 2 μl of sodium chloride (5 M) and 0.5 μl RNaseA (20 μg/ml) were added, and incubated at 37oC for 30 min. Then 3.6 μl of SDS (10%) were added and incubated at 37oC for 15 minutes. The solution were extracted once with equal volume of phenol/chloroform/isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1), and transfer the aqueous phase to a clean mircocentrifuge tube. The residual RNA were precipitated by adding 2.5 volume of ethanol and 1/10 volume of sodium acetate (3 M). The pellets were dissolved in 15 μl DEPC water. The CMV-SAT-LRE was used for first strand cDNA synthesis. The CMV-SAT-LFR (5’- CTT TTT CAT GGA TGC TTC TCG TTT TGT TTG -3’) was designed with 10 identical sequences to all published 5’ satellite RNAs and followed by CP-CMV sequences at 5’ region. The CMV-SAT-LFR was used for second strand cDNAs synthesis. The extracted dsRNA (from isolate 22 infected N. glutinosa) were used as template to synthesize cDNA. The cDNAs were synthesized as described. Synthesized cDNAs were used as a template DNA, and the primers CP-CMV RE, CP-CMV were used for PCR amplification with Taq (Promega) polymerase. Nucleotide sequences of the cloned cDNAs were determined by use of ABI Prism DNA sequencer 310 or 377 (Applied Biosystems, Foster city, CA)Phylogenetic analysisMultiple sequences alignment were performed by CLUSTAL X (1.83) (31). Phylogenetic analyses were inferred by maximum parsimony (MP) and neighbor joining (NJ) methods. MP and NJ was used by PAUP* 4.0b 10 (31). Nortriterpene lactones from the fruits of Schisandra arisanensis

Fractionation of an acetone extract from the fruits of Schisandra arisanensis afforded five new nortriterpene lactones, compounds 1-5, together with four known compounds, schindilactones D and E (6 and 7) and preschisanartanins A and B (8 and 9). Compound 1, a wuweiziartane-type nortriterpenoid, possesses a new type of fused ring system with a γ-lactone ring between C-15 and C-17. Compounds 2, 6, and 7 may be categorized as schisanartane-type nortriterpenoids and compounds 3-5, 8, and 9 as preschisanartane-type nortriterpenoids. The structures of the new compounds were elucidated by 1D and 2D NMR spectroscopic data interpretation. The structure and relative configuration of 3 were supported by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The antiviral activity against HSV-1 and inhibitory effects on superoxide anion generation and elastase release by human neutrophils in response to FMLP/CB of compounds 1-9 were evaluated.

General Experimental Procedures Meting points were recorded on a Bu¨chi B540 melting point apparatus. Optical rotations were recorded on a JASCO DIP-1000 polarimeter. IR spectra were taken on a HORIBA FT-720 spectrophotometer. The 1H and 13C NMR spectra as well as 2D NMR spectra (COSY, HMQC, HMBC, and NOESY) were recorded in CDCl3 on a Bruker AVX NMR spectrometer operating at 400 MHz for 1H and 100 MHz for 13C using the CDCl3 solvent peak as internal standard (δΗ 7.265, δC 77.0 ppm). Low-resolution EIMS were recorded on a VG Quattro 5022 mass spectrometer. HRESIMS were measured on a JEOL HX 110 mass spectrometer. LiChrospher Si 60 (5 μm, 250-10, Merck) and LiChrospher 100 RP- 18e (5 μm, 250-10, Merck) were used for NP-HPLC and RP-HPLC (Hitachi, L-6250; flow rate 2 mL/min, UV detection at 254 nm), respectively. Plant Material The fruits of Schisandra arisanensis were collected in Nan-Tou County, Taiwan, in March 2008. The plant material was identified by one of the authors (C.T.C.). A voucher specimen (code no. TP 98-1) has been deposited at the School of Pharmacy, National Taiwan University, Taipei, Taiwan. Extraction and Isolation The freeze-dried fruits (1.38 kg) of S. arisanensis were ground and extracted three times with acetone at room temperature and then concentrated under reduced pressure to afford a crude extract (300 g). This crude extract was partitioned between EtOAc and H2O (1:1) to obtain an EtOAc-soluble layer. After evaporating the organic solvent, the EtOAc residue (61 g) was partitioned between n-hexane-MeOH-H2O (4:3:1) to afford a MeOH-H2O extract. The MeOH-H2O extract (35 g) was subjected to passage over a Si gel flash column (n-hexane-EtOAc, 40:1 to 0:1) to furnish fractions A-H. Fraction H (2.9 g) was separated on a Sephadex LH-20 column eluted with MeOH to afford fraction H1 (1.4 g), which was further chromatographed on Si gel (n-hexane-CH2Cl2-MeOH, 100:20:1 to 0:10: 1) to furnish subfractions H1D-H1G. Subfraction H1D was subjected to RP-HPLC (MeOH-H2O, 5:3) and further purified by NP-HPLC (nhexane-EtOAc, 21:19) to give 5 (10.3 mg) and 9 (29.3 mg). Subfraction H1E was subjected to RP-HPLC (MeOH-H2O, 11:9) to afford 8 (22.6 mg) and another subfraction, H1E3. Subfraction H1E3 was separated by NP-HPLC (n-hexane-CH2Cl2-MeOH, 75:425:7) to yield 1 (21.3 mg) and 3 (16.4 mg). Separation of subfraction H1F by RP-HPLC (MeOH-H2O, 1:1) yielded 7 (65.4 mg)15 and two subfractions, H1F1 and H1F2. Subfraction H1F1 was purified by normal-phase HPLC (n-hexane-CH2Cl2-MeOH, 12:68:1) to obtain 6 (15.6 mg). Fraction H1F2 was separated by NP-HPLC (n-hexane-CH2Cl2- MeOH, 48:32:1) and further purified by RP-HPLC (MeCN-H2O, 2:3) to produce 4 (7.9 mg). Subfraction H1G was purified by RP-HPLC (MeOH-H2O, 17:23) and again purified by RP-HPLC (MeCN-H2O, 2:3) to furnish 2 (9.9 mg).

Dormancy and germination in seeds of the medical Asian tree species Phellodendron amurense var. wilsonii (Rutaceae)

The effects of alternating temperatures, cold stratification and gibberellic acid (GA3) on seed germination of Phellodendron amurense var. wilsonii were investigated. Incubation at 35/10℃ or stratification at 4℃prior to incubation of freshly harvested seeds significantly increased germination percentage from less than 5% to greater than 87%. Germination percentage was increased only slightly in intact seeds treated with up to 2000 ppm GA3. However, partial removal of the seed coat by mechanical scarfication plus GA3 resulted in a drastic increase in both germination percentage and rate. Storage in liquid nitrogen for one and seven months enhanced germination percentage and the beneficial action was due to cracking of the seed coat. Embryos excised from their enclosing tissues and embryos surrounded by endosperm germinated to a much higher percentage than intact seeds, indicating that the water-permeable seed coat plays a mechanical role in preventing radicle protrusion in nontreated intact seeds. Improved germination responses were obtained when the physiological dormant seeds of P. amurense var. wilsonii were pre-treated for 3 months of cold stratification, whilst GA3 treatments also promoted their germination.

seed collection and preparationMature black fruits of P. amurense var. wilsonii were harvested from Taiping Mountain (24°30’N, 121°29’E), Ilan County, northeastern Taiwan, at an elevation of 1600 m in September 2004. The fruits are very oily and aromatic. Fruits harvested from natural forests or plantations should be rapidly transported to the handling place to avoid decreases in viability of the seedlots due to high temperatures in the transport-containers (Chien personal observation). Each fruit contains 3~6 seeds (average 5), but some of them are empty. Fruits were macerated by hand in water, and the empty seeds were floated off and discarded. The clean sunken seeds were used for subsequent treatments. The black seed (4~6 mm long and 2~3 mm wide) consists of the seed coat and a large dicotyledonous embryo surrounded by a small amount endosperm (figure 1). The spatulate embryo (Martin, 1946) is fully developed with a mean (± SE) embryo length : seed length ratio of 0.83 ± 0.02 (n = 15), and it does not grow within the seed before the radicle emerges. Moisture content (MC) of seeds was determined with three replicates of 20 seeds and calculated on a fresh-weight basis after oven drying for 17 hours at 103°C (ISTA, 1999).ImbibitionEach of 20 non-scarified and scarified (cut at the point away from embryonic axis) seeds were weighed individually to the nearest 0.1 mg at time 0 and after incubation at ambient laboratory temperature (~24°C) for 24 hours on Whatman no. 1 filter paper in Petri dishes moistened with distilled water. Percentage water uptake was calculated as follows:%Ws = [(Wi ─ Wd)/Wd] × 100,where Ws = increase in seed mass, Wi = seed mass after imbibition and Wd = initial seed mass (Hidayati et al., 2000).Embryos were excised from each of 30 imbibed seeds, and then three replications of 10 embryos were weighed to nearest 0.1 mg before and after drying them in an oven at 50°C for 24 hours. Percentage embryo moisture content was calculated from these data as described above for seeds.Effect of stratification on germinationFor warm followed by cold stratification, freshly harvested seeds were placed in polyethylene bags (0.04 mm in thickness) with moist sphagnum and sealed, and then they were warm-stratified for 2, 4, 6 and 8 weeks at an alternating temperature regime of 30/20°C with 12 hours of fluorescent light (80-100 μMol m-2 s-1; hereafter light) at the higher temperature. These warm-stratified seeds were then given 4, 8, 12, 16 or 20 weeks of cold moist stratification at 4°C. A cold stratification treatment without a warm treatment was also carried out on fresh seeds in moist sphagnum for 4, 8, 12, 16 and 20 weeks prior to the seeds being subjected to germination tests. Each stratification treatment consisted of three replications of 100 seeds each. Water content of the sphagnum in both warm and cold stratification treatments was about 400% of its dry mass.Germination tests using fresh seeds were performed in germination chambers at constant 25°C and at 35/10, 30/20 and 25/15°C (12/12 hours) in light during the higher temperature. Germination tests of warm- followed by cold-stratified seeds or of cold-stratified seeds only were performed at 30/20°C, i.e. same temperature as that for warm stratification. Sphagnum served as the germination medium. Germination, i.e. radicle at least 5 mm long, was recorded weekly. Results were expressed as percentage germination after 12 weeks and as the mean germination time (MGT) in days. MGT is a measure of the rate (speed) of germination and of the sharpness of the germination peak:MGT = (Σniti)/Gt,where ni = number of seeds germinated in ti days from the beginning of the test and Gt = total number of germinated seeds at the end of the test (Naylor, 1981).Effect of GA3 on germinationFresh, intact seeds were treated with 0 (water control) and solutions of 100, 500, 1000 and 2000 ppm GA3 (as K-GA3) (95% purity, Sigma, St. Louis, MO, USA) for 24 hours at room temperature prior to germination. Each treatment consisted of three replicates of 100 seeds. Without washing them in water, the treated seeds were then mixed with moist sphagnum and incubated at constant 25°C and at 30/20 and 25/15°C in light. Number of germinated seeds was recorded weekly for 12 weeks. Results are expressed as percentage germination and as MGT in days.Due to the ineffectiveness of GA3 on intact seeds, the seed coat of seeds stored dry at 4 °C for seven months was cut at a point away from the embryonic axis to remove a small piece of the coat, and then the seeds were treated with the same concentrations of GA3 as described above. Without washing them in water, the treated seeds were mixed with moist sphagnum and incubated at 30/20 °C. Seeds were monitored for germination at weekly intervals for four weeks. Results are expressed as percentage germination and as MGT in days.Effect of seed storage at 4°C and at subzero temperatures on germinationSeeds were air-dried to a moisture content of 8.8% and then sealed in aluminium foil packets for storage at 4, -80 and -196°C (liquid nitrogen, LN). Dried seeds in the aluminium foil packets were immersed directly into LN for storage. Each storage treatment consisted of three replications of 50 seeds each. At intervals of 1, 3 and 7 months, seeds were removed from storage and tested for germination. Seeds stored in LN were first placed at -20°C for at least four hours and then at 4°C for several hours prior to incubation. Germination tests were performed at 30/20°C in light, and number of seeds germinated was monitored at weekly intervals for six weeks. Results are expressed as percentage germination.Effect of seed tissues cnclosing the embryo on radicle growth/emergenceSeeds that had been stored at 4, -80 and -196°C for seven months were sterilized for one minute in 70% ethanol followed by 10 minutes in 5% sodium hypochloride, and then they were rinsed five times with sterile distilled water. Different seed tissues were removed to assess their role in germination, i.e. the seed coat only was removed or both seed coat and endosperm were removed. The treated tissues were then placed in Petri dishes containing 20 mL of solidified MS basal medium (Murashige and Skoog, 1962) and incubated at 25°C for the germination test. Each treatment consisted of 20 seeds, i.e. each of four Petri dishes containing five seeds. Germination was monitored every two days for 12 days.statistical analysisRadical protrusion data were transformed to percentages based on number of treated seeds. Germination (mean ± SE) was calculated, and means were compared by analysis of variance (ANOVA) and by least significant difference (LSD) at the 5% level of significance (SAS, 2004).

Dormancy and germination in seeds of the medical Asian tree species Phellodendron amurense var. wilsonii (Rutaceae)
Preparation of Composite Board Using Foil- and Plastic- Laminated Liquid Packaging Paperboard as Raw Materials

We investigated the properties of composite board formed using base sheets of aluminum foil- and polyethylene (PE) plastic-laminated liquid packaging paperboard (LP) as an alternative to recycling these items in wastepaper stream. Boards of different specific gravities ranging from 0.55 to 0.75 were made by pressing shredded LP blended with urea resin having resin content of 6% to 10% at 180℃. Subsequently, we also prepared mixed particleboard (wood (WD) particles and LP mixed), 3-layered particleboard (with LP as the middle layer; WD in the upper and lower layers), and wood particleboard all having resin content of 10% and various specific gravities. Static bending and internal bonding strengths and thickness swelling of the specimens were carried out to examine their properties. At the same specific gravity, the properties of LP particle- boards were affected by their resin content. The modulus of rupture (MOR), modulus of elasticity (MOE) and internal bond of the LP particleboards increased with increasing specific gravities of the boards at the same resin content, but thickness swelling of the LP particleboards showed a reversed trend. The average MOR of the LP particleboards approximated that of the mixed particleboards and was greater than those of the 3-layered particleboards and wood particleboards. Internal bond and thickness swelling of the LP particleboards were smaller than those of the other particleboards. Based on the above observations, we deemed that LP can be made into composite boards of adequate properties either alone or mixed with wood particles.

static bendingIn accordance with JIS A5908:2003 test methods. Specimens for the static bending test had dimensions of 5 cm width and 20 cm length, load was applied at the center of the 15 cm span (15 x of the board thickness). Loading rate during the static bending was 10 mm/min. In the internal bond test, specimens of 5 cm x 5 cm were glued to steel anvil and tensile loads parallel to the specimen surfaces was applied at a 2 mm/min rate, the maximum tensile loading at the point of delamination was determined for each test specimen.internal bondIn the internal bond test, specimens of 5 cm x 5 cm were glued to steel anvil and tensile loads parallel to the specimen surfaces was applied at a 2 mm/min rate, the maximum tensile loading at the point of delamination was determined for each test specimen.water absorption swellingIn the water absorption swelling test, specimens of 5 cm x 5 cm were placed horizontally in a bath of 25±1℃ water, with the top specimen surface held 3 cm below the surface of water for a period of 24 h. A micro- meter caliper was used to determine the thickness changes before and after water immersion and to calculate the thickness swelling.

static bendingIn accordance with JIS A5908:2003 test methods. 台灣與鄰近島嶼水芫花族群遺傳 多樣性之研究

水芫花為泛熱帶分布的海灘及岩岸第一線植物，在台灣與鄰近島嶼中見於恆春半島、小琉球、蘭嶼及綠島等地，屬半紅樹類植物。本研究以取自上述地區15個族群150株水芫花個體，應用簡單序列重覆分子指紋技術來分析台灣本島與鄰近島嶼水芫花族群遺傳結構及族群間親緣關係，計使用6個引子，得到95個多型性條帶。POPGENE分析的結果發現Nei’s族群基因歧異度（H）為0.3017，族群間之遺傳分化係數（Gst）為0.2816，基因流（Nm）為0.6378，顯示族群已具高度分化結構。由族群分子變方分析（AMOVA）結果，地區間之變方成分為7.83 %（p＜0.001），地區內族群間之變方成分是13.37 %（p＜0.001），族群內個體間的變方成分是78.79 %（p＜0.001），顯示不同島嶼與族群間已有分化趨勢，但主要遺傳變異係存於族群內個體間。歸群及主座標分析結果可分為三群，其中蘭嶼的族群為一群，恆春半島及綠島之族群組成另一群，小琉球之族群自成一群。水芫花族群間之地理距離與遺傳距離具正相關（r0.56，P0.02*），符合距離隔離模式，推測是自然散布之結果。綜言之，水芫花族群基因流傳並不暢通，不同島嶼間已有分化現象，推測為島嶼間區隔對族群間之遺傳分化產生較顯著影響。就所得族群遺傳訊息，建議宜採就地保育之措施。

植物材料針對台灣恆春半島（包括香蕉灣、鵝鸞鼻、風吹砂及九棚4個族群）、小琉球（龍蝦洞單一族群）、蘭嶼（八代灣、雙獅岩、郎島、核廢廠及野銀5個族群）及綠島（龜灣鼻、龜灣、紫坪、柴口及孔子岩5個族群）等4個地區，合計15個水芫花族群進行取樣，每族群內之取樣採取每隔10～20m隨機取一株，每一單株選取無病蟲害之葉子5-10片，並以透氣紙袋包裝後，再利用矽膠乾燥劑於室溫下脫水保存以供DNA之萃取。DNA萃取與ISSR的擴大反應參考Kobayashi等人（1998）的CTAB萃取法進行萃取，分離出的DNA加入0.1ml的TE Buffer保存。並利用分光光度計進行DNA濃度（ng/μl）之測量。參考Zietkiewicz等人（1994）的方法，PCR反應溶液總體積為25μl，其內容物濃度為Tris-HCl 10 mM（pH 9.0），KCl 50 mM，MgCl2 1.5 mM，Gelatin 0.1 %（w/v），Triton X-100 1 %（w/v），template DNA 20 ng，dNTPs 200 μM，Primer 0.2 μM，Taq po-lymerase 1 units（Protech Technology En-terprsse co. Ltd），於溫度循環器thermocycler（Applied Biosystems Geneamp PCR System 9700）進行PCR反應設定溫度循環程序，94℃，6分鐘（initial denaturing step）後，加上35次循環的：94℃，60秒DNA（denaturing），51.9℃-60.5℃，50秒，煉合溫度（annealing）依引子而定（表2），72℃，2分15秒（elongation），72℃，7分鐘（final elongatoin step）最後降溫至4℃（end）。電泳、染色與照相配製1.5 % Agarose，將完成擴大反應的DNA樣本添加追蹤染劑 [tracking dye （0.25 % bromophenol blue, 0.25 % xylene cyanol FF, 30 % glycerol in water）]與100bp DNA Ladder，然後以電壓150V進行電泳分析，約2-2.5 h。完成電泳的膠片以溴化乙錠（ethidium bromide）染色並置於UV燈上顯影觀察，且以Vilber Lourmat CN-100拍照作為記錄。統計分析1.記錄強度較強且清晰的DNA片段，有條帶出現者記錄為1，無條帶者記錄為0。利用NTSYS-pc ver. 2.0套裝軟體（Rohlf, 1993）以Simple Matching公式計算兩兩樣本間之相似度，建立相似度矩陣（Ssm）。Ssm=M/N；M=兩兩樣本相同條帶數；N=多型性條帶總數。2.將各族群之條帶記錄以POPGENE ver. 1.31套裝軟體計算族群間的遺傳資料，包含Nei’s基因歧異度（H）（Nei, 1973）。Ho =－Σpi（lnPi）；Pi指某個DNA片段出現的頻度（frequency）。如假設各族群近親交配指數（Fis）為0，則可計算族群間遺傳分化係數Gst（coefficient of gene differentiation），再利用Gst估算基因流傳值Nm（Nm=0.25×（1-Gst）/Gst）。3.進行AMOVA（Analysis of Molecular Variance）分析，以Excoffer et al.（1992）所發表兩兩族群的距離公式求得距離矩陣D。D=N（1-Ssm）N（1-M/N）；M=兩兩樣本相同條帶數；N=多型性條帶總數。將距離矩陣以AMOVA ver. l.55程式（Excoffer et al., 1992）進行分析，求得地區間、地區內、族群間、族群內個體間之變方成份值及各變方成份所佔總變方成份的百分比，並用9999次之隨機重排列檢定（random permutation test），測驗各變方成分之顯著性，並繪製成不同層級之分析歸納表。4.將AMOVA計算得之族群間遺傳距離 （Φst）矩陣，以NTSYS之配對不加權算數平均值（UPGMA）的方法進行歸群分析（Cluster analysis）建立樹枝圖。同時透過主座標分析（principal coordinates analysis, PCoA）來繪製樣本分布圖，以及運用Mantel test（Mantel, 1967）來檢測遺傳距離矩陣（Φst）與相對地理矩陣間的相關性（r）。此外UPGMA歸群分析與原距離矩陣間的吻合程度以協表相關係數（r）來估計，且同樣運用Mantel Z統計進行。

表1　採樣地區與樣本數

植物材料針對台灣恆春半島（包括香蕉灣、鵝鸞鼻、風吹砂及九棚4個族群）、小琉球（龍蝦洞單一族群）、蘭嶼（八代灣、雙獅岩、郎島、核廢廠及野銀5個族群）及綠島（龜灣鼻、龜灣、紫坪、柴口及孔子岩5個族群）等4個地區，合計15個水芫花族群進行取樣，每族群內之取樣採取每隔10～20m隨機取一株，每一單株選取無病蟲害之葉子5-10片，並以透氣紙袋包裝後，再利用矽膠乾燥劑於室溫下脫水保存以供DNA之萃取。DNA萃取與ISSR的擴大反應參考Kobayashi等人（1998）的CTAB萃取法進行萃取，分離出的DNA加入0.1ml的TE Buffer保存。並利用分光光度計進行DNA濃度（ng/μl）之測量。參考Zietkiewicz等人（1994）的方法，PCR反應溶液總體積為25μl，其內容物濃度為Tris-HCl 10 mM（pH 9.0），KCl 50 mM，MgCl2 1.5 mM，Gelatin 0.1 %（w/v），Triton X-100 1 %（w/v），template DNA 20 ng，dNTPs 200 μM，Primer 0.2 μM，Taq po-lymerase 1 units（Protech Technology En-terprsse co. Ltd），於溫度循環器thermocycler（Applied Biosystems Geneamp PCR System 9700）進行PCR反應設定溫度循環程序，94℃，6分鐘（initial denaturing step）後，加上35次循環的：94℃，60秒DNA（denaturing），51.9℃-60.5℃，50秒，煉合溫度（annealing）依引子而定（表2），72℃，2分15秒（elongation），72℃，7分鐘（final elongatoin step）最後降溫至4℃（end）。電泳、染色與照相配製1.5 % Agarose，將完成擴大反應的DNA樣本添加追蹤染劑 [tracking dye （0.25 % bromophenol blue, 0.25 % xylene cyanol FF, 30 % glycerol in water）]與100bp DNA Ladder，然後以電壓150V進行電泳分析，約2-2.5 h。完成電泳的膠片以溴化乙錠（ethidium bromide）染色並置於UV燈上顯影觀察，且以Vilber Lourmat CN-100拍照作為記錄。統計分析1.記錄強度較強且清晰的DNA片段，有條帶出現者記錄為1，無條帶者記錄為0。利用NTSYS-pc ver. 2.0套裝軟體（Rohlf, 1993）以Simple Matching公式計算兩兩樣本間之相似度，建立相似度矩陣（Ssm）。Ssm=M/N；M=兩兩樣本相同條帶數；N=多型性條帶總數。2.將各族群之條帶記錄以POPGENE ver. 1.31套裝軟體計算族群間的遺傳資料，包含Nei’s基因歧異度（H）（Nei, 1973）。Ho =－Σpi（lnPi）；Pi指某個DNA片段出現的頻度（frequency）。如假設各族群近親交配指數（Fis）為0，則可計算族群間遺傳分化係數Gst（coefficient of gene differentiation），再利用Gst估算基因流傳值Nm（Nm=0.25×（1-Gst）/Gst）。3.進行AMOVA（Analysis of Molecular Variance）分析，以Excoffer et al.（1992）所發表兩兩族群的距離公式求得距離矩陣D。D=N（1-Ssm）N（1-M/N）；M=兩兩樣本相同條帶數；N=多型性條帶總數。將距離矩陣以AMOVA ver. l.55程式（Excoffer et al., 1992）進行分析，求得地區間、地區內、族群間、族群內個體間之變方成份值及各變方成份所佔總變方成份的百分比，並用9999次之隨機重排列檢定（random permutation test），測驗各變方成分之顯著性，並繪製成不同層級之分析歸納表。4.將AMOVA計算得之族群間遺傳距離 （Φst）矩陣，以NTSYS之配對不加權算數平均值（UPGMA）的方法進行歸群分析（Cluster analysis）建立樹枝圖。同時透過主座標分析（principal coordinates analysis, PCoA）來繪製樣本分布圖，以及運用Mantel test（Mantel, 1967）來檢測遺傳距離矩陣（Φst）與相對地理矩陣間的相關性（r）。此外UPGMA歸群分析與原距離矩陣間的吻合程度以協表相關係數（r）來估計，且同樣運用Mantel Z統計進行。

台灣地區竹炭產品之消費價值與市場選擇行為研究

本研究採用消費價值及市場選擇行為理論，探討尚處於初期發展階段的台灣竹炭市場中，消費者對竹炭產品的接受度，影響消費者購買竹炭產品的主要因素與潛在消費者之特質，藉此瞭解竹炭在市場之發展潛力。以台灣地區家計單位為對象寄出問卷，問卷資料以因素分析、區別分析、單因子多變量變異數分析與卡方檢定進行分析。結果顯示影響購買竹炭行為的顯著因素共計有9項，依其重要性由高至低分別為：1. 創新態度、2. 低風險低價條件、3. 基本功能與環保訴求、4. 神奇與實用感、5. 骯髒與誇大感、6. 衝動與居家感、7. 綠色行動家、8. 次級群體、9. 口碑與促銷條件因素。此外透過人口統計變項、有無購買經驗與前述9項顯著的消費價值因素間的分析發現婚姻狀態、年齡、學歷、職業、家庭月所得與有無購買經驗在消費價值與態度上具有顯著的差異。
竹炭是以成熟竹材為原料藉由熱分解反應於低量氧氣狀態下所生產之產品
綠色消費意指消費者對具有符合環保概念綠色商品之消費態度，是影響綠色消費行為之重要因素。
在生產、使用或最終廢棄處裡的過程中，不會耗用過多的資源、材質可以回收、不需包裝或減量包裝、可重複使用、且可更新功能、有資源再生之可能、具節省能源原則所生產之產品。
係由Sheth, Newman andGross於1991年所提出，認為消費者在購買時會面臨三種選擇行為：買或不買、產品型式、及品牌選擇。而此些選擇行為係依據：功能性價值、社會性價值、情感性價值、嘗新性價值、條件性價值等五種消費價值所決定。
影響消費者對新產品採用的特性或因素，大致可分為知覺創新特性、消費者特性(個人態度、人格特質與人口統計變數)與情境因素(溝通情境及購買情境)等三大項目。

問卷設計將影響消費者購買行為的相關變數進行篩選，再將與消費價值有關的變數轉換為消費價值變數。問卷內容共計有9部份，除了第一、第八與第九部分是透過名目尺度衡量外，其餘第二到第七部份皆是利用利用李克特五點式量表進行衡量。第一部份為有無購買經驗，用來衡量受測者是否具有購買竹炭產品的經驗。第二部份為綠色消費態度，此部分的變數內容有9個問項來瞭解受測者的綠色消費態度。第三部份為功能性價值，內容有13個問項，以瞭解受測者對這些產品之功能性價值的重視程度。第四部份為社會性價值，內容有10個問項，來瞭解受測者受到這些參考群體的影響程度。第五部份為情感性價值，內容有7個問項，以瞭解受測者受到竹炭產品所帶來的情感價值之影響程度。第六部份為嘗新性價值，內容有5個問項，以瞭解受測者對竹炭產品的創新性為何。第七部份為條件性價值，內容有8個問項，以瞭解受測者在某些情境下願意接受竹炭產品的程度為何。第八部份為選擇行為，用來詢問受訪者是否會決定購買竹炭產品。第九部份為人口統計變數，用來描述潛在消費者之特徵。樣本數決定以家庭數為調查單位，抽樣架構是取自全國家庭資料庫，並利用居住地區作為分層標準，採行比例配置分層隨機抽樣法進行抽樣。根據內政部2003年資料，民國91年底全台的總家計戶數為6,925,019戶，依據公式求得需要256個樣本數。資料收集資料收集採郵寄問卷方式進行，問卷共寄發2000份，兩星期後，針對未回覆問卷再寄發第二次問卷，回收共計387份，經過刪除答題不完整的無效問卷之後，有效問卷為363份，問卷回收率為18.2%。資料分析利用SPSS 10.0版的統計軟體作為分析工具，首先將五項消費價值及綠色消費態度構面之變數進行因素分析 (factor analysis)，以瞭解這些構面內容背後所潛藏的概念，再利用萃取後各個因素分數作為自變數與選擇行為進行區別分析 (discriminate analysis)，以找出具有顯著影響的因素變數。再利用人口統計變數及有無購買經驗與選擇行為進行卡方分析 (chi-squared test)，以瞭解人口統計變數、消費者先前的購買狀態是否與消費者購買意願之間具有關聯性。最後，再透過單因子多變量變異數分析 (one-way MANOVA) 來瞭解人口統計變數、有無購買經驗與具顯著影響之因素間之關聯為何，以進一步瞭解人口統計變數及先前有無購買使用之經驗在消費價值或態度上是否有所差異。
The questionnaries were designed for the consumption values and market choices for bamboo charcoal products in Taiwan.
The questionnaries were designed for the consumption values and market choices for bamboo charcoal products in Taiwan.
是否曾經購買過竹炭相關產品
綠色消費態度─意指消費者對具有符合環保概念綠色商品之消費態度，是影響綠色消費行為的重要因素。
功能性價值─意指產品或品牌若具有某些功能上、效用上或實體上之屬性，透過這些屬性藉以滿足消費者對使用該產品之功能或效用要求之價值。
社會性價值─意指產品或品牌能在消費者與其他社會群體相結合時，提昇該產品效用之價值。消費者的購買行為有時是為取得社會群體的認同、符合社會規範，或是展現內在的形象。
情感性價值─意指產品或品牌具有激發改變消費者某些情緒或是情感狀態之效用或能力之價值。消費者之消費行為中許多非計畫性或衝動型之消費，經常是由情感性價值所影響的。
嘗新性價值─意指產品或品牌具有引發消費者好奇感，提供新奇感或滿足消費者對知識追求渴望之效用與價值。此項效用通常發生於對消費者較不熟悉或較為複雜之事物，促使消費者購買非為滿足功能性或其他功能需求之事物，如新商品或娛樂性商品等。
條件性價值─意指產品或品牌在某些環境與情境中，具有暫時提昇功能性或社會性價值之能力。條件性價值基本上是導因於短暫性的情境因素，改變消費者的消費行為，提昇產品之價值或效用，情境因素若消失，產品之價值或效用將隨之降低。
決定是否購買竹炭相關產品

問卷設計將影響消費者購買行為的相關變數進行篩選，再將與消費價值有關的變數轉換為消費價值變數。問卷內容共計有9部份，除了第一、第八與第九部分是透過名目尺度衡量外，其餘第二到第七部份皆是利用利用李克特五點式量表進行衡量。第一部份為有無購買經驗，用來衡量受測者是否具有購買竹炭產品的經驗。第二部份為綠色消費態度，此部分的變數內容有9個問項來瞭解受測者的綠色消費態度。第三部份為功能性價值，內容有13個問項，以瞭解受測者對這些產品之功能性價值的重視程度。第四部份為社會性價值，內容有10個問項，來瞭解受測者受到這些參考群體的影響程度。第五部份為情感性價值，內容有7個問項，以瞭解受測者受到竹炭產品所帶來的情感價值之影響程度。第六部份為嘗新性價值，內容有5個問項，以瞭解受測者對竹炭產品的創新性為何。第七部份為條件性價值，內容有8個問項，以瞭解受測者在某些情境下願意接受竹炭產品的程度為何。第八部份為選擇行為，用來詢問受訪者是否會決定購買竹炭產品。第九部份為人口統計變數，用來描述潛在消費者之特徵。樣本數決定以家庭數為調查單位，抽樣架構是取自全國家庭資料庫，並利用居住地區作為分層標準，採行比例配置分層隨機抽樣法進行抽樣。根據內政部2003年資料，民國91年底全台的總家計戶數為6,925,019戶，依據公式求得需要256個樣本數。資料收集資料收集採郵寄問卷方式進行，問卷共寄發2000份，兩星期後，針對未回覆問卷再寄發第二次問卷，回收共計387份，經過刪除答題不完整的無效問卷之後，有效問卷為363份，問卷回收率為18.2%。資料分析利用SPSS 10.0版的統計軟體作為分析工具，首先將五項消費價值及綠色消費態度構面之變數進行因素分析 (factor analysis)，以瞭解這些構面內容背後所潛藏的概念，再利用萃取後各個因素分數作為自變數與選擇行為進行區別分析 (discriminate analysis)，以找出具有顯著影響的因素變數。再利用人口統計變數及有無購買經驗與選擇行為進行卡方分析 (chi-squared test)，以瞭解人口統計變數、消費者先前的購買狀態是否與消費者購買意願之間具有關聯性。最後，再透過單因子多變量變異數分析 (one-way MANOVA) 來瞭解人口統計變數、有無購買經驗與具顯著影響之因素間之關聯為何，以進一步瞭解人口統計變數及先前有無購買使用之經驗在消費價值或態度上是否有所差異。
台灣地區竹炭產品之消費價值與市場選擇行為研究

問卷內容共計有9部份，除了第一、第八與第九部分是透過名目尺度衡量外，其餘第二到第七部份皆是利用利用李克特五點式量表進行衡量。第一部份為有無購買經驗，用來衡量受測者是否具有購買竹炭產品的經驗。第二部份為綠色消費態度，此部分的變數內容有9個問項來瞭解受測者的綠色消費態度。第三部份為功能性價值，內容有13個問項，以瞭解受測者對這些產品之功能性價值的重視程度。第四部份為社會性價值，內容有10個問項，來瞭解受測者受到這些參考群體的影響程度。第五部份為情感性價值，內容有7個問項，以瞭解受測者受到竹炭產品所帶來的情感價值之影響程度。第六部份為嘗新性價值，內容有5個問項，以瞭解受測者對竹炭產品的創新性為何。第七部份為條件性價值，內容有8個問項，以瞭解受測者在某些情境下願意接受竹炭產品的程度為何。第八部份為選擇行為，用來詢問受訪者是否會決定購買竹炭產品。第九部份為人口統計變數，用來描述潛在消費者之特徵。
消費價值與市場選擇理論

Purchased behavior是否曾經購買過竹炭相關產品1曾經購買過2未曾購買過Green consumption attitude綠色消費態度─意指消費者對具有符合環保概念綠色商品之消費態度，是影響綠色消費行為的重要因素。1非常不同意2不同意3普通4同意5非常同意Functional value功能性價值─意指產品或品牌若具有某些功能上、效用上或實體上之屬性，透過這些屬性藉以滿足消費者對使用該產品之功能或效用要求之價值。1非常不重視2不重視3普通4重視5非常重視Social value社會性價值─意指產品或品牌能在消費者與其他社會群體相結合時，提昇該產品效用之價值。消費者的購買行為有時是為取得社會群體的認同、符合社會規範，或是展現內在的形象。1非常無影響2無影響3普通4有影響5非常有影響Emotional value情感性價值─意指產品或品牌具有激發改變消費者某些情緒或是情感狀態之效用或能力之價值。消費者之消費行為中許多非計畫性或衝動型之消費，經常是由情感性價值所影響的。1非常不同意2不同意3普通4同意5非常同意Epistemic value嘗新性價值─意指產品或品牌具有引發消費者好奇感，提供新奇感或滿足消費者對知識追求渴望之效用與價值。此項效用通常發生於對消費者較不熟悉或較為複雜之事物，促使消費者購買非為滿足功能性或其他功能需求之事物，如新商品或娛樂性商品等。1非常不同意2不同意3普通4同意5非常同意Conditional value條件性價值─意指產品或品牌在某些環境與情境中，具有暫時提昇功能性或社會性價值之能力。條件性價值基本上是導因於短暫性的情境因素，改變消費者的消費行為，提昇產品之價值或效用，情境因素若消失，產品之價值或效用將隨之降低。1非常不同意2不同意3普通4同意5非常同意Choice behavior決定是否購買竹炭相關產品1會買2不會買Gender性別1男2女Marital status婚姻狀況1已婚2未婚Age年齡124歲以下225-29歲330-34歲435-39歲540-44歲645-49歲750-54歲855-59歲960歲以上Educational level教育程度1小學以下2國中3高中(職)4專科5大學6研究所以上Occupation職業1軍公教2工3商4自由業5家庭主婦6學生7農林漁牧8待業中Family revenue家庭月所得12萬以下22-4萬34-6萬46-8萬58-10萬610萬以上Residence area居住地區1北部地區2中部地區3南部地區4東部地區5離島地區
台灣、西表島與香港銀葉樹族群遺傳多樣性之研究

銀葉樹是一種能生長在陸地，亦可適生於潮間帶的正紅樹類植物，雖然在亞洲、澳洲及非洲等地均可見，但由於過度伐採與生育地破壞，導致族群數量銳減，正面臨嚴重威脅。本研究以台灣、香港及日本西表島等地區6個族群60個單株應用簡單序列重覆分子指紋技術，來探討台灣與鄰近島嶼銀葉樹族群遺傳結構及各族群間的親緣關係。依POPGENE分析的結果顯示，總基因歧異度(H)為0.2888，族群間遺傳分化係數(Gst)為0.2742，基因流(Nm)為0.6618，顯示族群已具分化結構。族群間基因流傳並不暢通，不同島嶼間已明顯呈現分化現象，推測應受到島嶼區隔及海流方向影響。經由UPGMA歸群分析結果可區分為三群，即台灣、香港及西表島之族群各自成群，島嶼間以台灣與香港的族群較相近，而西表島的族群遺傳距離則較遠。Mantel test結果顯示族群間地理距離與遺傳距離雖呈正相關但不顯著(r=0.47，P=0.13)，其族群呈隨機散佈，因此遺傳漂變在族群分化上扮演重要角色。族群的分子變方分析(AMOVA)顯示，族群間變方成分佔38.17%( p＜0.001)，族群內個體間的變方成分佔61.87% ( p＜0.001)，顯示族群變異主要於族群內個體之間。故就所得之族群遺傳訊息，建議除需採取就地保育之措施來保存所有族群外，並應進行遷地保育措施。

植物材料針對台灣恆春半島 ( 香蕉灣及港仔2個族群 )、東北角 ( 卯澳及福隆2個族群 )、香港（荔枝窩）及日本（西表島）等4個地區，計6個銀葉樹天然族群進行取樣，採集其幼嫩部位葉片，以供相關分析，採集地點、數量與地理位置詳如表1及圖1。於每族群內取樣時，每隔10~20m隨機選取一株，每單株選取無病蟲害之葉子5-10片，以透氣紙袋包裝後，再利用矽膠乾燥劑於室溫下脫水保存。DNA之萃取與ISSR的擴大反應參考Kobayashi 等人 ( 1998 ) 的CTAB萃取法進行萃取，分離出的DNA加入0.1ml的TE Buffer保存。並利用分光光度計進行DNA濃度 ( ng / μl ) 之測量。參考Zietkiewicz等人 ( 1994 ) 的方法，PCR反應溶液總體積為25μl，其內容物濃度為10 mM Tris-HCl ( pH 9.0 )，50 mM KCl，1.5 mM MgCl2，0.1 % Gelatin ( w/v ) ，1 % Triton X-100 ( w/v ) ，20 ng template DNA，200 μM dNTPs，0.2 μM Primer，1 units Taq polymerase ( Protech Technology Enterprise co., Ltd ) ，於溫度循環器thermocycler ( Applied Biosystems Geneamp PCR System 9700, Foster City, USA ) 進行PCR反應設定溫度循環程序，94℃，6分鐘 ( initial denaturing step ) 後，加上35次循環的：94℃， 60 秒 DNA ( denaturing )，50.6℃-60.5℃， 50 秒，黏合溫度 ( annealing ) 依引子不同而定 ( 表2 )，72℃，2 分15秒 ( elongation ) ，72℃，7 分鐘 ( final elongatoin step ) 最後降溫至4℃ ( end ) 。（Ⅲ）電泳、染色與照相配製1.5 % Agarose，將完成擴大反應的DNA樣本添加追蹤染劑 [ tracking dye ( 0.25 % bromophenol blue, 0.25 % xylene cyanol FF, 30 % glycerol in water )] 與100 bp DNA Ladder，然後以電壓150V進行電泳分析，約2-2.5 h。完成電泳的膠片以溴化乙錠 ( ethidium bromide ) 染色並置於UV燈上顯影觀察，且以Vilber Lourmat CN-100拍照作為記錄。族群遺傳參數1. 記錄強度較強且清晰的DNA片段，有條帶出現者記錄為1，無條帶者記錄為0。利用NTSYS-pc ver. 2.0套裝軟體 ( Rohlf, 1993 )，以Dice公式計算兩兩樣本間之相似度（SAB），建立相似度矩陣（Ssm）。 SAB =2 NAB / （2NAB+ NA+ NB）SAB=兩兩樣本間之相似度。NA=僅在樣本A出現的條帶數。NB=僅在樣本B出現的條帶數。NAB =在樣本A與在樣本B皆出現的條帶數。2. 將各族群之條帶記錄以POPGENE ver. 1.31套裝軟體（Yeh et al, 1999）計算族群間的遺傳資料，包含Nei’s基因歧異度 ( H ) ( Nei, 1973 )。Ho = - Σpi ( lnPi ) ；Pi指某個DNA片段出現的頻度 ( frequency ) 。Shannon's多型性訊息指數 ( I )（Shannon and Weaver, 1949）。如假設各族群近親交配指數 ( Fis ) 為0，則可計算族群間遺傳分化係數Gst ( coefficient of gene differentiation ) ，再利用Gst估算基因流傳值Nm ( Nm = 0.25 × ( 1-Gst ) / Gst ) (Slatkin and Barton, 1989)。3. 進行AMOVA ( Analysis of Molecular Variance ) 分析，以Excoffer et al. ( 1992 ) 所發表兩兩族群的距離公式求得距離矩陣D。D=N ( 1-Ssm ) = N ( 1-M/N ) ； M=兩兩樣本相同條帶數；N=多型性條帶總數。將距離矩陣以AMOVA ver. l.55程式進行分析（Excoffer et al., 1992 )，求得地區間、地區內、族群間、族群內個體間之變方成份值及各變方成份所佔總變方成份的百分比，並用9999次之隨機重排列檢定 ( random permutation test ) ，測驗各變方成分之顯著性，並繪製成不同層級之分析歸納表。4. 將AMOVA計算得之族群間遺傳距離 (Φst ) 矩陣，以NTSYS之配對不加權算數平均值 ( UPGMA ) 的方法進行歸群分析 ( Cluster analysis ) 建立樹枝圖（Sokal and Michener, 1958）。同時透過主座標分析 ( Principal coordinates analysis, PCoA ) 來繪製樣本分布圖，以及運用Mantel test ( Mantel, 1967 ) 來檢測遺傳距離矩陣 ( Φst ) 與相對地理矩陣間的相關性 ( r )。此外UPGMA歸群分析與原距離矩陣間的吻合程度以協表相關係數 ( r ) 來估計，且同樣運用Mantel Z 統計進行( Mantel, 1967 )。

Typhoon impacts on stream water chemistry in a plantation and an adjacent natural forest in central Taiwan

We studied the hydro-chemical responses to a category 3 typhoon of two forested watersheds at Lienhuachi Experimental Forest: a 24 year old China-fir plantation (WS4) and a natural hardwood forest (WS5). One hundred and nineteen millimeters of precipitation fell in 26 h resulting in a peak stream flow of 80 l s1 ha1 in WS4 and 11 l s1 ha1 in WS5 despite a much lower base flow at WS4: 0.012 l s1 ha1 as compared to 0.38 l s1 ha1 at WS5. Stream water conductivity, an indicator of overall ionic strength, decreased by approximately 50% in WS4 and 30% in WS5. The observation that the China-fir plantation had a higher stream flow and ion fluctuation than the natural forest during typhoon Talim was the opposite of that observed during non-storm periods. The output of suspended solids in stream water was two orders of magnitudes higher in the plantation than in the natural forest during the storm period (8.8 vs. 0.06 kg ha1 net export of suspended solids). The plantation exhibited lower resistance than the natural forest to the stream water chemistry impacts of a category 3 typhoon with a return interval of six years. Among the 11 ions analyzed, nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium were the only elements that had higher concentrations in the natural forest than in the plantation, a pattern consistent with the aggradation of biomass and the concomitantly high demand on the macro-essential elements in the plantation. Conversion of a native broad leaf forest to a conifer plantation has persistent and large effects on hydrochemical cycling, changes that are still evident after two decades of growth.
Typhoon impacts on stream water chemistry in a plantation and an adjacent natural forest in central Taiwan
台北植物園蝶類相及族群變化

本研究在瞭解台北植物園之蝶相，並嘗試探討園中植物變化和經營管理方式對蝶相及其族群的影響。1989及1999年每月以穿越線調查法在台北植物園調查蝶類之種類和數量。1989年紀錄了7科47種1411隻次的蝶類，1999年紀錄了7科60種2221隻次，另檢查及鑑定1945年至1988年林業試驗所昆蟲標本館中採自植物園之蝶類標本共7科41種。台北植物園自1996年起其經營管理有很大變化，增設了許多主題展示區，增加的植物種類近600種，其中不少是蝶類的食草或蜜源植物，增加了蝶類族群數量和多樣性。但對蝶類造成負面影響的有除草的次數及竹區的改變，造成取食禾本科及竹類植物的單帶?蝶類和玉帶蔭蝶的數量驟降。由本研究的結果可以看出園區植物的改變與蝴蝶的種類和族群數量關係密切，並可作為棲地經營管理與物種保育的參考。
採集以穿越線方式於台北植物園進行調查鑑定將採集之樣本製成標本並計算數量

Dormancy-break and germination in seeds of Prunus campanulata (Rosaceae): Role of covering layers and changes in concentration of abscisic acid and gibberellin

Intact seeds (seed + endocarp) from freshly harvested fruits of Prunus campanulata were dormant and required 4~6 weeks of warm followed by 8 weeks of cold stratification for maximum germination percentage. Removing both endocarp and seed coat, however, promoted germination in a high percentage of nonstratified seeds. Treatment of intact nonstratified seeds with gibberellic acid (GA3) was only partially effective in breaking dormancy. However, GA3 promoted germination of nonstratified seeds in which the endocarp (but not the seed coat) had been removed. Order of ABA concentration in fresh seeds was endocarp > seed coat > embryo, and its concentration in endocarp plus seed coat was about 6.2-fold higher than that in the embryo. Total ABA contents of seeds subjected to warm and/or cold moist stratification were reduced 6~12-fold. A higher concentration of GA4 was detected in embryos of nondormant than in those of dormant seeds. Fluridone, an ABA biosynthesis inhibitor, was efficient in breaking dormancy of Prunus seeds. Paclobutrazol, a GA biosynthesis inhibitor, completely inhibited seed germination, and the inhibitory effect could be partially reversed by GA4 but not by GA3. Thus, dormancy in P. campanulata seeds is imposed by the covering layers. Dormancy-break is accompanied by a decrease in ABA in covering layers and embryo and germination by an increase of GA4 in embryo.

Plant materialsFruits of Prunus campanulata were collected in the field when they were mature, i.e. dark red or dark purple. More than 5000 mature fruits were collected from 5 trees at Alishan (23032’N, 120047’E), Chiayi County, central Taiwan at 2,000 m elevation in early May 2002. A small amount of green immature fruits also were collected 3 weeks before maturity. Seeds were extracted by removing the pulp (exocarp + mesocarp) in water, and the clean sunken seeds (with endocarp) were used for subsequent treatments. Seeds of P. campanulata are 8-9 mm in length and consist of a large embryo and a thin seed coat adhered to the small amount of endosperm. The seed is surrounded by a hard endocarp (Fig. 1). Thus, the word “seed” in this paper refers to the true seed plus endocarp, which is the germination unit in Prunus. Moisture content was determined for both fresh and treated seeds using three replications of 20 seeds each and calculated on a fresh-weight basis after oven drying for 17 hours at 103oC (ISTA, 1999).Effect of moist warm and moist cold stratification on germinationFreshly harvested seeds were placed on moist sphagnum in sealable polyethylene bags and warm-moist stratified for 4 or 6 weeks at 30/20oC (12/12 h) with 12 hours fluorescent light (80~100 µMol m-2 s-1) during the higher temperature portion of the regime. They were then cold-moist stratified at 4oC in dark for 4, 8 or 12 weeks. A cold-moist stratification treatment without warm treatment was also carried out on fresh seeds in moist sphagnum for 4, 8 or 12 weeks prior to testing them for germination. A treatment consisted of three replications of 50 seeds each. Moisture content of the sphagnum was about 400% of its dry mass.Effect of endocarp and seed coat on germinationTrue seeds (without endocarp but seed coat retained) and isolated embryos (without endocarp and seed coat) from freshly harvested seeds were placed on moist sphagnum in sealable polyethylene bags and germinated at 30/20oC (12/12 h) with 12 hours of fluorescent light during the high temperature portion of the regime. A treatment consisted of three replications of 50 seeds or embryos each. Germination was recorded three times a week, and germination percentages were calculated. Seeds (true seed plus endocarp) were as a control.Effect of GA3 on germination of intact seedsFreshly harvested, mature seeds were treated with concentrations of 0 (water control), 1.3, 2.6 and 5.2 mM GA3 (K-GA3) (95% purity, Sigma, St. Louis, MO, USA) for 16 hours at room temperature prior to germination. To enhance passage of GA3 solutions through the endocarp and seed coat, seeds with the various GA3 concentrations were placed in a vacuum container at a pressure of 30 cm Hg (0.4 atmospheric pressure) for 16 or 72 hours. Seeds with the endocarp removed also were treated with the above-described GA3 concentrations in addition to 0.26 mM GA3 for 16 hours. Each treatment consisted of 3 replicates of 50 seeds each. These treated seeds were then mixed with moist sphagnum for germination testing.Effect of fluridone, paclobutrazol, GA3, GA4, ABA and of combinations of them on germination of true seedsFluridone (1-methyl-3-phenyl-5-[3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]-4-(1H)-pyridinone) was obtained from Olchemim Ltd.(> 97% purity, Czech Republic), paclobutrazol ((2RS,3RS)-1-(4-chlorophenyl)-4,4-dimethyl-2-(1,2,4-triazolyl)-pentan-3-ol) from Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd. (97% purity, Japan), (±)-ABA from Sigma (99% purity, St. Louis, MO, USA) and GA4 from Sigma (≥ 90% purity, St. Louis, MO, USA). Due to the inhibitory effect of hard endocarp on germination, mature true seeds (without endocarp but seed coat retained) were soaked for 24 hours in double distilled water, two concentrations (10 and 50 μM) of ABA, GA3, GA4, fluridone, paclobutrazol and in combinations of these compounds. The solution-treated true seeds were then mixed with moist sphagnum and germinated at 30/20oC (12/12 h) with 12 hours fluorescent light during the higher temperature portion of the regime. A treatment consisted of three replications of 25 seeds each. Germination was recorded three times a week, and germination percentages were calculated. The seed lot used in this experiment was harvested in April 2006.Germination testsUnless otherwise stated, germination tests were carried out in a growth chamber for up to 12 weeks at an alternating temperature of 30/20oC (12/12 h) with 12 hours of fluorescent light during the high temperature portion of the regime, i.e. the same conditions as those used for warm stratification. Sphagnum served as the germination medium. Seeds were considered to have germinated when the radicle was at least 5 mm long. Germination was recorded weekly, and results were expressed as percent germination and as mean germination time (MGT) in days (Naylor, 1981). MGT = (Σniti)/N, where ni is the number of seeds germinated in ti days from the beginning of the test, and N is the total number of germinated seeds at the end of the test. MGT is a measure of the rate of germination and of the sharpness of the germination peak.Growth regulator analysesThe endocarp, seed coat (with adhering endosperm), embryo (cotyledons + axis) and pulp (exocarp + mesocarp) were separated individually from immature fruits collected 3 weeks before maturity (green pulp) and from freshly mature fruits (dark red or dark purple). Further, the endocarp, seed coat and embryo were separated from seeds (endocarp + true seed) warm moist-stratified only at 30/20oC for 6 weeks, from seeds cold moist-stratified only at 4oC for 12 weeks, from seeds warm moist-stratified at 30/20oC for 6 weeks and then cold moist-stratified at 4oC for 8 weeks (nondormant seeds) and from germinated seeds. In all cases, parts were separated from 50 fruits or seeds, lyophilized and weighed. Then, two replications of each fruit/seed part were stored at -80oC until they could be analyzed for the growth regulators ABA and GAs. Levels of endogenous ABA, GA1, GA3, GA4, GA7 and GA20 were determined by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry-selected ion monitoring (GC-MS-SIM).Embryos, seed coats and pulp were ground separately in liquid N2 using a mortar and pestle, and the endocarps were finely pulverized using an ultracentrifugal mill (Retsch, Germany). Origin of the internal standards were added to each sample after grinding as follows: 100 ng of [2H6]ABA and 50 ng of [17,17-2H2]GAs (GA1, GA3, GA4, GA7 and GA20). Tissue extraction was carried out overnight with 15 ml of 80% (v/v) MeOH containing 0.4 mg of butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT) and 2 mg of ascorbate at 4oC, and the residue was re-extracted in the same solvent for 2 hours at 4oC. The MeOH extracts were combined and reduced to 1~2 ml of water residue using both prepurified N2 airflow and SpeedVac (Savant Instruments, Massachusetts, USA).The residue with internal standards was adjusted to pH 8.5 with 0.05 M K-Pi buffer and passed through a polyvinylpolypyrrolidone (PVPP) column (approximately 5 g). The eluate was partitioned with ethyl acetate (EtOAc) (3 x 15 ml). The aqueous fraction was then adjusted to pH 3.0 with 0.5 M K-Pi buffer (pH 2.0) and partitioned with EtOAc (3 x 15 ml). The pooled EtOAc fraction was taken to dryness by the SpeedVac. The residue was dissolved in 0.05 M K-Pi buffer (pH 3.0) and loaded onto a preconditioned ODS-silica column (approximately 3 g). The ODS-silica column was washed 3 times with ddH2O in 0.1% HOAc and eluted with 80% aqueous MeOH containing 0.1% HOAc.Following drying in vacuo using the SpeedVac, the sample was dissolved in 30% aqueous MeOH containing 0.1% acetic acid and injected onto a Beckman System Gold HPLC with LiChrosphere RP-18 column (250 x 4 mm i.d. x 5-µm particle size, Merck, Germany) for further separation of ABA and GAs. Running conditions for HPLC were similar to those described by Nakayama et al. (2001) as follows: solvent A was 100% MeOH and solvent B 30% aqueous MeOH containing 0.1% HOAc; 0~2 min, 0% solvent A; 2~42 min, 0~100% solvent A; 42~52 min, 100% solvent A; flow rate, 0.6 ml min-1; fractionation, at 1 min intervals. Appropriate retention times of ABA and the GAs in HPLC: 17~20 min, GA1 and GA3; 26~28 min, GA20 and ABA; 29~30 min, GA7; and 34~35 min, GA4.GC-MS-SIM analysisThe HPLC fractions were dried using SpeedVac and derivatized by adding ethereal diazomethane, then dried with N2. GAs and ABA were further trimethysilylated with 50 µl pyridine plus 100 µl of N,N'-bis(trimethylsilyl)trifluoroacetamide (BSTFA) with 1% trimethylchlorosilane (TMCS) (Macherey-Nagel, USA) at 90oC for 30 min. The derivatized samples were analyzed using a HP 6890 GC and 5973 MSD with DB-1 capillary column (30 m x 0.25 mm i.d., 0.25 µm film thickness, J&W Scientific, USA). Operating conditions of GC-MS were similar to those described by Nakayama et al. (2001). The carrier gas was helium at a flow rate of 1 ml min-1, and the interface temperature of the ion source was 250oC. The MS source temperature was 200oC, and the electron energy was 70 eV. The split/splitless injector was used in the splitless mode at 250oC. The oven temperature was programmed to begin at 60oC for 2 min, then raised to 210oC at a rate of 30oC min-1 and to 280oC at a rate of 2oC min-1, where it remained for 5 min. The sample was dissolved in 10 µl of hexane, and 1 µl of it was injected. For ABA, GA1, GA3, GA4, GA7 and GA20, the m/z 190/194, 506/508, 504/506, 284/286, 222/224 and 418/420 ratios, respectively, were used for quantification.Statistical analysisRadicle protrusion data were transformed to percentages based on number of treated seeds. Concentrations of GAs and ABA were calculated from two replications and expressed by mean ± SD. Germination percentages (mean ± SE) were calculated, and means were compared by analysis of variance (ANOVA) and by least significant difference (LSD) test at the 5% level of significance (SAS Institute, 2004).

Oxygenated Lignans from the Fruits of Schisandra arisanensis

An acetone extract of the fruits of the Taiwanese medicinal plant Schisandra arisanensis has yielded 11 new oxygenated lignans. Four of these, named arisantetralones A-D (1-4), possess the aryltetralone skeleton, while the other seven, named arisanschinins F-L (5-11), are polyoxygenated C18-dibenzocyclooctadiene lignans. Structures were determined on the basis of spectroscopic analyses, especially 2D-NMR techniques. The structure of compound 1 was confirmed by X-ray crystallographic analysis. Immunomodulatory activity of the isolated lignans was tested and evaluated.
